{"timeCrawl": "16:49:00", "uri": "710438406", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:03:00Z", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "source": {"title": "MMA Fighting", "uri": "mmafighting.com", "id": "5020"}, "url": "https://www.mmafighting.com/2017/8/15/16152210/association-of-ringside-physicians-nac-for-caution-allowing-glove-change-for-mayweather-vs-mcgregor", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "The Association of Ringside Physicians (ARP) is asking the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to exercise \"caution\" in its hearing for the requested change in glove size for the Floyd Mayweather vs. Conor McGregor boxing match.\n\nIn a letter from the ARP to the NAC sent Tuesday, ARP board chairman Dr. Raymond Monsell writes that Mayweather vs. McGregor \"has already been set a specified weight class,\" which requires 10-ounce gloves per NAC regulations. Teams for Mayweather and McGregor will be requesting a change to 8-ounce gloves Wednesday at the NAC's meeting for the Aug. 26 bout in Las Vegas.\n\n\"Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of the bout, we should strongly caution against allowing current regulations to be over-ruled,\" Monsell wrote. \"To do so would also set a precedent for future bouts.\"\n\nUnder NAC and most boxing rules, in fights that take place under 147 pounds athletes can wear 8-ounce gloves. But Mayweather vs. McGregor is being contested at 154 pounds and the regulations say 10-ounce gloves are required. NAC executive director Bob Bennett told MMA Fighting two weeks ago that both teams can get a waiver to wear 8-ounce gloves if the commissioners vote in favor of that.\n\n\"They would have to come before the commission and articulate why they should be permitted to have their fight using 8-ounce gloves,\" Bennett said. \"The chairman (Anthony Marnell) and commissioners would make the determination with the health and safety of the fighters being the number-one priority.\"\n\nMayweather said last week that he would be trying to give McGregor another \"advantage\" by making the glove size lighter, since McGregor wears 4-ounce gloves in the UFC. McGregor said he doesn't care either way what the glove size is, but is predicting he'll knock out Mayweather within two rounds if the 8-ounce gloves are worn.\n\n\"Both guys have agreed that they want to fight in 8-ounce gloves,\" Mayweather Promotions CEO Leonard Ellerbe said last week at Mayweather's media workout day. \"Both guys are looking to knock each other out. The smaller the gloves, the better. Conor is used to fighting in 4-ounce gloves, Floyd is used to fighting in 8-ounce gloves.\n\n\"I think it's a good thing. I think with the mindset that both guys have, they're looking to knock each other out. ... This isn't a game or anything. If the commission approves it, both guys will be wearing the same ounce gloves. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell led the way in approving the smaller gloves, MMA Fighting reports that the ARP sent a letter to the NSAC on Tuesday arguing against changing the glove size from ten ounces to eight. Teams for both fighters have asked for the change.\n\n\"Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of the bout, we should strongly caution against allowing current regulations to be over-ruled,\" ARP board chairman Dr. Raymond Monsell wrote. \"To do so would also set a precedent for future bouts.\"\n\nUnder most boxing rule sets, athletes can wear eight-ounce gloves in fights that take place under 147 pounds. {"timeCrawl": "16:48:00", "uri": "710438398", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T20:03:00Z", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "source": {"title": "Sherdog", "uri": "sherdog.com", "id": "9076"}, "url": "http://www.sherdog.com/news/news/Association-of-Ringside-Physicians-Cautions-Against-Changing-Glove-Size-for-MayweatherMcGregor-126125", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "The Nevada Athletic Commission will decide on Wednesday whether to allow Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor to wear eight-ounce boxing gloves for their Aug. 26 bout.\n\nHowever, the Association of Ringside Physicians is urging the NAC to vote against allowing the combatants to wear anything lighter than the 10-ounce gloves that were originally agreed upon by both Mayweather and McGregor. The letter from the Association of Ringside Physicians to the NAC is as follows:\n\nThe Association of Ringside Physicians understands that consideration is being given to amend current regulations, and in so doing, permit the use of [eight-pounce] gloves in the forthcoming boxing match between Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor. This is a bout that has already been set a specified weight class. Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of this bout, we would caution strongly against allowing current regulations to be overruled. To do so would set a precedent for future bouts.\n\nNAC executive director Bob Bennett confirmed to Sherdog.com last week that the commission would listen to reasoning as to \"why we should deviate from our regulations from 10-ounce gloves to eight-ounce gloves.\"\n\nTen-ounce gloves are standard for fights at 147 pounds and above in Nevada. Meanwhile, eight-ounce gloves are utilized for bouts taking place at 135 pounds and below. Matchups between 135 and 147 pounds can utilize either eight- or 10-ounce gloves, depending on what both parties agree to use.\n\nBoth Mayweather and McGregor have traded barbs on social media recently regarding the size of the gloves. McGregor, the UFC lightweight champion, is accustomed to wearing four-ounce gloves in the Octagon. Both fighters submitted a waiver to the NSAC.\n\nThe Nevada commission voted unanimously to approve the one-time exception to its own regulations, which state any boxing match contested above 147 pounds mandates 10-ounce gloves.\n\nIn addition, Robert Byrd was named as the referee on Wednesday for the main event at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas. The NSAC appointed veteran judges Burt Clements, Dave Moratti and Guido Cavalleri to work the bout.\n\nThe 40-year-old Mayweather (49-0, 26 KOs) took to social media earlier this month to say that he was in favor of wearing the 8-ounce gloves.\n\n\"I'm telling McGregor, 'Let's fight in 8 oz gloves,'\" Mayweather wrote. \"McGregor can fight in any brand he prefers or chooses. I'll be wearing 8 oz Grant gloves. Whatever advantage McGregor needs to feel more comfortable in the ring, I'm willing to accommodate.\"\n\nThe 29-year-old McGregor (21-3), who is the UFC's lightweight champion, uses 4-ounce gloves in mixed martial arts bouts. He was quick to respond to the social media post, saying he didn't care about glove size and pointed to Mayweather's \"brittle hands.\"\n\nNeither fighter has competed this year. {"timeCrawl": "23:39:00", "uri": "710597448", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T23:39:00Z", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "source": {"title": "ESPN.com", "uri": "espn.com", "id": "4"}, "url": "http://www.espn.com/boxing/story/_/id/20362700", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "UFC star Conor McGregor had agreed to box Floyd Mayweather Jr. in 10-ounce gloves, per Nevada State Athletic Commission rules, but was pleased that the panel agreed at its monthly meeting Wednesday to allow them to wear 8-ounce gloves.\n\n\"I'm very happy with how the Nevada State Athletic Commission handled it. They handled it fairly and they listened to both requests,\" McGregor said on a teleconference with reporters to talk about the heavily hyped fight with Mayweather on Aug. 26 (Showtime PPV) at the T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas.\n\nAlthough Nevada rules stipulate that in boxing matches contracted over 147 pounds the fighters must use 10-ounce gloves, McGregor wanted smaller ones and Mayweather agreed. So, both submitted formal requests to the commission asking for it to issue a waiver for their fight, which is contracted at 154 pounds.\n\nThe commissioners voted unanimously to give the fighters the waiver on Wednesday, when they also appointed Robert Byrd as the referee and Burt Clements, Dave Moretti and Guido Cavalleri as judges.\n\n\"Overall their approach to the decision [about the gloves], the judges and referee -- they were fair throughout in taking into consideration both fighters' requests,\" McGregor said.\n\nMcGregor is accustomed to fighting his UFC bouts in 4-ounce fingerless gloves and said he believed that the lighter boxing gloves will make his punching power more effective against Mayweather, though he acknowledged that the lighter gloves could also give Mayweather even faster hands than he already has.\n\n\"I think that's it in a nutshell. You have pros and cons on both sides,\" he said of the new glove size. \"Both athletes were asking for it, and me, I'm coming up in ounces from what I am used to. Hey, look what I fight with. I fight in 4-ounce fingerless gloves. [The change] benefits both of us in certain ways.\"\n\nOf course, McGregor said he believes the change will benefit him more. He had been predicting a fourth-round knockout, but now that he can wear smaller gloves he said Mayweather won't go past the second round.\n\n\"We are prepared for every possible outcome,\" McGregor said. \"Part of me wants to show some skill and dismantle him that way, [but] I'm ready to put him away in the first 10 seconds.\"\n\nUFC president Dana White said he also believes the switch to the lighter gloves will have a major impact on the fight.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said. \"Yes, Floyd will be faster with 8-ounce gloves, but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves help him big time. I think it absolutely does [work in McGregor's favor].\"\n\nWhite said he was unsure why Mayweather agreed to go along with McGregor's request for the smaller gloves but is happy that he did. He said the topic never came up in the negotiations for the fight as 10-ounce gloves were always what they figured they would fight with due to the Nevada rules.\n\n\"I don't know what's changed, but I'm glad it did,\" White said.\n\nMcGregor has his option of wearing any brand glove that the commission will approve, but he said he has not decided which kind he will wear.\n\n\"We're still in discussion on that,\" McGregor said.\n\nMayweather has fought almost all of his professional fights in 8-ounce gloves, since virtually all of his bouts have been at 147 pounds or less. He has said he will wear the same Grant brand gloves he always wears.", "id": "9584026", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "McGregor 'very happy' with move to 8-oz gloves", "image": {"timeCrawl": "04:48:00", "uri": "710679492", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:48:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"title": "ABS-CBN SPORTS", "uri": "sports.abs-cbn.com", "id": "6300"}, "url": "http://sports.abs-cbn.com/boxing/news/2017/08/17/mayweather-mcgregor-will-fight-smaller-gloves-29826", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Conor McGregor trains during a workout for the media, Friday, Aug. 11, 2017, in Las Vegas. McGregor is scheduled to fight Floyd Mayweather Jr. in a boxing match Aug. 26 in Las Vegas. (AP Photo/John Locher)\n\nBy Tim Dahlberg, Associated Press\n\nLAS VEGAS (AP) -- Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor got their wish to fight in smaller gloves, but not before being chastised by a Nevada boxing official for using the issue to hype their fight later this month.\n\nNevada boxing regulators on Wednesday gave the two fighters an exemption to a rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for fights at 154 pounds, approving 8-ounce gloves for the Aug. 26 bout. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMcGregor said the gloves will only speed up the end of the fight, which he earlier predicted wouldn't last four rounds.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is also more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.\n\nThe glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favor of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. McGregor has never boxed before, but quickly agreed to Mayweather's challenge on social media to fight in smaller gloves.\n\nUFC chief Dana White echoed McGregor in saying the smaller gloves will make a difference in the fight.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nCommissioners said they struggled with making an exception to regulations in place since 2006, but decided to approve the waiver because of the unusual nature of the event.\n\n\"The fight is not normal,\" said commissioner Sandra Morgan.\n\nJohn Hornewer, an attorney for Mayweather, said the unbeaten boxer would likely not be at the 154-pound limit at the fight weigh-in anyway.\n\n\"He'll be 150 pounds. That's his best weight and there's no reason to put on extra weight,\" Hornewer said.\n\nA McGregor representative said his fighter has been about 160 pounds in training camp and would likely enter the ring somewhere around that weight after making the 154-pound limit the day before.", "id": "9611625", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Mayweather and McGregor will fight in smaller {"timeCrawl": "15:14:00", "uri": "710391270", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:59:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"title": "SB Nation", "uri": "sbnation.com", "id": "962"}, "url": "https://www.sbnation.com/2017/8/16/16156064/mayweather-mcgregor-arp-no-glove-reduction", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Worried about safety, the Association of Ringside Physicians supports 10 ounce gloves rather than 8 ounce\n\nAfter Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor agreed to fight in 8 ounce gloves rather than the standard 10 ounces in their Aug. 26 bout, the Association of Ringside Physicians (ARP) asked the Nevada State Athletic Commission (NSAC) to deny the glove change.\n\nThe NSAC has to vote on whether the fighters can reduce the size of their gloves. However, the ARP urged the NSAC not to vote in favor of the change in an official release.\n\nThe Association of Ringside Physicians understands that consideration is being given to amend current regulations, and in so doing, permit the use of 8oz Gloves in the forthcoming boxing match between Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor. This is a bout that has already been set a specific weight class. Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of this bout, we would strongly caution against allowing current regulation to be over-ruled. To do so would also set a precent for future bouts.\n\n(via Jesse Holland of MMAmania.com)\n\nMayweather proposed to McGregor that they should fight in 8 ounce gloves instead of 10 ounces on his Instagram page, according to Holland.\n\n\"I'll be wearing 8oz. Grant gloves. McGregor can fight in any brand he prefers or chooses. Whatever advantage McGregor needs to feel more comfortable in the ring, I'm willing to accommodate,\" Mayweather, 49-0, posted.\n\nMcGregor, 29, agreed moments later, telling Mayweather, 40, to pick whatever size gloves he wants. \"I fight with 4oz. I don't give a fuck about the size of the glove. I am coming sprinting at you with bricks. Know that. Brittle hands.\"\n\nThe UFC lightweight champion also said that he doesn't care about fighting with lighter gloves because he uses 4ounce gloves in the UFC. \"If we're wearing eight-ounce gloves, I'm struggling to see how he lasts two rounds, and that's the God's honest truth.\"\n\nMayweather told the Boxing Scene that McGregor was complaining about the glove sizes. \"So I said, 'Listen, let's do eight ounces. I want to do anything so that you feel that you have an advantage. {"timeCrawl": "23:19:00", "uri": "710591023", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T23:19:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"title": "Chicago Sun-Times", "uri": "chicago.suntimes.com", "id": "762"}, "url": "http://chicago.suntimes.com/sports/mayweather-mcgregor-get-ok-to-use-smaller-boxing-gloves/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "LAS VEGAS (AP) -- Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor got their wish to fight in smaller gloves, but not before being chastised by a Nevada boxing official for using the issue to hype their fight later this month.\n\nNevada boxing regulators on Wednesday gave the two fighters an exemption to a rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for fights at 154 pounds, approving 8-ounce gloves for the Aug. 26 bout. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMcGregor said the gloves will only speed up the end of the fight, which he earlier predicted wouldn't last four rounds.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is also more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.\n\nThe glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favor of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. McGregor has never boxed before, but quickly agreed to Mayweather's challenge on social media to fight in smaller gloves.\n\nUFC chief Dana White echoed McGregor in saying the smaller gloves will make a difference in the fight.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nCommissioners said they struggled with making an exception to regulations in place since 2006, but decided to approve the waiver because of the unusual nature of the event.\n\n\"The fight is not normal,\" said commissioner Sandra Morgan.\n\nJohn Hornewer, an attorney for Mayweather, said the unbeaten boxer would likely not be at the 154-pound limit at the fight weigh-in anyway.\n\n\"He'll be 150 pounds. That's his best weight and there's no reason to put on extra weight,\" Hornewer said.\n\nA McGregor representative said his fighter has been about 160 pounds in training camp and would likely enter the ring somewhere around that weight after making the 154-pound limit the day before.", "id": "9581668", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Mayweather, McGregor get OK to use smaller Under [10] ounce, he is certainly unconscious and that's it.\"\n\nNow McGregor has his wish and he'll face Mayweather wearing eight-ounce gloves when they step in the ring together on Aug. 26 in Las {"timeCrawl": "08:01:00", "uri": "710754379", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:11:00Z", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "source": {"title": "Herald and News", "uri": "heraldandnews.com", "id": "12156"}, "url": "http://www.heraldandnews.com/sports/mayweather-and-mcgregor-will-fight-in-smaller-gloves/article_e1181826-9b12-5b75-a2e0-f740070f868c.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "LAS VEGAS (AP) -- Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor got their wish to fight in smaller gloves, but not before being chastised by a Nevada boxing official for using the issue to hype their fight later this month.\n\nNevada boxing regulators on Wednesday gave the two fighters an exemption to a rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for fights at 154 pounds, approving 8-ounce gloves for the Aug. 26 bout. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\n\u00d7 Advertisement\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMcGregor said the gloves will only speed up the end of the fight, which he earlier predicted wouldn't last four rounds.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is also more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.\n\nThe glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favor of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. Its promoters will have five days after Sunday's total eclipse of the sun to turn attention back to their Aug. 26 boxing match between unbeaten boxing champ Floyd Mayweather and pro cage fighter Conor McGregor.\n\nAlready making things more interesting going into \"eclipse weekend,\" the odds are tightening and some problematic lighter gloves have been approved for the fight.\n\nThe Nevada State Athletic Commission ruling on gloves added a dimension that the fight is a sanctioned boxing match, in addition to a made-for-whatever-goes Vegas event, and that McGregor was coming to the ring as a boxer, not a UFC mixed martial arts cage fighter.\n\nAs expected, Mayweather remains the favorite. But the odds have dropped as more fans put their money on the trash-talking McGregor, who claims he'll knock out \"Money\" Mayweather within four rounds.\n\nBefore the fight was even officially announced, Mayweather was a -2250 favorite while McGregor was at +950, CBS Sports noted. A little more than a week before what some are calling \"the biggest fight in history,\" Mayweather was just a -450 favorite while McGregor was a +325 underdog on Thursday, OddsShark.com said.\n\n(If you don't understand odds, it means everyone was still betting Mayweather will smear McGregor, but more people are starting to look for a long shot to come in, or are betting emotionally.)\n\nThe Bleacher Report suggested part of this could be due to McGregor's attention-making antics during the two fighters' four-city promotional tour, including some dicey dialogue between them.\n\nMcGregor got back in the spotlight by bringing up lighter gloves.\n\nMcGregor is accustomed to fighting in 4-ounce gloves, but the Nevada State Athletic Commission typically requires boxers to fight in 10-ounce gloves when competing at 154 pounds or more, USA Today noted, with more padding to absorb more shock generated by higher bodyweights.\n\nMcGregor predicted he would \"floor\" Floyd in the first round if they were boxing with lighter gloves.\n\n\"If we are in 8-ounce gloves, he will be floored multiple times in the first round,\" McGregor said. \"I believe first-round KO in 8-ounce gloves. {"timeCrawl": "23:28:00", "uri": "710593977", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T23:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com", "id": "104"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/boxing-mma-wrestling/floyd-mayweather-conor-mcgregor-to-fight-using-8-ounce-gloves/2017/08/16/585a5bc6-82ab-11e7-ab27-1a21a8e006ab_story.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Ten days before he's scheduled to step into the boxing ring against undefeated world champion Floyd Mayweather, Conor McGregor, never lacking in confidence, feels like he's already scored a key victory. With the change in glove size, he has revised his pre-fight prediction, promising a knockout in the second round instead of the fourth.\n\n\"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds,\" McGregor said. \"We are ready for absolutely every scenario. I am ready to go to war for the full 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away in the first 10 seconds. That's where my head is at.\"\n\nThe Nevada State Athletic Commission has agreed to allow the fighters to wear smaller boxing gloves for their Aug. 26 fight in Las Vegas. The bout was granted a special exemption at the request of both fighters. McGregor and Mayweather will battle in 8-ounce gloves, not the 10-ounce variety typically required by the commission.\n\n[Early Lead: Big money comes in on Mayweather]\n\n\"It affects the contest a lot,\" said UFC President Dana White. \"First of all, Floyd will be faster with 8-ounce gloves. Floyd is a defensive master. .\u2009.\u2009. Connor hits like a truck. Smaller gloves favor him big time.\"\n\nMcGregor, the UFC's lightweight champion who has never before boxed professionally, has built his name and reputation wearing 4-ounce gloves used in mixed martial arts. He clearly believes Wednesday's ruling will give him added punching power.\n\n\"You've got pros and cons on both sides,\" he said on a teleconference. \"You got both athletes asking for the request and then you got me coming up in ounces from what I'm used to. I know the media likes to go, '10, eight .\u2009.\u2009. .' but look what I fight with. I fight with 4-ounce gloves. Fingerless gloves. The knuckles are barely covered with what I'm used to .\u2009.\u2009. so I'm very happy with it.\"\n\n[Early Lead: Mayweather says McGregor has the edge. Really.]\n\nWhile McGregor, 29, certainly feels the lighter gloves are to his advantage, Mayweather, 40, has actually fought most of his career wearing 8-ounce gloves and is the one who proposed the change. Under Nevada rules, fights contested above 147 pounds must be fought with 10-ounce gloves. Mayweather has only fought above 147 a few times, most notably his 2007 win over Oscar De La Hoya (154 pounds), his 2012 win over Miguel Cotto (154) and his 2013 win over Canelo Alvarez (a catchweight of 152).\n\n\"How often you've worn the gloves or any of that never factored in. I didn't even know that for instance,\" McGregor said of Mayweather's history with 8-ounce gloves. \"I do not care about his record. I do not care about his achievements. Every fight is on a fight-by-fight basis, so that's the way we approach it.\"\n\nDespite the change, Mayweather will still enter the fight as a heavy favorite. Considered one of the best defensive fighters in the history of the sport, he'll be facing an MMA star making his boxing debut. With a 49-0 record and more than 15 title belts over five weight classes, Mayweather, who retired from boxing following his last bout 23 months ago, has topped more seasoned fighters, most of them handily, regardless of glove size.\n\nEven if McGregor packs a stronger punch, he still faces the challenge of laying one of those 8-ounce gloves on his more experienced foe.", "id": "9582703", {"timeCrawl": "21:51:00", "uri": "710561364", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:51:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "Orlando Sentinel", "uri": "orlandosentinel.com", "id": "883"}, "url": "http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/la-sp-mayweather-mcgregor-gloves-20170816-story.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor were unanimously granted \"a one-fight exception\" Wednesday by the Nevada Athletic Commission to fight using lighter eight-ounce gloves for their unique Aug. 26 boxing match in Las Vegas.\n\nAdditionally, veteran referee Robert Byrd was named the third man in the ring for the bout that matches the 49-0, former five-division boxing champion Mayweather against the UFC champion McGregor in his pro boxing debut.\n\nThe commission, on the recommendation of Executive Director Bob Bennett, also selected Burt A. Clements, Dave Moretti and Italy's Guido Cavalerri as judges.\n\nByrd previously worked Mayweather's one-sided and uneventful unanimous-decision victory over Robert Guerrero in May 2013.\n\nThis bout is expected to be a far greater challenge for the referee, considering that McGregor is making his pro boxing debut and the possibility that he could turn to the rougher fighting techniques employed in the UFC.\n\nThe decision on the gloves came after both fighters lobbied for a change from a 2006 rule adopted as a safety measure that stipulates 10-ounce gloves for fights above 154 pounds. Bulkier, higher-weight gloves are believed to soften the impact of more forceful punches. McGregor has said he will likely weigh as much as 170 pounds on fight night.\n\nOne commissioner, Skip Avansino, said despite the fact that \"that's the rule,\" there has been no scientific study on why 10-ounce gloves are needed for 154-pound fights, and said an adjustment can be \"reconsidered by this unprecedented fight.\"\n\nChairman Anthony Marnell III said, \"My biggest concern is I don't like the Nevada commission being used as a pawn in a social-media battle,\" that occurred between the two fighters. \"If you cut a deal for a fight with this much money, you should get it right.\"\n\nMarnell said he wanted commissioners to screen the gloves as part of launching a new study to consider if 8-ounce gloves can be used in future 154-pound fights.\n\nMcGregor wanted gloves nearer in size to the 4-ounce gloves he uses as a UFC fighter, believing his punching power will be more effective.\n\n\"I'm strong enough to give him two rounds,\" in eight-ounce gloves, McGregor said. \"The only reason [Mayweather] can get to the second round is because in this game the referee gives him time to recover [with an eight-count] without getting his head pounded into the canvas. That's the only reason he might make it to the second round.\"\n\nIn the fight contract, Mayweather requested \"no Mexican-made gloves, no gloves made of horsehair, only 10-ounce. I didn't even know the difference,\" McGregor said. \"I didn't really care. Now he's pushing for the 8-ounce. Great.\"\n\nMayweather has said the 8-ounce gloves will give him more punching power, as well, which could enhance his chances of posting his first knockout victory since 2011.\n\nMcGregor's representative said at Wednesday's meeting that he believes \"there is no inherent risk to the health and safety\" of the Irishman by fighting Mayweather in 8-ounce gloves. The representative said McGregor has trained exclusively in 10-ounce gloves.\n\nThe McGregor representative said the gloves will not be Mexican-made or contain any horsehair.\n\nNevada Commissioner J. Daniel Carpenter, said, \"We want great entertainment, but we want the health and safety of the fighters, first and foremost,\" noting a recent MMA fighter's death, but also expressing trust in a referee like Byrd to stop punishment that could endanger either fighter.\n\n\"This is a hybrid fight. An individual who's never stepped foot in a boxing ring against one of the best ... boxers ever.\"\n\nIf the fight goes the distance, the outcome will be decided by the judges, including Moretti, who's judged 10 Mayweather fights since 2005.\n\nMoretti has been favorable to Mayweather in two of his most compelling bouts, awarding him a wide 118-110 (10 rounds to two) advantage in the record-setting 2015 bout against Manny Pacquiao, and giving Mayweather eight rounds in what was seen as a more narrow decision over Marcos Maidana in their first 2014 fight.\n\nCavalerri was added to the mix to fulfill a request by McGregor's camp to have one international judge as part of the panel.\n\nClements has worked four Mayweather fights, including the victories over Pacquiao and Juan Manuel Marquez in 2009.\n\nlance.pugmire@latimes.com\n\n@latimespugmire\n\nALSO\n\nNevada won't use referee Kenny Bayless for Mayweather-McGregor fight\n\nConor McGregor wants to keep boxing and {"timeCrawl": "17:28:00", "uri": "710456516", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "boxingscene.com", "uri": "boxingscene.com", "id": "1666"}, "url": "http://www.boxingscene.com/mayweather-mcgregor-8-ounce-gloves--119535", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "By Keith Idec\n\nThe Nevada State Athletic Commission voted unanimously Wednesday to allow Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor to wear eight-ounce gloves in their August 26 boxing match in Las Vegas.\n\nThe vote for this one-time approval was taken during the NSAC's regularly scheduled meeting in Las Vegas. The NSAC determined that wearing smaller gloves that have less padding poses no significantly greater threat to the health and safety of Mayweather and McGregor, a UFC superstar who'll make his professional boxing debut.\n\nMayweather's handlers petitioned the NSAC recently to use eight-ounce gloves because the boxing legend is willing to use the lighter gloves McGregor claimed Mayweather refused to wear during negotiations.\n\nIn accordance with Association of Boxing Commissions regulations, boxers who compete above the welterweight limit of 147 pounds are required to wear 10-ounce gloves. In bouts contested at or below the welterweight limit, ABC rules require boxers to wear eight-ounce gloves.\n\nThe weight limit for the 12-round bout between Las Vegas' Mayweather (49-0, 26 KOs) and Ireland's McGregor (21-3, 18 KOs in MMA) is boxing's junior middleweight maximum of 154 pounds.\n\nRepresentatives for Mayweather and McGregor agreed to use comparable gloves, but a brand was not mentioned during the meeting. They did state that they would not use what are considered \"puncher's gloves,\" which would give McGregor more of an advantage.\n\nNeither Mayweather nor McGregor attended the NSAC meeting Wednesday, but attorneys for both boxers accepted any additional liability that could come with using eight-ounce gloves in this Showtime Pay-Per-View main event.\n\nThe 40-year-old Mayweather mostly has fought with eight-ounce gloves during his 20-year pro career, but has used 10-ounce gloves for his three fights contested above 147 pounds (Oscar De La Hoya, Miguel Cotto and Canelo Alvarez). The 29-year-old McGregor is used to fighting in four-ounce gloves, the standard for professional mixed martial arts matches.\n\nMcGregor has predicted that wearing eight-ounce gloves will enable him to knock out Mayweather within two rounds.\n\nKeith Idec is a senior writer/columnist for BoxingScene.com. He can be reached on Twitter @Idecboxing.\n\nTags: Mayweather vs. McGregor Conor McGregor Floyd Mayweather Jr.", "id": "9532553", "details": {"liCnt": 3}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Mayweather {"timeCrawl": "12:13:00", "uri": "711430558", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:13:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "The Scottish Sun", "uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "id": "17001"}, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/boxing/1437807/floyd-mayweather-says-there-is-no-rematch-clause-in-conor-mcgregor-contract-as-insists-super-fight-will-be-his-last/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3371701", "body": "Undefeated 40-year-old says he has promised his children that next week's super-bout against the UFC star will be the final time he pulls on the gloves\n\nFLOYD MAYWEATHER has promised his kids that his mega-money showdown with Conor McGregor next week will be his last.\n\nThe 40-year-old is preparing for the 50th fight of his career next Saturday at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\nBut no matter the result, which he is heavy favourite for, Mayweather is adamant that he will not return to the ring again.\n\nHe has previously announced his retirement twice after defeating Oscar De La Hoya and Ricky Hatton in 2007.\n\nAnd he admits he fought his last victory, which took his record to 49-0, against Andre Berto in September 2015 would be his last.\n\nHowever, after being lured back again by the huge purse on offer to meet UFC star McGregor, he is adamant this will be the final chapter.\n\nMayweather said: \"I thought Andre Berto was going to be the last weigh-in, the last training camp.\n\n\"Honestly speaking, I thought that was going to be my last everything.\n\n\"But you never know what can happen. Now we're here for this big event.\n\n\"This is my last one, ladies and gentlemen. I gave my word to (advisor) Al Haymon, I gave my word to my children, and one thing I don't want to do is break that.\n\n\"I gave Haymon my word, I gave my children my word. I'm going to stick to my word. This will be my last fight.\n\n\"My real estate portfolio is truly amazing; that's a huge part of my life. My children are going to college - that's going to take up a lot of my time, because education is extremely important in my home.\n\n\"I've got businesses started so both my children and children's children can take over from there.\"\n\nMayweather goes into the clash with Irishman McGregor as the heavy favourite.\n\nBut although his confidence of defeating the MMA man is high, he admits he is no longer at the peak of his powers.\n\nMayweather said: \"I don't think I'm the same Floyd Mayweather I was 21 years ago (when I made my debut) - of course not.\n\n\"I'm not the same Floyd Mayweather as 10 years ago, not even five or two years ago.\n\n\"But I still said that I still have a high IQ in that ring, and experience-wise, (this fight) leans towards me. {"timeCrawl": "06:26:00", "uri": "710712848", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:26:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "The Indian Express", "uri": "indianexpress.com", "id": "1155"}, "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/floyd-mayweather-and-conor-mcgregor-will-fight-in-smaller-gloves-4800531/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "By: AP | Las Vegas | Published:August 17, 2017 11:24 am Mayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves. (Source: AP) Yogi Adityanath: If I cannot stop namaz on road, I have no right to stop Janmashtami at thanaAmit Shah resigns as MLA, says Congress will be reduced to half in next pollsToilet Ek Prem Katha box office collection day 6: Akshay Kumar film eyes Rs 100 crore\n\nFloyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor got their wish to fight in smaller gloves, but not before being chastised by a Nevada boxing official for using the issue to hype their fight later this month.\n\nNevada boxing regulators on Wednesday gave the two fighters an exemption to a rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for fights at 154 pounds, approving 8-ounce gloves for the Aug. 26 bout. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMcGregor said the gloves will only speed up the end of the fight, which he earlier predicted wouldn't last four rounds.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is also more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.\n\nThe glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favor of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. McGregor has never boxed before, but quickly agreed to Mayweather's challenge on social media to fight in smaller gloves.\n\nUFC chief Dana White echoed McGregor in saying the smaller gloves will make a difference in the fight.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nCommissioners said they struggled with making an exception to regulations in place since 2006, but decided to approve the waiver because of the unusual nature of the event.\n\n\"The fight is not normal,\" said commissioner Sandra Morgan.\n\nJohn Hornewer, an attorney for Mayweather, said the unbeaten boxer would likely not be at the 154-pound limit at the fight weigh-in anyway.\n\n\"He'll be 150 pounds. That's his best weight and there's no reason to put on extra weight,\" Hornewer said.\n\nA McGregor representative said his fighter has been about 160 pounds in training camp and would likely enter the ring somewhere around that weight after making the 154-pound limit the day before.\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App", "id": "9623727", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "06:04:00", "uri": "710705537", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:04:00Z", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "source": {"title": "Fiji One", "uri": "fijione.tv", "id": "13294"}, "url": "http://fijione.tv/smaller-gloves-for-mayweather-and-mcgregor/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor got their wish to fight in smaller gloves today.\n\nNevada boxing regulators gave the two fighters today an exemption to a rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for fights at 154 pounds, approving 8-ounce gloves for next Sunday's bout.\n\nRepresentatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds.\n\nBut Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMcGregor said the gloves will only speed up the end of the fight, which he earlier predicted wouldn't {"timeCrawl": "09:21:00", "uri": "711355460", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:21:00Z", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "source": {"title": "Weekly Standard", "uri": "weeklystandard.com", "id": "9952"}, "url": "http://www.weeklystandard.com/why-does-floyd-mayweather-think-conor-mcgregor-is-dangerous/article/2009332", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "UFC lightweight champion Conor McGregor during a media workout on August 11, 2017 in Las Vegas, Nevada. Getty Images\n\nFloyd Mayweather says he's in for the fight of his life with Irish mixed martial arts champion Conor McGregor in their much-anticipated Las Vegas bout on August 26. \"He's a lot younger,\" Mayweather told ESPN last week. \"When you look at myself and Conor McGregor on paper, he's taller, has a longer reach, he's a bigger man from top to bottom. He's a lot younger, so youth is on his side,\" Mayweather said of the 29-year-old McGregor. \"And I've been off a couple of years. And I'm in my 40s. So, if you look at everything on paper, it leans toward Conor McGregor.\"\n\nWow. Mayweather's assessment sounded so much like the talking points coming out McGregor's camp the only thing missing was an Irish brogue. Is it possible that the 49-0 Mayweather, the best pound-for-pound boxer in the world before he retired two years ago, thinks McGregor has the upper hand? Nope. Floyd's just pumping money into the market.\n\nMayweather is a great boxer, and one of sport's all-time best businessmen. In 2015 he was Forbes magazine's highest-paid athlete. His net worth is estimated at around $400 million, and his career earnings are likely to soar past $1 billion with the McGregor fight. Where most boxers, even champions, are dependent on their business handlers for their living, Mayweather wisely took control of the means of production and in 2007 exercised a clause freeing him from his contract with Top Rank and started promoting his own fights. In 2013, he jumped from HBO to Showtime for a six-fight deal that guaranteed him at least $30 million per fight, including the massive pay-per-view payout (more than $200 million) from his May 2015 fight with Manny Pacquiao. Mayweather is keen to preserve the integrity of his nickname, \"Money,\" by making sure there's enough interest in the McGregor fight to bring in the pay-per-view dollars.\n\nThe thing you have to understand about Mayweather is that he never leaves money on the table. For instance, lots of viewers who tuned in for his September 2013 fight with Canelo Alvarez couldn't figure out why Justin Bieber was part of Mayweather's pre-fight entourage. \"About 90 minutes prior to the fight, Bieber made a clumsy entrance into Mayweather's dressing room, barging in with hand-slaps and bro-hugs,\" writes ESPN's Tim Keown. \"Mayweather nodded in Bieber's direction but otherwise ignored him. Thirty minutes later, though, came the crystallizing moment: Mayweather wordlessly called Bieber over, put his arm around him and said, 'Take a photo and send it out to your followers.' For a moment, Bieber looked a part of Money's posse. . . . And assuming even an infinitesimal portion of those 48,735,521 Beliebers persuaded their parents to buy the fight, they juiced the fight's record payday of nearly $150 million in pay-per-views. Suddenly, the pairing that makes no sense at all made all the sense in the world.\"\n\nFast forward to today and Mayweather is worried that fans might be losing interest in the McGregor fight because the Irishman's camp looks like a mess.\n\nTwo weeks ago, retired welterweight Paulie Malignaggi headed out to Las Vegas to spar with McGregor, and left abruptly after McGregor's team leaked pictures and videos of a sparring session which suggested that the MMA fighter got the better of the former two-time world champion. In one disputed scene, Malignaggi hits the canvas -- by knockdown, says McGregor's camp, including president of the United Fighting Championship Dana White. Malignaggi says he was pushed, and urged Team McGregor release film of the entire session, which will show, says the Brooklyn fighter, that he beat McGregor all 12 rounds.\n\nAfter leaving the UFC champion's camp, Malignaggi said that McGregor \"whimpers like a girl\" when hit by body shots. \"This guy is one of the biggest dirtbags I've ever met in my life -- bar none,\" said Malignaggi, whose profession is not short on big dirtbags.\n\n\"I was amazed at what a dirtbag this person is. I don't care if we never speak again. My life is fine if I never see Conor McGregor again,\" he said. (And Malignaggi had even harsher words for White.)\n\nMcGregor's camp showed it's a little short on class by releasing pictures making someone else look bad to make their fighter look good. By contrast, Mayweather's training partners say that Floyd has nothing but respect for the guys who come to his camp to help him prepare, fighters who know they're going to get outclassed by Mayweather every time they step into the ring.\n\nIf the footage was indeed altered by McGregor's people it won't have been the first time. Last summer, South African boxer Chris Van Heerden got mad when edits made it look like McGregor owned him, so he released a fuller account of the action that showed otherwise. The fact is, it's not a good sign that McGregor is making noise about thumping sparring partners. If he did manhandle a retired and out of shape Malignaggi, as he claims, then it's hardly worth the distraction. If he didn't, if he's revising reality to make himself look like a better boxer, it suggests that both the fighter and his camp realize he's overmatched and are trying to camouflage his lack of boxing skills. Film editors aren't much help in a boxer's corner -- unless McGregor's also doubles as a cut-man. Because that fellow is likely to see a lot of blood August 26.\n\nMcGregor's open workout for the press last week hardly convinced fight fans he's ready for Mayweather (here's Mayweather's open workout). The Irishman is a tough guy who knows what it takes to be a champion, expert commentator Teddy Atlas remarked on ESPN -- \"he knows what to do when the wolf is at the door,\" Mike Tyson's former assistant trainer uttered lyrically -- but his boxing skills, continued Atlas, are amateur at best. Sure he's quick, said Atlas, but nothing like Mayweather. (Here's a clip of Floyd working the mitts with his uncle Roger Mayweather -- note not just the speed, but the timing and reflexes as well.) The two things you're taught when you first walk into a boxing gym, MMA champion Chael Sonnen told the ESPN audience, are to keep your hands up and your chin down. McGregor, said Sonnen, does neither. Those are two obvious chinks in the armor that would make him vulnerable to any boxer, amateur or professional.\n\nThen there's something else I noticed during McGregor's workout. He's a southpaw -- which allegedly gives Mayweather trouble, but not so much trouble that he's ever lost to one -- but he switches sometimes to an orthodox stance. This isn't that unusual, and really terrific pros that have power in both hands and are exceptionally agile, like Terence Crawford, the 29-year-old undefeated champion out of Omaha, Nebraska, can use it to their advantage. Switching angles like that, and popping with both hands hard can really baffle opponents -- but you need to know what you're doing, which comes from long practice in the gym learning the footwork and the distance from your opponent required to switch sides, or else you get tangled up, which increases your chances of getting hit hard. Then you have to practice the move sparring, and finally try it out in a real fight. But McGregor has very few of these hours under his belt. If he tries it with Mayweather -- not exactly the appropriate venue for experimental labwork -- my bet is that the second or third time he's stepping over he'll walk into a big right hand. And Mayweather has much more power than he's typically given credit for.\n\nIt might come as a surprise to casual observers that in almost all of the betting so far something like 85 percent of the money -- and 95 percent of the betting tickets -- has come down on McGregor. That's because it makes no sense to bet on Mayweather, the huge favorite. Here's how the line has changed since November, months before the fight was announced in June. Mayweather opened at -2250, with the minus sign designating the favorite, and McGregor at +950. That means, to win $100 on Mayweather, you have to bet $2250. If you're taking McGregor, a $100 bet will net you $950. Immediately after the fight was announced, it was -800 Mayweather and +500 McGregor, and as of August 12 it's -500 Mayweather and +350 McGregor.\n\nBut the improved price on Mayweather -- still an insanely huge favorite -- doesn't reflect McGregor's improved chances, it only reflects the oddsmakers' response to the amount of money out on McGregor. Presumably Mayweather's Br'er Rabbit routine suggesting that McGregor looks great on paper is meant not only to generate PPV interest but also to further drive the odds down. (An $880,000 ticket on Mayweather this week, the largest bet so far on the fight, would earn $160,000 -- the kind of safe bet typical of hedge fund managers, not professional gamblers.) Mayweather is a famously degenerate gambler who bets on everything, including, it's assumed, himself. McGregor says he's betting a million euros on himself, and encourages friends to help themselves to an easy payday.\n\nAlmost no one's buying it. Ring announcer David Diamante says McGregor is the worst opponent Mayweather has ever faced. \"I don't see any scenario in a boxing match where McGregor's going to win,\" Diamante said. \"You don't want the guy getting hurt, number one. Number two, from a boxing standpoint, many people have tried to crack the Mayweather code . . . I believe that McGregor, if he wants any chance, needs to get on him really early and try and rough him up.\"\n\nLots of fight fans believe that's exactly what will happen: McGregor will press hard and may even surprise Mayweather the first round or two -- then Floyd will figure him out, adjust, and dominate. Others say that's not good enough. Chael Sonnen says that Mayweather needs to make quick work of McGregor or it will be a stain on boxing. If a guy who's never fought a professional boxing match can stand toe-to-toe with an undefeated champion for even two rounds, says Sonnen, it's a disaster for boxing.\n\nHe's got a point -- if a ski-jumping champion, for instance, challenged a slalom racer who dominated the sport and beat him in his own discipline, it wouldn't reflect well on slalom racing. Or, if an NFL place-kicker who hadn't played soccer since 8th grade led the Premier League in scoring, etc.\n\nTeddy Atlas believes that boxing can't win. If Mayweather beats McGregor, he was supposed to, and if he doesn't, well, forget about it. David Diamante sees one upside, if Mayweather wins, \"Hopefully people will say this guy, McGregor's at the top of Mixed Martial Arts and this boxing guy dispatched of him so easily, wow maybe there's something to this boxing thing and maybe they'll try to get into it more and take a look.\"\n\nThe catch, which Mayweather is surely aware of, is that the fight's priced on Showtime for $100. If he dispatches of McGregor too easily, lots of fans will feel ripped off. If the fight lasts the full 12 rounds and there's not enough action, fans will say it was the same as the much-hyped Pacquiao fight and will feel ripped off. McGregor guarantees he'll stop Mayweather in the fourth round. Floyd concurs with part of that assessment -- it won't go the distance, he says, but not in McGregor's favor.", "id": "9860588", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Why Does Floyd Me and McGregor should give the fans a blockbuster.\"\n\nThe \"Fight of the Century\" between Mayweather and Pacquiao was almost six years in the making. It still holds a number of financial records in boxing, generating over $400 million from 4.6 million pay-per-views and an additional $72.2 million from ticket sales. And yet, despite those figures, the fight failed to come close to expectations. I'm ready to put him away in the first 10 seconds.\"\n\nIt's smart for McGregor to look to get the fight over with while Mayweather isn't fully warmed up for the fight. However, coming events cast their shadows before.\n\nMayweather said in the past that he would make it exciting for the fans, but he's failed to deliver. The only thing the boxing can predict about Mayweather is more of his past behavior. He'll promise an exciting fight, but then play it safe in a safety first type of affair on the night of the fight. With Mayweather, you have to go by his actions rather than on what he says. It's better for McGregor to try and get Mayweather out before he starts moving around the ring.\n\n\"I'm very happy with how the promotion has gone,\" said McGregor.\n\nMcGregor could be making $100 million for the fight if it brings in the 4.6 million that Mayweather believes it'll bring in on Showtime PPV. There's a lot of attention on the fight, but it seems more like the MMA fans are the ones that are more interested in the match rather than the boxing fans, who seem to know better. Malignaggi has never had this kind of a spotlight put on him for this long of a time in his own career in boxing. Malignaggi's fights were more as him as the B-side opponent for Adrien Broner, Ricky Hatton, Danny Garcia and Miguel Cotto. Now he's getting a lot of attention by the casual boxing and MMA fans by him name dropping McGregor's name night and day on Twitter and in interviews with different news outlets.\n\nIt'll be interesting to see how much longer Malignaggi's 15 minutes of fame will last. He keeps talking nonstop about McGregor months from now, it's going to look wretched and more than a little pathetic. But if it helps Malignaggi's career, I guess you can't blame him for name dropping the way he's been doing. As far as Malignaggi getting a fight against McGregor, it's not going to happen. McGregor told Malignaggi to get in line if he wants to fight him. Believe me; there's very, very long line of fighters waiting for a chance to fight McGregor. Unfortunately, McGregor will probably never fight Malignaggi. It just won't happen. Malignaggi brings nothing to the table in terms of ability and popularity. {"timeCrawl": "23:37:00", "uri": "711165935", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:03:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "cleveland.com", "uri": "cleveland.com", "id": "2166"}, "url": "http://www.cleveland.com/sports/index.ssf/2017/08/who_benefits_more_from_8-ounce.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Gallery: Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather Jr. news conference\n\nThe Nevada State Athletic Commission approved the use of eight-ounce gloves for the highly anticipated fight between Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather in late August. The lighter gloves will help McGregor out, lessening the six-ounce adjustment from UFC gloves down to four. This may allow him to keep the hand speed that has won him so much success in MMA. But the lighter gloves also give Mayweather, who has some of the fastest hands in boxing, even more speed. Who does it help more?\n\nFloyd Mayweather just did something he rarely does -- he let an opponent control fight conditions. After weeks of goading, Mayweather agreed to allow the use of eight-ounce gloves in his fight with Conor McGregor. It isn't hard to imagine McGregor doing cartwheels when the news broke.\n\nLighter gloves mean McGregor's adjustment to boxing will be easier. The difference of two-ounces will allow his hands to move quicker, and show off the knockout power he had in the UFC. McGregor had an outside shot of competing with Mayweather in 10-ounce gloves. Now, he has a chance of winning.\n\nI am impressed, Floyd. You followed through on your offer to wear 8-oz gloves. But you let McGregor goad you into a dangerous disadvantage. -- Skip Bayless (@RealSkipBayless)\n\nAugust 16, 2017\n\nPeople act like Conor McGregor is going to use eight-ounce gloves, and Floyd Mayweather is going to stick with the 10-ounce mitts. No, Mayweather will get to use the eight-ounce gloves too, and now he is going to be even better than he was before.\n\nMayweather is a defensive boxer who uses his hands a lot to set up his opponents. Now imagine that defense with lighter gloves where he can really show off the elite hand speed that got him to 49-0. Mayweather has less weight to carry, so he can easily pepper McGregor with more shots than before. The best boxer in the world just got better.\n\nChill, McGregor fans: 8-Ounce gloves give him no extra advantage\n\nFunny McGregor thinks 8oz benefits him more...Floyd spent most of his career in 8oz. -- Chad Maddox (@chadmaddox11)\n\nAugust 17, 2017", "id": "9795554", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Who benefits more from 8-ounce gloves: Floyd Mayweather or Conor McGregor?", {"timeCrawl": "22:19:00", "uri": "710571354", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T22:19:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "Federal News Radio", "uri": "federalnewsradio.com", "id": "9518"}, "url": "https://federalnewsradio.com/sports-news/2017/08/mayweather-and-mcgregor-will-fight-in-smaller-gloves/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "LAS VEGAS (AP) -- Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor got their wish to fight in smaller gloves, but not before being chastised by a Nevada boxing official for using the issue to hype their fight later this month.\n\nNevada boxing regulators on Wednesday gave the two fighters an exemption to a rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for fights at 154 pounds, approving 8-ounce gloves for the Aug. 26 bout. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\nSponsored Content: How is your agency managing and maximizing its data? Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMcGregor said the gloves will only speed up the end of the fight, which he earlier predicted wouldn't last four rounds.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is also more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nGSA gives per diem travel rates another bump for 2018\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.\n\nThe glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favor of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. McGregor has never boxed before, but quickly agreed to Mayweather's challenge on social media to fight in smaller gloves.\n\nUFC chief Dana White echoed McGregor in saying the smaller gloves will make a difference in the fight.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nCommissioners said they struggled with making an exception to regulations in place since 2006, but decided to approve the waiver because of the unusual nature of the event.\n\n\"The fight is not normal,\" said commissioner Sandra Morgan.\n\nJohn Hornewer, an attorney for Mayweather, said the unbeaten boxer would likely not be at the 154-pound limit at the fight weigh-in anyway.\n\n\"He'll be 150 pounds. That's his best weight and there's no reason to put on extra weight,\" Hornewer said.\n\nA McGregor representative said his fighter has been about 160 pounds in training camp and would likely enter {"timeCrawl": "18:00:00", "uri": "710471407", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:00:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "Los Angeles Times", "uri": "latimes.com", "id": "971"}, "url": "http://www.latimes.com/sports/boxing/la-sp-mayweather-mcgregor-gloves-20170816-story.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor were unanimously granted \"a one-fight exception\" Wednesday by the Nevada Athletic Commission to fight using lighter eight-ounce gloves for their unique Aug. 26 boxing match in Las Vegas.\n\nAdditionally, veteran referee Robert Byrd was named the third man in the ring for the bout that matches the 49-0, former five-division boxing champion Mayweather against the UFC champion McGregor in his pro boxing debut.\n\nThe commission, on the recommendation of Executive Director Bob Bennett, also selected Burt A. Clements, Dave Moretti and Italy's Guido Cavalerri as judges.\n\nByrd previously worked Mayweather's one-sided and uneventful victory by unanimous decision over Robert Guerrero in May 2013.\n\nThis bout is expected to be a far greater challenge for the referee, considering that McGregor is making his pro boxing debut and the possibility that he could turn to the rougher fighting techniques employed in the UFC.\n\nThe decision on the gloves came after both fighters lobbied for a change from a 2006 rule that stipulates fights above 154 pounds should be contested with 10-ounce gloves. McGregor has said he will likely weigh as much as 170 pounds on fight night.\n\nOne commissioner, Skip Avansino, said despite the fact that \"that's the rule,\" there has been no scientific study on why 10-ounce gloves are needed for 154-pound fights, and said an adjustment can be \"reconsidered by this unprecedented fight.\"\n\nChairman Anthony Marnell III said, \"My biggest concern is I don't like the Nevada commission being used as a pawn in a social-media battle,\" that occurred between the two fighters. \"If you cut a deal for a fight with this much money, you should get it right.\"\n\nMarnell said he wanted commissioners to screen the gloves as part of launching a new study to consider if 8-ounce gloves can be used in future 154-pound fights.\n\nMcGregor wanted gloves nearer in size to the 4-ounce gloves he uses as a UFC fighter, believing his punching power will be more effective.\n\n\"I'm strong enough to give him two rounds,\" in eight-ounce gloves, McGregor said. \"The only reason [Mayweather] can get to the second round is because in this game the referee gives him time to recover [with an eight-count] without getting his head pounded into the canvas. That's the only reason he might make it to the second round.\"\n\nIn the fight contract, Mayweather requested \"no Mexican-made gloves, no gloves made of horsehair, only 10-ounce. I didn't even know the difference,\" McGregor said. \"I didn't really care. Now he's pushing for the 8-ounce. Great.\"\n\nMayweather has said the 8-ounce gloves will give him more punching power, as well, which could enhance his chances of posting his first knockout victory since 2011.\n\nMcGregor's representative said at Wednesday's meeting that he believes \"there is no inherent risk to the health and safety\" of the Irishman by fighting Mayweather in 8-ounce gloves. The representative said McGregor has trained exclusively in 10-ounce gloves.\n\nThe McGregor representative said the gloves will not be Mexican-made or contain any horsehair.\n\nNevada Commissioner J. Daniel Carpenter, said, \"We want great entertainment, but we want the health and safety of the fighters, first and foremost,\" noting a recent MMA fighter's death, but also expressing trust in a referee like Byrd to stop punishment that could endanger either fighter.\n\n\"This is a hybrid fight. An individual who's never stepped foot in a boxing ring against one of the best ... boxers ever.\"\n\nIf the fight goes the distance, the outcome will be decided by the judges, including Moretti, who's judged 10 Mayweather fights since 2005.\n\nMoretti has been favorable to Mayweather in two of his most compelling bouts, awarding him a wide 118-110 (10 rounds to two) advantage in the record-setting 2015 bout against Manny Pacquiao, and giving Mayweather eight rounds in what was seen as a more narrow decision over Marcos Maidana in their first 2014 fight.\n\nCavalerri was added to the mix to fulfill a request by McGregor's camp to have one international judge as part of the panel.\n\nClements has worked four Mayweather fights, including the victories over Pacquiao and Juan
