{"timeCrawl": "22:16:00", "uri": "710569848", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T22:16:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "News.com.au", "uri": "news.com.au", "id": "308"}, "url": "http://www.news.com.au/sport/boxing/shocking-rule-switch-completely-changes-mcgregormayweather/news-story/cdaeb1396707c88b1c2211824fd46f7a", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "THE Nevada State Athletic Commission handed Conor McGregor a major early victory over Floyd Mayweather on Wednesday, when it overturned its own rules regarding glove size.\n\nAccording to Nevada's boxing rules, all fighters over 147 pounds must wear 10-ounce gloves. Mayweather and McGregor's Showtime pay-per-view superfight on August 27 will be contested at the junior middleweight limit of 154 pounds.\n\nHowever, both fighters submitted official requests to the commission stating their desire to compete in smaller, eight-ounce gloves.\n\nIn a shocking decision, the NSAC agreed to the fighters' request and granted an exception to its own rule.\n\nCommission chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nGlove size has been a constant issue in the long war of words between Mayweather and McGregor.\n\nFrom the beginning, McGregor has been pushing for the smallest gloves possible because smaller gloves have less padding and thus accentuate his significant punching power. McGregor has made a name for himself in the UFC with showstopping knockouts delivered with the sport's traditional four-ounce gloves.\n\nMayweather, goaded by McGregor's taunts, publicly stated that he'd be fine with the smaller gloves, safe in the knowledge that Nevada's own rules would assuredly protect him.\n\nMcGregor, who is also known for making wild predictions about his fights that often end up being true, said Friday that the eight-ounce gloves would be the end of Mayweather.\n\n\"If we're eight ounces, I'm struggling to give him two rounds,\" McGregor said at his media workout. \"That's the God's honest truth. The only reason I maybe give him two rounds is because in this game, the referee stops me from pounding his head into the canvas. And he has 10 seconds to recover. That's the only reason he might get to the second round.\"\n\nThe NSAC decision came despite strong advice to the contrary from the Association of Ringside Physicians.\n\n\"Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of this bout, we would strongly caution against allowing current regulation to be overruled,\" wrote the Association's Chairman, Dr Raymond M. Monsell, in a letter to the NSAC.\n\n\"To do so would also set a precedent for future bouts.\"\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director. Commissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000. The glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favour of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nMore Boxing Aldo says Mayweather-McGregor is 'a joke' Lomachenko stops Marriaga after 7 rounds Mayweather, McGregor still trying to hype their fight Wladimir Klitschko retires from boxing Ireland's Taylor shines in NY boxing debut\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nhttps://t.co/3uljFZ24hC pic.twitter.com/TOF5iBPoHu -- Floyd Mayweather (@FloydMayweather)\n\nAugust 1, 2017\n\nI am very pleased with the Nevada State Athletic Commission's handling of my next bout today. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nadvertisement | advertise on newsday\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.\n\nThe glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favor of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. McGregor has never boxed before, but quickly agreed to Mayweather's challenge on social media to fight in smaller gloves.\n\nCommissioners said they struggled with making an exception to regulations in place since 2006, but decided to approve the waiver because of the unusual nature of the event.\n\n\"The fight is not normal,\" said Commissioner Sandra Morgan.\n\nadvertisement | advertise on newsday\n\nJohn Hornewer, an attorney for Mayweather, said the unbeaten boxer would likely not be at the 154-pound limit at the fight weigh-in anyway.\n\n\"He'll be 150 pounds. That's his best weight and there's no reason to put on extra weight,\" Hornewer said.\n\nA McGregor representative said his fighter has been about 160 pounds in training camp and would likely enter Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMcGregor said the gloves will only speed up the end of the fight, which he earlier predicted wouldn't last four rounds.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is also more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.", "id": "9672556", "details": {}, "date": On Wednesday, the Nevada State Athletic Commission voted unanimously to allow the pair to wear 8-ounce gloves during their bout on August 26.\n\nThe NSAC's rules mandate that fights taking place above 147 pounds must be contested with 10-ounce gloves. Mayweather and McGregor will fight at 154 pounds, but both signed waivers and wanted to use the smaller gloves. McGregor has used 4-ounce gloves -- which are little more than knuckle protectors -- during his career in mixed martial arts, while Mayweather has spent most of his career using 8-ounce gloves.\n\nThe NSAC says this will be a one-time exception to its glove size rule, and that it was allowed because this is a \"unique\" matchup. Also on Wednesday, veteran official Robert Byrd was appointed to oversee the bout in the ring.\n\nThe smaller gloves certainly favor McGregor in the fight, but it doesn't change the fact that he'll be an overwhelming underdog. Mayweather is used to 8-ounce gloves, and while the UFC lightweight champion's power could be a factor, it almost certainly won't change the expected outcome.\n\nMayweather might be 40, but he's been boxing virtually his entire life. McGregor is in his first professional bout. Glove size won't have anything to do with the anticipated outcome of a wide decision for Mayweather. \"Money May\" is too good at avoiding punishment and is so smart in the ring he should run circles In one corner: Conor \"the Notorious\" McGregor (who has never fought in a professional boxing match.) In the other: Floyd 'Money' Mayweather (an undefeated world champion.)\n\nIf you're planning to watch the match live - and a huge chunk of humanity is - here are all the ways to tune in from Australia. We've also included pub venues, fighter statistics, Mayweather Vs McGregor start time, betting odds and everything else a fighting fan needs to know.\n\nFor the past few months, the Mayweather Vs McGregor travelling circus has been pulling no punches. (You can watch the expletive-filled international press conferences here, here, here and here.) In just a few day's time, the relentless trash talking will be traded for physical blows in a boxing ring. Here's everything you need to know.\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor: When does the fight start?\n\nThe Mayweather Vs McGregor boxing match is set to go down on Sunday, August 27 (AEST). Coverage will start at 11am (AEST) with the main card loosely scheduled for 5pm (AEST).\n\nHere's the full breakdown for each Australian time zone:\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor start time in NSW: 11am (AEST)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor start time in Victoria: 11am (AEST)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor start time in Tasmania: 11am (AEST)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor start time in ACT: 11am (AEST)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor start time in Queensland: 11am (AEST)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor start time in Northern Territory: 10:30am (AEST)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor start time in Western Australia: 9am (AEST)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor start time in South Australia : 10:30am (AEST)\n\nImage: Getty Images Where is the Mayweather Vs McGregor fight being held?\n\nThe Mayweather Vs McGregor fight will be held at the T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas.\n\nHow to watch Mayweather Vs McGregor on TV\n\nThe Mayweather Vs McGregor fight will be shown on the Pay-Per-View channel Main Event. Paying customers will be able to follow the action on their large screen TVs via the Foxtel app or Fetch TV.\n\nHow to watch Mayweather Vs McGregor online\n\nIf you don't have access to a smart TV, the aforementioned Pay-Per-View can be accessed on a computer or tablet. You can also purchase the fight on UFC TV.\n\nHow to watch Mayweather Vs McGregor at the pub\n\nYou can rest assured that sports venues around the country will be showing the Mayweather Vs McGregor fight on the biggest commercial TV screens that money can buy. Here are all the bars and pubs that will be showing the Mayweather Vs McGregor live. (Type in your postcode to find the closest venue to your location.).\n\nHow to watch Mayweather Vs McGregor for free Image: YouTube\n\nThe only legal way to watch the Mayweather Vs McGregor fight without paying is to head down the pub (see above.) With that said, Australia is a nation of ex-convicts... and convicts find a way.\n\nOne option is to trawl the internet on August 27 for a cheeky broadcast on Facebook Live. This is precisely what happened during the Anthony Mundine Vs Danny Green pay-per-view boxing match back in February. Darren Sharpe, a mechanic from Brisbane, ended up getting 112,000 viewers piggybacking off his Facebook Live stream of the fight.\n\nNeedless to say, Foxtel was not amused, but it did not pursue the matter legally. Sharpe was eventually forced to issue a public apology for breaking copyright law, but that was all he copped. Meanwhile, none of the people who watched the stream were punished in any way.\n\nJust be aware that this is a pretty risky way to watch the fight - if a Facebook Live stream does appear, it will be of the handheld, bootleg variety and the broadcast could be shut down at any second. Also, it's clearly an extremely dodgy thing to partake in. (For those interested, you can read up on the legalities of Facebook Live event streaming here.)\n\nHow to watch Mayweather Vs McGregor live\n\nPlanning a trip to Vegas? Getting into the venue won't be cheap: ringside tickets will set you back over $11,000 (!), while the cheapest available seats are still in the region of fifteen-hundred bucks. You can purchase tickets on ticketmaster. (We advise not gambling at the casino too - nobody has that much money.)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor: Fight rules\n\nThe Mayweather Vs McGregor fight will follow boxing rules, comprising 12 three-minute rounds at 154 pounds with eight-ounce gloves. (Yes, this means McGregor will not be able to use any of his MMA moves, with the exception of legal punching blows.)\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor: Fighter stats Mayweather McGregor Record Boxing: 49-0 (28 KOs) MMA: 21-3 (18 KOs) Height 5'8\" (172cm) 5'9\" (175cm) Weight 154lb (70kg) 154lb (70kg) Style Orthodox Southpaw Reach 72 inches 74 inches Age 40 29\n\nAs you can see, Mayweather has a significant height, reach and age disadvantage, but his 49-0 boxing record speaks for itself. McGregor is very much the underdog here. With that said, self-belief goes a long way and McGregor has this in spades.\n\nMayweather Vs McGregor: Betting Odds\n\nWe do not encourage gambling at Lifehacker, but if you're going to risk your hard-earned cash on the outcome of a sports match, it might as well be for something outlandish and crazy like this.\n\nHere are the current odds from TAB for various outcomes:\n\nMayweather: $1.25\n\nMayweather by KO/TKO: $1.80\n\nMayweather by decision/tech decision: $4\n\nMcGregor: $4\n\nMcGregor by KO/TKO: $5.50\n\nMcGregor Wins in Round 1: $17\n\nMcGregor by decision/tech decision: $21\n\nMayweather Wins in Round 1: $21\n\nMcGregor Wins in Round 2: $21\n\nDraw: $26\n\nThe safe money is on a head-to-head Mayweather victory, but at odds of $1.18 it's hardly worth the risk. If you're going to take a punt, go full madman and back a McGregor KO in round 2. This will give you a nice 20x return on whatever you put down. (For what it's worth, the Irishman has vowed to knock Mayweather out inside two rounds and most experts agree that if McGregor is going to win he will need to do it early.) A more conservative bet is a Mayweather victory by decision, which is currently sitting at $4.\n\nWhat is a Mayweather Vs McGregor?\n\nIf you're scratching your head about all this but want to be part of the conversation, we got you: here is your Complete Bluffer's Guide to Mayweather Vs McGregor.\n\nThe Bluffer's Guide To Mayweather Vs McGregor\n\nIt's the 'fight of the century'. Boxing versus MMA, Old versus New, Floyd 'Money' Mayweather versus Conor 'The Notorious' McGregor. Nothing about it makes any goddamn sense whatsoever but it's happening and there's nothing anyone can do about that.\n\nThe only thing we can do now is prepare.\n\nWelcome to the bluffer's guide to {"timeCrawl": "22:46:00", "uri": "711149607", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:46:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "Boxing News 24", "uri": "boxingnews24.com", "id": "1065"}, "url": "http://www.boxingnews24.com/2017/08/mcgregor-says-hell-break-40-year-old-mayweather/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "By Jeff Aranow: Conor McGregor says he's trained hard to adapt from the 5 round UFC fights to be ready to fight Floyd Mayweather Jr. for 12 hard rounds on August 26. McGregor says Mayweather is hoping that he'll wear down in the fight as the rounds go by, but he doesn't plan on letting that happen.\n\nMcGregor, 29, it's going to be the 40-year-old Mayweather (49-0, 26 KOs) who winds up fatiguing from the fast pace that he's going to be setting for him in their fight on Showtime pay-per-view at the T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas, Nevada.\n\nThe 8oz gloves that both fighters will be wearing for the fight will favor McGregor, who is the naturally bigger puncher than Mayweather. The odds for the Mayweather-McGregor fight have narrowed due to the smaller gloves size. Mayweather is favored by the odds -550, and McGregor +425.\n\nMcGregor isn't just talking about wanting to fight at a fast pace against Mayweather. He actually means what he says. If you saw the sparring video of McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi, you'll have noticed that McGregor was all over Malignaggi, not giving him a second to rest and hitting him constantly with punches. There was virtually no letup from McGregor, even when he was on the inside. McGregor continued to hammer away at Malignaggi with short punches o the head that made him not want to hold. Mayweather is 40, and he's no used to fighting without holding and resting with his back against the ropes. If Mayweather fights like that against McGregor, it could be his undoing.\n\n\"Floyd is praying for me to fatigue in there, but I will not fatigue. I will continue to press forward, and I will break him. At 40 years of age, he will not sustain my pace,\" said McGregor to 'Conan on TBS.' \"We've made slight adjustments in my cardio preparation. It's actually been very enjoyable to go from five, five-minute rounds, which is what we're used to, which is 25 minutes, to 12, three-minute rounds of boxing, which is 36 minutes. Slight adjustments, but we are more than ready. I done 12 rounds last night, I've done multiple 12-round fights in the gym in the lead-up to this. We are more than ready,\" said McGregor.\n\nA fast pace fight favors McGregor, because he's the younger guy and the more active of the two. McGregor's fights in the octagon are generally always fast pace affairs with a lot of fireworks. In contrast, Mayweather has fought a lot of slow paced fights in recent years against Manny Pacquiao, Andre Berto and Marcos Maidana. Even Mayweather's fight against Saul Canelo Alvarez in 2013 was a slow-paced fight. Canelo stayed on the outside and boxed Mayweather, and let him fight at a slow pace. It was a mistake on Canelo's part and it cost him the fight.\n\nMayweather will likely have trained to stay in the center of the ring for as long as possible against McGregor. I don't know if Mayweather can do that. Mayweather has ALWAYS fought with his back against the ropes during his career. He likes to cover up, rest his legs, and throw short punches with his back leaning against the ropes. Most of the guys that Mayweather has fought during his career have been head hunters that ignored his body. This has made Mayweather's job much easier, since he hasn't had to worry about getting hit to the body. McGregor has a chance of wearing Mayweather down with body shots if he gets him against the ropes. McGregor also could hurt Mayweather with head shots if he gets him against the ropes. McGregor will take the power off his shots and slap with them.\n\n\"I'm going down in the history books, Conan. I've dominated the UFC and I will dominate boxing also. It has never been done. That's where I'm going, down in the history books,\" said McGregor. \"There will be no dancing in there, Conan. I'm going to go straightforward and put him away inside four rounds.\"\n\nIt would be a sad ending to Mayweather's long boxing career if he were to get knocked out by the heavy underdog McGregor. Mayweather has won so many fights during his career and looked invincible most of the time. That's what happens with old fighters that stay out of the ring for 2 or more years. When they come back, they frequently get beaten badly by younger fighters. We saw that with Sugar Ray Leonard in his loss to Hector Camacho. Leonard tried to come back 1 time too many, and it cost him dearly in losing by a knockout.\n\nMayweather hasn't looked that great in the ring for some time. He took a lot of rounds off against Andre Berto, Manny Pacquiao and Marcos Maidana. Mayweather doesn't seem capable of fighting hard for a full 12 rounds. He fights hard for 6 rounds, and wins because his opponents are so bad. McGregor will have a chance of outworking and maybe even stopping Mayweather if he doesn't want to fight hard in this fight.\n\n\"He's saying he's going to come towards me, I'm saying I'm going to come towards him. We'll find out pretty early who's telling the truth. We'll see who takes a back step first. I will go forward for him and put him away,\" said McGregor.\n\nI don't think you can take what Mayweather says anymore at face value. He says he's going to do something, but then he does the opposite. Mayweather is saying he's going to take the fight to McGreor and knock him out. Are we to believe Mayweather this time or should we ignore what he's saying and judge him by his actions in his past fights? In regular life, we judge the people we associate with on their behavior and actions that they've shown in the past.\n\nIf a person doesn't keep their word, then we stop listening to what they say when they're talking about doing something that is important. Mayweather is saying he's going to go directly at McGregor and knock him out so that he can repay the boxing fans for his lackluster fight against Pacquiao in 2015. Are we to believe Mayweather or judge him by what he's done in the past?\n\nMcGregor will come at Mayweather on August 26 and look to knock him out. We know this because that's how McGregor always fights in the octagon. He goes after his opponents, and he doesn't play it safe no matter which it is he's fighting. McGregor feels really confident in fighting with the 8oz gloves. He thinks he'll hurt Mayweather and knock him out quickly with those gloves. It would be the biggest upset boxing has seen in quite some time. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"My biggest concern about this consideration or this request that is being made is that I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media bout between these two,\" Marnell said. \"That part of this request, it pisses me off, I'll be really, really honest with you. I respect the fact that you missed this and you admitted that in your testimony, that you may have missed this subject when you guys put this bout agreement together.\n\n\"But this body is not the subject of two fighters who want to go back and forth like these two have at each other to create social media stir and another controversy for attention to sell tickets [and] to sell DirecTV. However, in saying that, I would like to put that aside and I would just caution going forward that this body, this forum, not be used for that again.\"\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nTags: Floyd Mayweather Jr. {"timeCrawl": "05:52:00", "uri": "711271129", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:14:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "Bleacher Report", "uri": "bleacherreport.com", "id": "3199"}, "url": "http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2728148-floyd-mayweather-announces-he-will-retire-after-fight-vs-conor-mcgregor", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3371701", "body": "Floyd Mayweather Jr. announced Thursday he will retire following his Aug. 26 fight against Conor McGregor.\n\nMoney made things official with a post on the Mayweather Promotions Twitter account:\n\n\"I mean, just honestly speaking, I thought that [2015 fight against Andre Berto] was going to be my last everything,\" he said on a conference call Thursday, per MMA Mania's Ryan Harkness. \"But you just never know what can happen. We're here with this big event. It's just, this is my last one, ladies and gentlemen. I gave my word to Al Haymon. I gave my word to my children. And one thing I don't want to do is break that.\n\n\"I gave Haymon my word. I gave my children my word. I'm going to stick to my word. This will be my last fight.\"\n\nMayweather has been adamant for weeks that he intends to call it quits after the McGregor megafight at T-Mobile Arena -- and that he means it this time.\n\nSpeaking to ESPN's Stephen A. Smith Aug. 8, Mayweather called his first retirement a \"vacation\" and that he didn't have time to come back again. {"timeCrawl": "21:03:00", "uri": "710542980", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:03:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "mmafrenzy.com", "uri": "mmafrenzy.com", "id": "3090"}, "url": "http://mmafrenzy.com/147341/floyd-mayweather-conor-mcgregor-lighter-gloves-approved-commission/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Following a back-and-forth on social media, and the submission of formal requests to the commission, Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather have been approved to wear 8-ounce gloves...\n\nThe fighters formally petitioned the Nevada State Athletic Commission to allow them to wear 8-ounce gloves, instead of 10-ounce ones, when they throw hands on August 26th. Mayweather had begun a public campaign on social media to wear smaller gloves, in response to claims the decorated boxer had insisted on wearing larger gloves.\n\nAll this played into the narrative that McGregor would crush Mayweather in a MMA fight, which of course, would involve 4-ounce gloves (and a myriad of fighting techniques...).\n\nWell, today the NSAC ruled on the request and they have signed off on 8-ounce gloves, despite significant cautions from the Association of Ringside Physicians (quote via MMA Fighting):\n\n\"Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of the bout, we should strongly caution against allowing current regulations to be over-ruled,\" ARP board chairman Dr. Raymond Monsell wrote in the aforementioned state. \"To do so would also set a precedent for future bouts.\"\n\nThe commission, apparently, wasn't all smiles about the situation either. According to a follow up report from MMA Fighting, Chairman Anthony Marnel had this to say:\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media bout,\" Marnell said. \"Between these two, that part of this request pisses me off.\n\n\"This body is not the subject of two fighters ... to create social media stir and other controversy to sell tickets and to sell DirecTV.\"\n\nBut, at the end of the day, 8-ounce gloves are going to be worn, although apparently, the NSAC says this is a \"one-time\" thing. {"timeCrawl": "10:09:00", "uri": "711375461", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:29:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "The Independent", "uri": "independent.co.uk", "id": "3441"}, "url": "http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/boxing/mayweather-mcgregor/floyd-mayweather-putting-it-all-on-the-line-vs-conor-mcgregor-live-fight-latest-news-what-time-when-a7899611.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "Mayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career\n\nWith his superfight against Conor McGregor a little over a week away, Floyd Mayweather struck a reflective tone on Thursday as he discussed the risk of coming out of retirement for a massive payday.\n\nMayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career, while McGregor, who is making his professional boxing debut, is 21-3 in mixed martial arts.\n\n\"When a fighter has lost before, if he loses again they say 'oh, it's nothing, he's lost before,'\" Mayweather told a conference call. \"But when a fighter has been dominating for 20-some years and never lost, everything is on the line.\n\nRead more Explained: Why Mayweather wanted to fight McGregor in 8oz gloves\n\n\"My legacy. My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\"\n\nThe fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite scepticism about how competitive it will be.\n\nMayweather, a master defensive technician and tactician, is heavily favoured to win the Aug. 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said that, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\nMayweather vs McGregor: From trash-talk to super-fight 18 show all Mayweather vs McGregor: From trash-talk to super-fight 1/18 From trash-talk to super-fight\n\nJust how did an appearance on late-night show Conan and a rumbling Twitter feud turn into the biggest fight the sport of boxing has ever known.\n\nHere, we tell the story of how the trash-talk turned into a super-fight.\n\nGetty Images\n\n2/18 McGregor appears on Conan\n\n\"If you're asking would I like to fight Floyd Mayweather, I mean, who would not like to dance around the ring for $180m?\" McGregor replied to a playful question from late-night host Conan O'Brien, in July 2015, on whether he would ever be tempted into switching sports.\n\n\"I would certainly box him if the opportunity arose,\" he smiled.\n\n\"Most certainly.\"\n\n3/18 Mayweather's observation\n\nMayweather then rekindled the speculation, that December. In an interview with FightHype on the worldwide adulation McGregor had received for knocking out Aldo in just 13 seconds, the American complained that he would never receive such acclaim from the public because of the colour of his skin.\n\n\"They say he talk a lot of trash and people praise him for it, but when I did it, they say I'm cocky and arrogant,\" Mayweather observed.\n\n\"So biased! Like I said before, all I'm saying is this, I ain't racist at all, but I'm telling you racism still exists.\"\n\nGetty Images\n\n4/18 \"I am an Irishman\"\n\nThis time, it didn't take the other man the best part of half a year to respond. \"Don't ever bring my race into my success again,\" McGregor commented in a long Instagram post, the very next day.\n\n\"I am an Irishman. My people have been oppressed our entire existence. And still very much are. I understand the feeling of prejudice. It is a feeling that is deep in my blood ... If you want we can organise a fight no problem. I will give you a fair 80/20 split purse in my favour seen as your last fight bombed at every area of revenue.\"\n\nA feud was born.\n\n5/18 McGregor 'retires'\n\nAs interest in a fight with Mayweather began to increase, McGregor threatened to retire not just from MMA, but from sport altogether.\n\nUFC president Dana White announced that the promotion has pulled McGregor from the main event at UFC 200, because of his refusal to participate in mandatory media duties. McGregor's response?\n\n\"I have decided to retire young. Thanks for the cheese. Catch ya's later.\"\n\n6/18 Scoop\n\nThings came to a boil in May 2016. British tabloid The Sun reported that the two men were \"on the verge\" of agreeing to a deal, with an unnamed source telling the paper that \"Floyd is obsessed with making Conor eat his words\".\n\nThe story attracted so much attention that Dana White, the president of the UFC, felt compelled to finally address the situation. He laughed off suggestions the super-fight would ever take place, instead pointing out that McGregor was contracted to the UFC, and would thus be in breach of contract should he attempt to organise a fight himself away from the confines of the Octagon.\n\nAFP/Getty Images\n\n7/18 Battle of the photoshopped posters\n\nWhite's comments appeared to spur both men into action. First McGregor tweeted a mocked up fight poster with the caption 'MMA vs Boxing'...\n\nGetty Images\n\n8/18 Battle of the photoshopped posters\n\n... before Mayweather responded with an effort of his own (it wasn't quite as good).\n\nMayweather insisted began to insist a fight was \"possible\". Then he told a journalist that he was a retired man and would only countenance returning to professional sport in order to fight McGregor. And then he pressed the nuclear button, offering the Irishman just $50m to fight him in what people were already describing as a billion-dollar bout.\n\nGetty Images\n\n9/18 Leonard Ellerbe puts his foot down\n\nHold the hype. Just as things were beginning to heat up, Mayweather's promotions head, Leonard Ellerbe, poured cold water on the prospective fight, insisting it was \"a calculated effort by McGregor to gain more fans\".\n\nGetty Images\n\n10/18 Mac gets personal\n\nIn an attempt to get discussions back on track, McGregor got personal.\n\n\"Call me CJ Watson!\" he tweet, with a cartoon of him standing triumphantly above a knocked out Mayweather.\n\nThe caption was explosive: Mayweather was sent to prison in 2010 for the assault of his then-girlfriend. He was reportedly angry about text messages she had received from NBA star CJ Watson.\n\nGetty Images\n\n11/18 White rebuffed\n\nAt this point in the saga the president of the UFC, Dana White, reenters the fray.\n\nHaving previously insisted that the fight was a non-starter, he suddenly proposed a deal: $25m for each fighter, with the complicated PPV splits to be patiently worked out at a later date.\n\n\"He's a f***ing comedian,\" Mayweather replied.\n\nGetty Images\n\n12/18 In February 2017...\n\n... McGregor arrived in Las Vegas, to much excitement.\n\nMayweather tweeted the following.\n\nGetty Images\n\n13/18 Conor's response\n\nMcGregor's response to Mayweather's short statement was brutal and to the point.\n\n\"I am in Las Vegas. Floyd has retired on my arrival,\" he observed.\n\n14/18 Conan's back!\n\nWithout Conan O'Brien the biggest fight in the history of boxing would still be a daydream.\n\nIn March he invited Dana White onto his show, who said the following.\n\n\"I do think it's gonna happen. I think it's going to be a tough deal because obviously [there are] a lot of egos involved in this deal and a lot of people, so that always makes it tougher.\n\n\"On the flip side, there's so much money involved. I just don't see how it doesn't happen.\"\n\n15/18 Conor and Conlan\n\nMcGrgor was in New York to support Belfast boxer Michael Conlan in his professional debut against Tim Ibarra in March.\n\nBut the spotlight quickly sought him out. He reminded everyone that an announcement was imminent by shouting furiously into the face of ESPN boxing reporter Dan Rafael: \"I AM BOXING!\"\n\nGetty Images\n\n16/18 Fine downgraded\n\nOn March 22, an outstanding fine McGregor had with the Nevada Athletic Commission was downgraded, paving the way for the Irishman to obtain his necessary boxing license.\n\nGetty Images\n\n17/18 McGregor confirms\n\nOn Wednesday 14 June, the fight was finally confirmed by both men.\n\n\"THE FIGHT IS ON,\" McGregor posted on Twitter, along with a mocking picture of himself side-by-side with Floyd Mayweather Snr.\n\n18/18 Mayweather confirms\n\n\"It's official!\" replied Mayweather on Instagram, along with a short promotional video confirming the involvement of Showtime.\n\nGetty Images\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather.\n\n\"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\nRead more Mayweather vows to retire after McGregor fight because of his children\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 21 years ago. Of course not,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 10 years ago. I'm, not even the same Floyd Mayweather that I was I was five or two years ago.\n\n\"But I still have a high IQ in that ring. And experience wise, it leans towards me, period, because I have been in the ring at such a high level for so long.\"\n\nMore about: UFC Floyd Mayweather Conor McGregor Mayweather vs McGregor Andre {"timeCrawl": "04:17:00", "uri": "710671167", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:17:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "Daily Republic", "uri": "dailyrepublic.com", "id": "4795"}, "url": "http://www.dailyrepublic.com/sports/mayweather-and-mcgregor-will-fight-in-smaller-gloves/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Nevada boxing regulators on Wednesday gave the two fighters an exemption to a rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for fights at 154 pounds, approving 8-ounce gloves for the Aug. 26 bout. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMcGregor said the gloves will only speed up the end of the fight, which he earlier predicted wouldn't last four rounds.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is also more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.\n\nThe glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favor of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. McGregor has never boxed before, but quickly agreed to Mayweather's challenge on social media to fight in smaller gloves.\n\nUFC chief Dana White echoed McGregor in saying the smaller gloves will make a difference in the fight.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nCommissioners said they struggled with making an exception to regulations in place since 2006, but decided to approve the waiver because of the unusual nature of the event.\n\n\"The fight is not normal,\" said commissioner Sandra Morgan.\n\nJohn Hornewer, an attorney for Mayweather, said the unbeaten boxer would likely not be at the 154-pound limit at the fight weigh-in anyway.\n\n\"He'll be 150 pounds. That's his best weight and there's no reason to put on extra weight,\" Hornewer said.\n\nA McGregor representative said his fighter has been about 160 pounds in training camp and would likely enter the ring somewhere around that weight after making the 154-pound limit the day before.", "id": "9608688", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Mayweather and McGregor will fight in smaller The change could improve McGregor's odds and make him more comfortable in his first attempt in the boxing ring.\n\nThe odds could shift in Conor's favor due to this latest change.\n\nThe Nevada State Athletic Commission has overturned it's own rules regarding the glove size yesterday. The two opponents will now be using 8-ounce gloves in the fight instead of 10-ounce gloves. Accordingly, \"all fighters over 147 pounds must wear 10-ounce gloves.\" The super fight will be at the 154 pound pound limit.\n\nBoth Floyd and Conor submitted their waivers to contest the glove size and it has been accepted. The committee will be granting an exception for this single fight. McGregor has been pushing for a smaller glove size for the fight in the promotions between the two earlier in the summer. The two greatly insulted each other hilariously in the promotions leading up to the match.\n\nFloyd Mayweather was also pushing for lighter gloves to help out his opponent.\n\nHe even posted a picture on his Instagram account to describe it.\n\nMcGregor has gotten his wish, but will now have to back it up by knocking him out sooner with lighter gloves. McGregor is one to talk a lot and he is very confident in his abilities. He even stated that \"8-ounce gloves would be the end of Mayweather.\"\n\nConor McGregor does have a chance in the ring. He has certain advantages over Floyd with respect to age, energy, and power. The recent change gives McGregor more of a chance in the ring against the undefeated boxer. The Irishman is used to fighting in lighter gloves.\n\nThe lighter gloves will help out Conor because he will be able to put his punching power on full display. McGregor has been known for knocking out opponents in light gloves in the UFC. Although, the gloves he uses in those matches are the traditional 4-ounce gloves. The 8-ounce gloves certainly help because it is less padding that in turn makes punches more effective.\n\nAll eyes will be set on the match debut on August 26. {"timeCrawl": "07:53:00", "uri": "711319062", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:53:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "ArkansasOnline", "uri": "arkansasonline.com", "id": "766"}, "url": "http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2017/aug/18/lighter-glove-only-adds-to-the-hype-201/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "LAS VEGAS -- It's only two ounces of foam, four if you count both hands.\n\nStill, it was enough to make Conor McGregor quite happy. Floyd Mayweather Jr., too, because it likely means more sales for what could be the richest fight ever.\n\nNevada boxing regulators went out of their way to give a gift to both fighters, approving an exemption to the rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for the 154-pound fight so that both fighters can wear 8-ounce gloves.\n\nAnd just like that, the fight appeared more competitive -- at least to some.\n\nOddsmaker William Hill immediately boosted the odds of McGregor winning, though they are still low. And UFC chief Dana White didn't wait long to trumpet the smaller gloves as a game changer.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nThe underlying school of thought is that McGregor will have a better chance of knocking Mayweather out with smaller gloves, though Mayweather has fought all but three of his professional fights with 8-ounce gloves and has never been knocked out.\n\nBut the fight needed another selling point, and Nevada State Athletic Commission members were happy to give it one.\n\n\"It's an unusual contest for us as a commission,\" said Chairman Anthony Marnell.\n\nUnusual, well, yes. The fight matches a UFC champion in his first professional boxing match against a fighter who was throwing punches before he could walk and who won all 49 of his pro fights before announcing his retirement.\n\nCommission members -- who regulate both UFC and boxing in Nevada -- are charged with protecting the health and safety of fighters. Their No. 1 job is to make sure as few fighters as possible get their brains scrambled in the ring or in the octagon.\n\nAnd in this case, they failed.\n\nIt was bad enough that the commission approved a novice boxer to go 12 rounds with one of the best fighters of all time, no questions asked. But commission members lost any remaining credibility when they agreed to change the glove size for no real reason other than the two fighters asked for it.\n\nIn doing so, they ignored a letter from the Association of Ringside Physicians asking them not to.\n\n\"We hated to see them break their own rules and regulations kind of arbitrarily,\" said Dr. Larry Lovelace, who heads the association and is also on the Oklahoma State Boxing Commission. \"It seemed almost capricious to change from 10 ounces, which is the prescribed weight of gloves for that weight class.\"\n\nTo be fair, there is no solid medical evidence about the effects of getting hit with smaller gloves. But there was enough anecdotal evidence that the Nevada commission in 2006 adopted regulations that call for 8-ounce gloves in fights 147 pounds or smaller, and 10-ounce gloves for anything above that.\n\nIn the 11 years since, that has been the rule. Until Wednesday, there had been no exceptions.\n\nBut tickets and pay-per-view had to be sold. More people had to be convinced that McGregor actually has a chance in the ring with Mayweather.\n\nAnd convinced they were, at least the ones betting at William Hill. Oddsmakers there lowered the lopsided odds favoring Mayweather from minus-600 to minus-550 because they will be fighting with smaller gloves.\n\nMcGregor himself predicted the smaller gloves would make the night even easier for him.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMost in boxing scoff at that, saying the size of the gloves would only matter if they were both forced to fight in 4-ounce UFC gloves that are open past the knuckle. There's also a school of thought that smaller gloves will actually help Mayweather by making his hands even quicker.\n\nBut by allowing smaller gloves, commission members did more than just try and lure a few more people to Las Vegas next week. They made a decision that, in theory at least, could affect the outcome of the fight.", "id": "9846139", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Lighter glove only adds to the hype", "image": that he is committed to throwing caution against the wind when he takes on McGregor in less than two weeks' time.\n\n\"He [McGregor] is going to land shots because in this fight I'm going straight ahead,\" Mayweather said. \"Normally it's more taking my time, being very cautious, but this time I'm going straight ahead because the fans deserve it.\"\n\nMayweather also insisted that there would be no repeat of his underwhelming fight with Pacquiao, which proved such a disappointment that critics relabelled the fight 'Better Never Than Late' rather than 'The Fight of the Century'.\n\nMayweather is determined to bow out with a bang (Getty)\n\n\"No, it's going to be bigger than the Pacquiao fight,\" Mayweather added.\n\n\"I feel like I owe the fans seeing as me and Pacquiao didn't give the fans a blockbuster. {"timeCrawl": "04:20:00", "uri": "710672090", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T23:42:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "ESPN.com", "uri": "espn.co.uk", "id": "4451"}, "url": "http://www.espn.co.uk/boxing/story/_/id/20360455", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "LAS VEGAS -- The Nevada State Athletic Commission approved Floyd Mayweather's and Conor McGregor's requests for smaller boxing gloves on Wednesday -- just 10 days before their highly anticipated fight on Aug. 26.\n\nThe NSAC voted unanimously in favor of a one-time exception that will allow both fighters to wear 8-ounce gloves in their 154-pound bout. Per NSAC regulations, any boxing match contested above 147 pounds mandates 10-ounce gloves.\n\nChairman Anthony Marnell, who strongly chastised both camps for using the NSAC as a \"pawn\" for social media controversy to sell tickets, noted that while he holds a strong respect for the commission's rules, it must always \"adopt it to current times.\"\n\nThe issue came to light on Aug. 1, when Mayweather (49-0, 26 KOs) wrote on Facebook: \"Let's fight in 8 oz gloves.\"\n\nMayweather, 40, has fought the majority of his career in 8-ounce gloves. McGregor (21-3), the UFC's lightweight champion, is used to 4-ounce gloves in mixed martial arts.\n\nBoth fighters submitted a waiver to the NSAC this month, requesting the smaller glove size.\n\n\"I'm very happy with how the Nevada State Athletic Commission handled it,\" McGregor said Wednesday after the decision. \"They handled it fairly, and they listened to both requests.\"\n\nAccording to longtime commission member Skip Avansino, the rule for 10-ounce gloves went into effect in 2006, based on the recommendations of an advisory committee. At that time, the committee stated its recommendations were not based on scientific fact and encouraged the NSAC to fund a study on the matter.\n\nThat study is now planned for after Aug. 26. The rule will remain in place for now, with this one-time exception for the Mayweather-McGregor bout.\n\nOne point articulated by Marnell, which every other commission member echoed, is that referee selection is the most important factor in fighter health and safety, particularly in a \"unique\" matchup such as this. During Wednesday's meeting, the NSAC appointed veteran official Robert Byrd to oversee the bout.\n\n\"The No. 1 line of defense is the referee,\" Marnell said. \"It always will be.\"\n\nAnother concern regarding glove selection was the distribution of padding. The bout contracts mandate that foam gloves be used -- and not Mexican horsehair gloves, which are known more as \"puncher's gloves.\"\n\nIn addition to regular inspections, Marnell and other commission members will inspect each fighter's gloves before the fight. Alternative gloves not selected for the bout will be donated to the NSAC's study.\n\nA nonprofit organization dedicated to the health and safety of boxers and mixed martial artists indicated before the ruling that lighter gloves was a bad idea.\n\n\"This is a bout that has already been set [at] a specified weight class,\" Dr. Raymond M. Monsell, chairman of the Association of Ringside Physicians, wrote to the commission on Tuesday. \"Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of this bout, we would strongly caution against allowing current regulations to be overruled. To do so would also set a precedent for future bouts.\"\n\nSpeaking to ESPN late last week, McGregor, 29, predicted he would need only two rounds to dispatch Mayweather if the commission approved 8-ounce gloves.\n\n\"If we are in 8-ounce gloves, he will be floored multiple times in the first round,\" McGregor said. \"I believe first-round KO in 8-ounce gloves. The fact I can't follow through in MMA and pound the head into the canvas and there's a 10-count in boxing, maybe I'll give him second round. But 8-ounce gloves, he will be done in two.\"\n\nShortly after the NSAC's ruling, longtime Mayweather adviser Leonard Ellerbe told ESPN that Mayweather wanted McGregor's confidence to be high going into the fight.\n\n\"Floyd wanted Conor to be as comfortable as possible, so there wouldn't be any excuses,\" Ellerbe said. \"Conor has vowed he'll knock out Floyd in four rounds. He recently corrected that and said if the commission approved 8-ounce gloves, he doesn't give Floyd two rounds.\n\n\"I have no reason to believe he's not feeling very confident, and I want him to continue to have that confident attitude.\"", "id": "9609060", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Mayweather, McGregor to wear 8-ounce gloves", "image": {"timeCrawl": "00:20:00", "uri": "711177861", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:20:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "The Globe and Mail", "uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "id": "1409"}, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/more-sports/smaller-gloves-mean-bigger-hype-for-mcgregor-and-mayweather-fight/article36022988/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "It's only two ounces of foam, four if you count both hands.\n\nStill, it was enough to make Conor McGregor quite happy. Floyd Mayweather Jr., too, because it likely means more sales for what could be the richest fight ever.\n\nNevada boxing regulators went out of their way to give a gift to both fighters, approving an exemption to the rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for the 154-pound fight so that both fighters can wear 8-ounce gloves.\n\nAnd just like that, the fight appeared more competitive - at least to some.\n\nOdds maker William Hill immediately boosted the chances of McGregor winning the bout, though they are still low. And UFC chief executive Dana White didn't wait long to trumpet the smaller gloves as a game changer.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed, but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nThe underlying school of thought is that McGregor will have a better chance of knocking Mayweather out with smaller gloves, though Mayweather has fought all but three of his professional fights with 8-ounce gloves and has never been knocked out.\n\nBut the fight needed another selling point, and Nevada State Athletic Commission members were happy to give it one.\n\n\"It's an unusual contest for us as a commission,\" chairman Anthony Marnell said.\n\nUnusual, well, yes. The fight matches a UFC champion in his first professional boxing match against a fighter who was throwing punches before he could walk and who won all 49 of his professional fights before announcing his retirement.\n\nCommission members - who regulate both UFC and boxing in Nevada - are charged with protecting the health and safety of fighters. Their No. 1 job is to make sure as few fighters as possible get their brains scrambled in the ring or in the octagon.\n\nAnd in this case, they failed.\n\nIt was bad enough that the commission approved a novice boxer to go 12 rounds with one of the best fighters of all time, no questions asked. But commission members lost any remaining credibility when they agreed to change the glove size for no real reason other than that the two fighters asked for it.\n\nIn doing so, they ignored a letter from the Association of Ringside Physicians asking them not to.\n\n\"We hated to see them break their own rules and regulations kind of arbitrarily,\" said Dr. Larry Lovelace, who heads the association and is also on the Oklahoma State Boxing Commission. \"It seemed almost capricious to change from 10 ounces, which is the prescribed weight of gloves for that weight class.\"\n\nTo be fair, there is no solid medical evidence about the effects of getting hit with smaller gloves. But there was enough anecdotal evidence that the Nevada commission in 2006 adopted regulations that call for 8-ounce gloves in fights 147 pounds or smaller, and 10-ounce gloves for anything above that.\n\nIn the 11 years since, that has been the rule. Until Wednesday, there had been no exceptions.\n\nBut tickets and pay-per-view had to be sold. More people had to be convinced that McGregor actually has a chance in the ring with Mayweather.\n\nAnd convinced they were, at least the ones betting at William Hill. Odds makers there lowered the lopsided odds favouring Mayweather from minus-600 to minus-550 because they will be fighting with smaller gloves.\n\nMcGregor himself predicted the smaller gloves would make the night even easier for him.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMost in boxing scoff at that, saying the size of the gloves would only matter if they were both forced to fight in 4-ounce UFC gloves that are open past the knuckle. There's also a school of thought that smaller gloves will actually help Mayweather by making his hands even quicker.\n\nBut by allowing smaller gloves, commission members did more than just try and lure a few more people to Las Vegas next week. They made a decision that, in theory at least, could affect the outcome of the fight.", "id": "9799302", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Smaller gloves mean bigger hype for McGregor and {"timeCrawl": "02:16:00", "uri": "710638370", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T16:22:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "FanSided", "uri": "fansided.com", "id": "8632"}, "url": "https://fansided.com/2017/08/16/floyd-mayweather-conor-mcgregor-8-ounce-gloves-fight/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "On Wednesday, the Nevada State Athletic Commission approved the use of 8 oz. gloves in the upcoming fight between Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor.\n\nFloyd Mayweather made the inquiry to fight Conor McGregor on Aug. 26 with 8-ounce gloves instead of 10, to which the UFC lightweight champion responded favorably. On Wednesday, the Nevada State Athletic Commission made the inquiry a reality.\n\nDuring the NSAC monthly meeting, the use of 8-ounce gloves was unanimously approved by the panel. Since the fight is taking place at 154 pounds, Nevada rules state that any fight that takes place with boxers weighing over 147 pounds, the participants must wear 10-ounce gloves. However, the commission approved the ruling for educational and safety purposes.\n\nThe commission stated that they want to have the gloves following the fight to study the impact of the weight of gloves for safety. Because there was no prior study that had occurred the current weight class to glove weight safety ratio, the panel approved the change less than two weeks away from the biggest fight in combat sports history.\n\nIt was also revealed during the meeting that veteran Robert Byrd will serve as the bout's referee. Byrd has been the third man in important boxing bouts such as Sergey Kovalev and Andre Ward, as well Canelo Alvarez's fight against Miguel Cotto. The judges for the fight will be Burt Clements, Dave Moretti and Guido Cavalerri.\n\nMcGregor had already predicted a knockout over Mayweather inside of four rounds with the gloves being at 10 ounces, but during his open workout in Las Vegas on Friday, the UFC lightweight champion predicted a much shorter night if the NSAC went forward with Wednesday's approval to 8-ounce gloves.\n\n\"If we're 8 ounces, I'm struggling to give him two rounds, and that's the God's honest truth,\"McGregor said. \"The only reason I maybe give him two rounds is because in this game the referee stops me from pounding his head into the canvas, and he has 10 seconds to recover. That's the only reason why he might get to the second round.\"\n\nWe will find out on Aug. 26 whether or not the gloves will make a difference, as the 49-0 Mayweather will welcome McGregor to the professional boxing world at the T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas, Nevada.", "id": "9597556", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor will officially fight in {"timeCrawl": "05:51:00", "uri": "711271014", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:14:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "La Crosse Tribune", "uri": "lacrossetribune.com", "id": "2796"}, "url": "http://lacrossetribune.com/sports/local/tim-dahlberg-what-s-in-a-smaller-glove-more-hype/article_878ccfa3-beb8-5eac-a0b2-197f254814d0.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "LAS VEGAS -- It's only two ounces of foam, four if you count both hands.\n\nStill, it was enough to make Conor McGregor quite happy. Floyd Mayweather Jr., too, because it likely means more sales for what could be the richest fight ever.\n\nNevada boxing regulators went out of their way to give a gift to both fighters, approving an exemption to the rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for the 154-pound fight so that both fighters can wear 8-ounce gloves.\n\nAnd just like that, the fight appeared more competitive -- at least to some.\n\nOddsmaker William Hill immediately boosted the odds of McGregor winning, though they are still low. And UFC chief Dana White didn't wait long to trumpet the smaller gloves as a game changer.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nThe underlying school of thought is that McGregor will have a better chance of knocking Mayweather out with smaller gloves, though Mayweather has fought all but three of his professional fights with 8-ounce gloves and has never been knocked out.\n\nBut the fight needed another selling point, and Nevada State Athletic Commission members were happy to give it one.\n\n\"It's an unusual contest for us as a commission,\" said chairman Anthony Marnell.\n\nUnusual, well, yes. The fight matches a UFC champion in his first professional boxing match against a fighter who was throwing punches before he could walk and who won all 49 of his pro fights before announcing his retirement.\n\nCommission members -- who regulate both UFC and boxing in Nevada -- are charged with protecting the health and safety of fighters. Their No. 1 job is to make sure as few fighters as possible get their brains scrambled in the ring or in the octagon.\n\nAnd in this case, they failed.\n\nIt was bad enough that the commission approved a novice boxer to go 12 rounds with one of the best fighters of all time, no questions asked. But commission members lost any remaining credibility when they agreed to change the glove size for no real reason other than the two fighters asked for it.\n\nIn doing so, they ignored a letter from the Association of Ringside Physicians asking them not to.\n\n\"We hated to see them break their own rules and regulations kind of arbitrarily,\" said Dr. Larry Lovelace, who heads the association and is also on the Oklahoma State Boxing Commission. \"It seemed almost capricious to change from 10 ounces, which is the prescribed weight of gloves for that weight class.\"\n\nTo be fair, there is no solid medical evidence about the effects of getting hit with smaller gloves. But there was enough anecdotal evidence that the Nevada commission in 2006 adopted regulations that call for 8-ounce gloves in fights 147 pounds or smaller, and 10-ounce gloves for anything above that.\n\nIn the 11 years since, that has been the rule. Until Wednesday, there had been no exceptions.\n\nBut tickets and pay-per-view had to be sold. More people had to be convinced that McGregor actually has a chance in the ring with Mayweather.\n\nAnd convinced they were, at least the ones betting at William Hill. Oddsmakers there lowered the lopsided odds favoring Mayweather from minus-600 to minus-550 because they will be fighting with smaller gloves.\n\nMcGregor himself predicted the smaller gloves would make the night even easier for him.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMost in boxing scoff at that, saying the size of the gloves would only matter if they were both forced to fight in 4-ounce UFC gloves that are open past the knuckle. There's also a school of thought that smaller gloves will actually help Mayweather by making his hands even quicker.\n\nBut by allowing smaller gloves, commission members did more than just try and lure a few more people to Las Vegas next week. They made a decision that, in theory at least, could affect the outcome of the fight.\n\nAnd by any standard, that's a bad decision to make.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time. ... I don't know what changed but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\" Dana White, UFC fight chief", "id": "9830324", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Tim Dahlberg: What's in a smaller glove? {"timeCrawl": "03:02:00", "uri": "711221145", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:02:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "ABS-CBN SPORTS", "uri": "sports.abs-cbn.com", "id": "6300"}, "url": "http://sports.abs-cbn.com/boxing/news/2017/08/18/column-what-s-smaller-glove-more-hype-fight-29881", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Conor McGregor, right, taunts Floyd Mayweather Jr. while pausing for photos during a news conference at Staples Center on Tuesday, July 11, 2017, in Los Angeles. The two will fight in a boxing match in Las Vegas on Aug. 26. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong)\n\nBy Tim Dahlberg, AP Sports Columnist\n\nLAS VEGAS (AP) -- It's only 2 ounces of foam, 4 if you count both hands.\n\nStill, it was enough to make Conor McGregor quite happy. Floyd Mayweather Jr., too, because it likely means more sales for what could be the richest fight ever.\n\nNevada boxing regulators went out of their way to give a gift to both fighters, approving an exemption to the rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for the 154-pound fight so that both fighters can wear 8-ounce gloves.\n\nAnd just like that, the fight appeared more competitive -- at least to some.\n\nOddsmaker William Hill immediately boosted the odds of McGregor winning, though they are still low. And UFC chief Dana White didn't wait long to trumpet the smaller gloves as a game changer.\n\n\"It affects the fight big time,\" White said. \"When we were in our original negotiations it was something they would not even talk about. I don't know what changed, but I'm glad it did. It makes it so much more fun.\"\n\nThe underlying school of thought is that McGregor will have a better chance of knocking Mayweather out with smaller gloves, though Mayweather has fought all but three of his professional fights with 8-ounce gloves and has never been knocked out in any of them.\n\nBut the fight needed another selling point, and Nevada State Athletic Commission members were happy to give it one.\n\n\"It's an unusual contest for us as a commission,\" chairman Anthony Marnell said.\n\nUnusual, well, yes. The fight matches an Irish UFC champion in his first professional boxing match against a fighter who was throwing punches before he could walk and who won all 49 of his pro fights before announcing his retirement.\n\nBut commission members -- who regulate both UFC and boxing in Nevada -- are charged with protecting the health and safety of fighters. Their No. 1 job is to make sure as few fighters as possible get their brains scrambled in the ring or in the octagon.\n\nAnd in this case, they failed.\n\nIt was bad enough that the commission approved a novice boxer to go 12 rounds with one of the best fighters of all time, no questions asked. But commission members lost any remaining credibility when they agreed to change the glove size for no real reason other than the two fighters asked for it to help build the hype.\n\nIn doing so, they ignored a letter from the Association of Ringside Physicians asking them not to.\n\n\"We hated to see them break their own rules and regulations kind of arbitrarily,\" said Dr. Larry Lovelace, who heads the association and is also on the Oklahoma State Boxing Commission. \"It seemed almost capricious to change from 10 ounces, which is the prescribed weight of gloves for that weight class.\"\n\nTo be fair, there is no solid medical evidence about the effects of getting hit with smaller gloves. But there was enough anecdotal evidence that the Nevada commission in 2006 adopted regulations that call for 8-ounce gloves in fights 147 pounds or smaller, and 10-ounce gloves for anything above that.\n\nIn the 11 years since, that has been the rule. Until Wednesday, there had been no exceptions.\n\nBut tickets and pay-per-view had to be sold. More people had to be convinced that McGregor actually has a chance in the ring with Mayweather.\n\nAnd convinced they were, at least the ones betting at William Hill. Oddsmakers there lowered the lopsided odds favoring Mayweather from minus-600 to minus-550 because they will be fighting with smaller gloves.\n\nMcGregor himself predicted the smaller gloves would make the night even easier for him.\n\n\"I believe now that gloves are eight ounces, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said. \"I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMost in boxing scoff at that, saying the size of the gloves would matter only if they were both forced to fight in 4-ounce UFC gloves that are open past the knuckle. There's also a school of thought that smaller gloves will actually help Mayweather by making his hands even quicker.\n\nBut by allowing smaller gloves, commission members did more than just try to lure a few more people to Las Vegas next week. They made a decision that, in theory at least, could affect the outcome of the fight.\n\nTim Dahlberg is a national sports columnist for The Associated Press. The NSAC's own rules state that their 154-pound bout requires 10-ounce gloves. Such rules were enacted for the safety of the fighters involved.\n\nThe Association of Ringside Physicians considered the matter of such importance that it sent a letter to the NSAC asking it not {"timeCrawl": "18:46:00", "uri": "710489094", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:46:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "The Seattle Times", "uri": "seattletimes.com", "id": "844"}, "url": "http://www.seattletimes.com/sports/mayweather-and-mcgregor-will-fight-in-smaller-gloves/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "LAS VEGAS (AP) -- Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor got their wish to fight in smaller gloves, but not before being chastised by a Nevada boxing official for using the issue to hype their fight later this month.\n\nNevada boxing regulators on Wednesday gave the two fighters an exemption to a rule requiring 10-ounce gloves for fights at 154 pounds, approving 8-ounce gloves for the Aug. 26 bout. Representatives of both fighters appeared before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to request the waiver.\n\nCommissioners also approved veteran referee Robert Byrd as the third man in the ring for the fight.\n\nCommission Chairman Anthony Marnell said he was comfortable with the fighters using smaller gloves, but unhappy that they used the issue to sell the fight on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media battle,\" Marnell said.\n\nUnder Nevada regulations, 10-ounce gloves are required in fights above 147 pounds and the bout is set for 154 pounds. But Mayweather has worn 8-ounce gloves most of his career, and McGregor has worn 4-ounce gloves in his UFC fights.\n\nMayweather's promoter, Leonard Ellerbe, said his fighter is more comfortable in smaller gloves and would use them to stop McGregor.\n\n\"The fight is going to end in a knockout, I'm very confident,\" Ellerbe said. \"And it will probably be early.\"\n\nMcGregor will be in a boxing ring for the first time as a pro when he takes on Mayweather, who is coming out of retirement for a fight that will make him tens of millions of dollars. They will fight under boxing rules, which will be enforced by Byrd, a veteran of many championship fights.\n\n\"The referee makes a big difference in this fight, which is the specific reason I chose Robert Byrd,\" said Bob Bennett, the commission's executive director.\n\nCommissioners also approved Burt Clements and Dave Moretti of the United States and Italy's Guido Cavalleri as judges for the bout. McGregor's camp had asked for an international judge among the three.\n\nByrd will be paid $25,000 for the bout, while the judges will make $20,000.\n\nThe glove issue took up much of the commission meeting, though in the end all voted in favor of the smaller gloves. There was also discussion about the padding in the gloves, with both sides agreeing to be bound by Nevada boxing inspectors approving the foam padding.\n\nMayweather has fought 46 of his 49 fights with 8-ounce gloves, including his last six. McGregor has never boxed before, but quickly agreed to Mayweather's challenge on social media to fight in smaller gloves.\n\nCommissioners said they struggled with making an exception to regulations in place since 2006, but decided to approve the waiver because of the unusual nature of the event.\n\n\"The fight is not normal,\" said Commissioner Sandra Morgan.\n\nJohn Hornewer, an attorney for Mayweather, said the unbeaten boxer would likely not be at the 154-pound limit at the fight weigh-in anyway.\n\n\"He'll be 150 pounds. That's his best weight and there's no reason to put on extra weight,\" Hornewer said.\n\nA McGregor representative said his fighter has been about 160 pounds in training camp and would likely enter the ring somewhere around that weight after making the 154-pound limit the day before.", "id": "9544464", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", "title": "Mayweather and McGregor will fight in smaller
