{"timeCrawl": "09:03:00", "uri": "710781978", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "source": {"title": "Capital News", "uri": "capitalfm.co.ke", "id": "333"}, "url": "http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/17/mcgregor-vows-fast-finish-mayweather/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "Shares\n\nUFC lightweight champion Conor McGregor holds a media workout in Las Vegas, ahead of his fight against Floyd Mayweather Jr. on August 26 \u00a9 GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA/AFP/File / Ethan Miller\n\nLOS ANGELES, United States, Aug 17 - Conor McGregor believes he will knock out Floyd Mayweather inside two rounds but is ready for all scenarios when the two fighters clash in their eagerly anticipated superfight next week.\n\nIrish mixed martial arts star McGregor told reporters on a conference call on Wednesday that a controversial switch to lighter gloves could lead to an explosive outcome in the August 26 showdown in Las Vegas.\n\nMcGregor, who is widely seen as a massive underdog against undefeated former welterweight king Mayweather, predicted an early finish to the fight.\n\n\"Particularly with the eight-ounce gloves, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" said McGregor, nevertheless expressing the hope that the fight would last longer.\n\n\"I don't want people saying 'Oh, it was a lucky punch' and all that. Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way.\n\n\"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a grueling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\"\n\nUlimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\n- 'Hits like a truck' -\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves helps him big time. I think it absolutely does.\"\n\nMcGregor and Mayweather will climb into the ring following an international publicity tour last month marked by expletive-laden tirades and trash-talking.\n\nMcGregor, who was criticized for addressing Mayweather as \"boy\" during one event, dismissed suggestions that there was a racially tinged dimension to the duel.\n\n\"For me, it's athlete versus athlete,\" McGregor said. \"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's being portrayed. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. It's a set way and there is no other way. Well, if that was the case we would have never reached across the oceans in search of other lands. We would never have gone into space.\n\n\"You have to have an open mind and you got to realize that there are other ways. Fighting is a complex game. Representatives of both fighters stated their case for the use of lighter gloves at the NAC meeting on Wednesday.\n\nAfter hearing the arguments from both representatives, the commission passed a one-time waiver allowing the use of 8 oz gloves for the bout set at 154 lbs. They concluded that there was no evidence to suggest that the use of smaller gloves brings up health and safety concerns.\n\nAccording to the rules, fighters over 135 lbs should wear ten-ounce gloves, but fighters between the 135-pound to the 147-pound range are able to wear 8 oz gloves upon agreement.\n\nThe commission stipulated that the gloves must have a sufficient amount of padding. To ensure they do, they will be inspected by the chairman and executive chairman on the evening of the fight. The gloves must also be given to the NAC after they're used.\n\nRobert Byrd was appointed to referee the bout and the judges were also selected at the meeting. If you have lost before it's OK, but if you are 49-0, as I am, everything is on the line.\"\n\nMcGregor has lost three of his 24 mixed martial arts contests. This will be his first professional boxing match, one expected to draw five million pay per view buys and shatter all records as the richest fight in history, potentially grossing over 700 million US dollars\n\nBut Mayweather believes the UFC's Irish mixed martial arts star will employ potentially underhand tactics when they face off here in their mega-fight on August 26.\n\nAnd the richest boxer in history reiterated that this really will be his very last fight, after which he intends to tighten up his business interests for his family for \"generations to come\".\n\nMayweather watched clips of McGregor in training against former two weight world champion Paulie Malignaggi. \"I see a lot of rabbit punches behind the head, grappling, wrestling, illegal shots,\" Mayweather said on an international media conference call.\n\n\"Some may call that a KO (over Malignaggi), but it doesn't matter as it is just in the gym. What counts is in the ring. Paulie has retired and he is now commentating and traveling around the world. McGregor is active and hard in training.\"\n\n\"But the ref will be fair on both sides, I want him to be even. Like I have said, I am coming straight ahead.\"\n\n\"I look forward to following the Queensberry rules of boxing. McGregor had referee Joe Cortez in his training camp but I still see him being extremely dirty. But my job is not to referee the fight, I am going to do my job. I am not worried about the outcome, I am more worried about excitement.\"\n\nMayweather had also said in recent television interviews that he may be prepared to fight McGregor in a rematch, perhaps even in a mixed martial arts fight, but was insistent that this will be his last walk to a fight ring.\n\n\"I thought Andre Berto (September 2015) was going to be last weigh-in, last training camp, my last everything,\" Mayweather explained. \"But you just never know what can happen and we are here with this big event. This is my last one, ladies and gentlemen. I gave my word to Al Haymon (his business and boxing adviser), my children, and I don't want to break that. I want to stick to my word. This will be my last fight.\"\n\n\"I now want my children to go to College, and do what I was never able to do,\" explained 40-year-old Mayweather. \"They will be able to turn 100 million in my business into 300 million. This could be the real fight of the night, and I'm looking to capitalise on that.\n\n\"(Mayweather-McGregor is) one of these once-in-a-blue-moon fantasy fights: it's captured the public's imagination.\n\n\"It's massive: the magnitude and scale of this event. It's a great opportunity for us, that this fight is part of this show.\n\n\"Mayweather deserves that pinnacle position in boxing; McGregor that pinnacle position in UFC. Does he deserve the opportunity in boxing? No, but can you blame him for making it happen? No you can't.\n\n\"Fair play for the work they've put in in the gym and outside it as well, and making this a one-off, freak event.\"\n\nCleverly beat J\u00fcrgen Br\u00e4hmer last time out (Getty)\n\nConfirmation of Cleverly's match-up with Jack had been expected soon after that of the main event but only came last week, little over a fortnight before they actually fight.\n\nGroves was similarly kept waiting by Mayweather Promotions in the build-up to his 2015 defeat by Jack, and the Mayweathers have a reputation for pursuing subtle advantages, but Cleverly insists if that was their plan it has had no effect.\n\nJack has moved up weight classes (Getty)\n\n\"It was quite possibly a ploy but it's expected in boxing, in all walks of life,\" said the Welshman, who also has no plans to speak to Groves or DeGale for advice.\n\n\"Everyone's at it, so it's how you handle it. I handle those situations: it's just part and parcel of boxing and the business.\n\nRead more Everything you need to know about Mayweather v McGregor\n\n\"I was very optimistic the fight was going to get made and we'd cross the line and get it done.\n\n\"In preparation, even though it wasn't official, I was always getting ready for August 26, so it made no difference to me. Either way, whether it was a ploy or not, we're trained up 100 per cent, ready to do business, not messing around. We're going to Vegas to turn up, get the gloves on, get in that ring, do the business, and get home.\n\n\"Maybe it would help (to speak to Groves or DeGale), but he is what he is, I know his style, I've seen enough of him.\n\n\"Regardless of any advice, it's down to me, and I'm confident in myself.\"\n\nSky Sports Box Office will show Mayweather v McGregor exclusively live on 26 August. I think that's where he can be most intense but fighting up close is the hardest thing in boxing to learn and I don't think you can do that in a few months.\"\n\nMcGregor, 29, has employed retired Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez in order to adapt to boxing rules for his debut in the sport against undefeated Mayweather, who will come out of retirement for the 26 August bout in Las Vegas.\n\nMayweather, speaking to a teleconference of journalists around the world, said: \"He had Joe Cortez in his camp but I still saw him being extremely dirty. My job is not to worry about the referee but to let the referee do his job.\"\n\nRobert Byrd, himself a Hall of Fame referee, has been chosen to officiate the T-Mobile Arena bout.\n\nMayweather, 40, will surpass Rocky Marciano's perfect record of 49 fights without defeat should he avoid loss against McGregor. The Las Vegas-based fighter retired in 2015 but is adamant this will now be his final contest, stating he has \"given my word\" to his family and advisor Al Haymon.\n\nHe is a heavy favourite with bookmakers to score a 50th win almost 21 years since his professional debut. McGregor, who is widely seen as a massive underdog against undefeated former welterweight king Mayweather, predicted an early finish to the fight.\n\n\"Particularly with the eight-ounce gloves, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" said McGregor, nevertheless expressing the hope that the fight would last longer.\n\n\"I don't want people saying 'Oh, it was a lucky punch' and all that. Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way. \"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a gruelling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\" Ulimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. I want to do anything so that you feel that you have an advantage. I want to make sure you're comfortable coming to the fight world.\"\n\nThe bout will be refereed by veteran Robert Byrd, who has taken charge of a number of world-title bouts, including Andre Ward's first victory over Sergey Kovalev.\n\nMcGregor's camp had objected to high-profile ref Kenny Bayless being considered after the official questioned the validity of the contest but Bob Bennett, executive director of the Nevada State Commission claimed that McGregor's views didn't affect the decision to not consider Bayless.\n\nThe judges will be Burt Clements and Dave Moretti (who both scored Mayweather's 2015 victory over Manny Pacquiao) and Guido Cavalleri, who was ringside for both of Carl Frampton's fights against Leo Santa Cruz.\n\nNAC chairman Marnell said the commission being used as a \"pawn\" for social media promotion \"pisses me off.\" -- MMAFighting.com (@MMAFighting)\n\nAugust 16, 2017\n\nThe Dubliner is accustomed to wearing four-ounce gloves in the UFC so it should be easier for him to adapt to 8oz rather than 10.\n\nHowever, his former MMA sparring partner Richard Kiely feels that it won't make a big difference to the overall contest.\n\n\"If there was an impact you would feel it a bit more with the heavier gloves but in terms of the protection it offers Floyd - which is a big advantage - it won't really be a factor, Kiely told RT\u00c9 Sport.\n\n\"Floyd still has the advantage because he is wearing pillows to protect himself. If there is a solid connection you will feel it but they still cover a large area so to get that connection will be difficult.\n\n\"With the four-ounce gloves that are worn in MMA if you put the guard up you can still connect with punches.\n\n\"The four-ounce gloves literally cover the knuckles and then the padding is dispersed around the hand. earlier this evening.\n\nAnd the commission voted in favour of allowing the two biggest names in combat sports to box using 8oz gloves, which are normally used for fights taking place at less than 154lbs.\n\nThe hearing also saw the NAC announced the referee and judges for Mayweather vs. McGregor.\n\nVeteran referee Robert Byrd will officiate proceedings in the main event, while Burt Clements, {"timeCrawl": "05:09:00", "uri": "710687393", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T02:12:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Daily News", "uri": "nydailynews.com", "id": "422"}, "url": "http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/sports/lighter-gloves-spell-quick-mayweather-mcgregor-article-1.3418432", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "By Larry Fine\n\n(Reuters) - Mixed martial arts champion Conor McGregor is happy about the switch to lighter gloves for his Aug. 26 fight against undefeated boxer Floyd Mayweather and says his opponent will now struggle to make it past the second round.\n\nThe Nevada State Athletic Commission on Wednesday, just 10 days before the hotly anticipated Las Vegas fight, approved requests from Mayweather and McGregor to wear eight-ounce gloves rather than 10-ounce ones.\n\n\"That was a good thing for me. I'm very happy with it,\" McGregor told reporters on a conference call.\n\nMayweather had nearly all of his 49 professional wins using eight-ounce gloves, which may accentuate one of his advantages - his hand speed.\n\nMcGregor preferred the lighter gloves since he is used to the fingerless, four-ounce gloves typically worn in MMA.\n\n\"That's it in a nutshell, you've got pros and cons on both sides,\" he said. \"Favors us both in certain ways.\n\n\"I believe now that the gloves are eight ounces, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor added.\n\n\"Part of me ... kind of wants to show some skills and dismantle him that way. (But) I do not foresee him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nWhile most pundits have McGregor, who has never boxed professionally, as a heavy underdog, the Dubliner said he was determined to prove the doubters wrong.\n\n\"I'm just looking forward to Aug. 26, going in and proving what I'm saying and educating the world on what martial arts is,\" he said. \"And earning my respect in this game also.\"\n\nThe Irishman said his grueling preparations for the fight would enable him to triumph no matter how the fight develops.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I am not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor added.\n\n\"The training sessions and the practice that we've been putting in has been through hell and back. We are ready for absolutely every scenario.\n\n\"I'm ready to go to war for the full 12 rounds and I am ready to put him away in the first 10 seconds. That's where my head's at.\"\n\nDana White, president of the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC), followed McGregor on the conference call and predicted the fight could even threaten the reported $600 million haul from the Mayweather-Manny Pacquiao 2015 showdown.\n\n\"This is the biggest event ever in combat sports history. This is the most distributed event in pay-per-view history,\" White said, also citing the additional digital reach.\n\n\"This thing is in like 200 countries on pay-per-view. Boxing doesn't usually do a lot of digital. If you're in Manhattan or on a desert island somewhere, if you have Wifi you can buy this fight.\"\n\n(Editing by Peter Rutherford)\n\n(c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2017. {"timeCrawl": "09:35:00", "uri": "710795931", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:35:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Firstpost", "uri": "firstpost.com", "id": "2530"}, "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/sports/conor-mcgregor-says-floyd-mayweather-wont-last-two-rounds-against-him-in-upcoming-clash-3940273.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Los Angeles: Conor McGregor believes he will knock out Floyd Mayweather inside two rounds but is ready for all scenarios when the two fighters clash in their eagerly anticipated superfight next week.\n\nIrish mixed martial arts star McGregor told reporters on a conference call on Wednesday that a controversial switch to lighter gloves could lead to an explosive outcome in the 26 August showdown in Las Vegas.\n\nConor McGregor is delighted with glove size change from 10-ounce to 8-ounce. Twitter/@Maclifeofficial\n\nMcGregor, who is widely seen as a massive underdog against undefeated former welterweight king Mayweather, predicted an early finish to the fight.\n\n\"Particularly with the eight-ounce gloves, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" said McGregor, nevertheless expressing the hope that the fight would last longer.\n\n\"I don't want people saying 'Oh, it was a lucky punch' and all that. Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way.\n\n\"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a grueling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\"\n\nUlimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\n'Hits like a truck'\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves helps him big time. I think it absolutely does.\"\n\nMcGregor and Mayweather will climb into the ring following an international publicity tour last month marked by expletive-laden tirades and trash-talking.\n\nMcGregor, who was criticized for addressing Mayweather as \"boy\" during one event, dismissed suggestions that there was a racially tinged dimension to the duel.\n\n\"For me, it's athlete versus athlete,\" McGregor said. \"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's being portrayed. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. It's a set way and there is no other way. Well, if that was the case we would have never reached across the oceans in search of other lands. We would never have gone into space.\n\n\"You have to have an open mind and you got to realize that there are other ways. Fighting is a complex game. But I'm just looking forward to August 26 and proving what I'm saying and educating the world of what martial arts is.\"\n\nPublished Date: Aug 17, 2017 02:52 pm | Updated Date: Aug 17, 2017 02:52 {"timeCrawl": "00:23:00", "uri": "711178741", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:31:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Bleacher Report", "uri": "bleacherreport.com", "id": "3199"}, "url": "http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2728134-floyd-mayweather-says-conor-mcgregor-fight-is-his-last-talks-legacy-on-call", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "When Floyd Mayweather last stepped into a ring nearly two years ago to fight Andre Berto, he thought he was doing it for the last time.\n\nThis time, Mayweather says his impending retirement is for real.\n\n\"I gave my word to Al Haymon. I gave my word to my children. And one thing I don't want to do is break that. ... This will be my last fight,\" Mayweather said Thursday at a media conference call for his Aug. 26 fight against Conor McGregor.\n\nMayweather, who retired after earning a unanimous-decision win over Berto in September 2015, spent most of the conference call reflecting on a career that ranks among the greatest in boxing history. He would set an all-time record with 50 wins without a defeat should he beat McGregor, breaking a tie with Rocky Marciano.\n\n\"I don't try to focus on other fighters, but I'm appreciative for every fighter that paved the way for me to be where I'm at,\" Mayweather said. \"Even though this is No. 50, this is my 50th fight, that's not my focus. My focus is to give the fans an exciting fight. ... Rocky Marciano is a legend. Rocky Marciano did it his way. I'd just like to it the Mayweather way.\"\n\nMcGregor, the most famous face in mixed martial arts, is making his boxing debut after becoming the first fighter in UFC history to simultaneously hold two championships. Some have wondered whether McGregor, in the prime of his career, is taking too big of a risk switching sports altogether in a match that could lower his star power.\n\nMayweather said he believes his decision to put his undefeated record on the line is more of a risk.\n\n\"I believe I'm taking the bigger risk, I have the 49-0 record,\" Mayweather said. \"When a fighter has lost before, if he loses again, they say it's nothing he lost before. But when a boxer has been dominating for twentysome years, never lost, everything is on the line. My legacy, my boxing record, everything is on the line.\"\n\nMayweather also doubled down on his comments acknowledging that he may have lost a step at age 40.\n\n\"I'm just being honest, I don't think I'm the same Floyd Mayweather I was 21 years ago, of course not. I don't think I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 10 years ago. I'm not even the same Floyd Mayweather I was five or two years ago. But I said I still have a high IQ in that ring, and I said experience wise it leans towards me,\" he said.\n\nThe fight will take place using eight-ounce gloves, rather than the standard 10-ounce gloves, thanks to a waiver granted by the Nevada State Athletic Commission. McGregor typically fights using four-ounce gloves in UFC while boxing typically requires 10-ounce gloves for any weight class above 147 pounds.\n\nMayweather said that was put in place to avoid excuses on either side, saying, \"I'm not really worried about the outcome, I'm worried about excitement. I understand he's used to fighting in four-ounce gloves...I want to make him feel as comfortable as possible. {"timeCrawl": "18:28:00", "uri": "710482230", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:03:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Bloody Elbow", "uri": "bloodyelbow.com", "id": "1995"}, "url": "https://www.bloodyelbow.com/2017/8/16/16157244/nac-approves-eight-ounce-gloves-floyd-mayweather-vs-conor-mcgregor-boxing-ppv-news", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "The Nevada Athletic Commission has made a one-time exception to allow eight-ounce gloves for this 154-pound matchup between Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor.\n\nAt Wednesday's Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) meeting in Las Vegas, the ringside judges and referee were appointed for the August 26th super showdown between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Conor McGregor. Sorry to disappoint, but Marc Goddard won't be the referee.\n\nVeteran referee Robert Byrd will be in charge of the action in the ring, marking just the second time he's handled a Mayweather fight before. Byrd's first time reffing Floyd was his 2013 win over southpaw Robert Guerrero. Other notable recent major boxing events Byrd has featured in include the first Andre Ward vs. Sergey Kovalev matchup, as well as Miguel Cotto vs. Canelo Alvarez. He's a well-respected official who has been in the fight game for more than three decades.\n\nYour three judges at ringside will be Dave Moretti, Burt Clements, and Guido Cavalleri. Moretti and Clements were two of the judges who scored the Mayweather vs. Manny Pacquiao fight in 2015, with Moretti having Floyd winning 118-110, while Clements went a bit closer at 116-112. Cavalleri scored 115-112 for Mayweather over Marcos Maidana in their 2014 rematch, and otherwise has an extensive history judging fights outside the United States. I guess you can argue Cavalleri is the \"international judge\" McGregor's team wanted.\n\nLet's get to the much bigger story, which is the NAC's decision to approve (just once!) eight-ounce gloves for Mayweather vs. McGregor. The plan was for ten-ounce gloves, which is the actual NAC rule dictating as follows: (via ESPN)\n\n\"Athletes (boxers/kick boxers) weighing-in up to and including 135 pounds must wear 8 oz gloves in competition, while athletes weighing-in over 135 pounds (junior welterweight class and above) must wear 10 oz gloves in competition. However, athletes weighing-in over 135 but (no) more than 147 may wear 8 oz gloves in competition if both athletes agree to do so in writing on their bout agreement (contract).\"\n\nWell despite the Association of Ring Physicians (ARP) letter to the commission recommending that they don't change their rules \"Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of the bout,\" the NAC went ahead and changed the rules.\n\nMMA Fighting's Marc Raimondi has the details:\n\nThe commissioners, citing a lack of scientific evidence for their glove size rules dictated by weight class, all gave their approval. Chairman Anthony Marnell did say he was upset that Mayweather and McGregor had used the commission for promotion on social media.\n\n\"I do not like the Nevada State Athletic Commission being used as a pawn in a social media bout,\" Marnell said. \"Between these two, that part of this request pisses me off.\n\n\"This body is not the subject of two fighters ... to create social media stir and other controversy to sell tickets and to sell DirecTV.\"\n\nCommissioner Skip Avasino, the commission's most tenured member, said since it was a hybrid fight -- an MMA fighter coming in and facing a boxer -- they could grant a waiver for this occasion. But he recommend a scientific study that was first supposed to be done in 2006 regarding glove size.\n\nYou couldn't make it up, could you? Keep in mind that Mayweather's team was the one pushing for eight-ounce gloves, just like they did for the 2012 fight against Miguel Cotto. Funnily enough, that request was denied.\n\nOh yeah, and two weeks ago, NAC executive director Bob Bennett was on record as saying this:", "id": "9541893", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", {"timeCrawl": "10:45:00", "uri": "711393824", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:38:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "Citizen", "uri": "thecitizen.co.tz", "id": "339"}, "url": "http://www.thecitizen.co.tz/News/Sports/McGregor--I-ll-fast-finish-Mayweather/1840572-4062218-rlmrvv/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Irish mixed martial arts star McGregor told reporters on a conference call on Wednesday that a controversial switch to lighter gloves could lead to an explosive outcome in the August 26 showdown in Las Vegas. McGregor, who is widely seen as a massive underdog against undefeated former welterweight king Mayweather, predicted an early finish to the fight.\n\nConor McGregor believes he will knock out Floyd Mayweather inside two rounds but is ready for all scenarios when the two fighters clash in their eagerly anticipated superfight next week.\n\nIrish mixed martial arts star McGregor told reporters on a conference call on Wednesday that a controversial switch to lighter gloves could lead to an explosive outcome in the August 26 showdown in Las Vegas. McGregor, who is widely seen as a massive underdog against undefeated former welterweight king Mayweather, predicted an early finish to the fight. \"Particularly with the eight-ounce gloves, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" said McGregor, nevertheless expressing the hope that the fight would last longer.\n\n\"I don't want people saying 'Oh, it was a lucky punch' and all that. Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way.\n\n\"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a grueling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said. \"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\" Ulimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent. \"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves helps him big time. I think it absolutely does.\" (AFP)\n\nMcGregor and Mayweather will climb into the ring following an international publicity tour last month marked by expletive-laden tirades and trash-talking.\n\nMcGregor, who was criticized for addressing Mayweather as \"boy\" during one event, dismissed suggestions that there was a racially tinged dimension to the duel.\n\n\"For me, it's athlete versus athlete,\" McGregor said. \"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's being portrayed. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"", "id": "9875136", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "McGregor: I'll fast finish Mayweather", I'm very happy with it,\" McGregor told reporters on a conference call.\n\nMayweather had nearly all of his 49 professional wins using eight-ounce gloves, which may accentuate one of his advantages - his hand speed.\n\nMcGregor preferred the lighter gloves since he is used to the fingerless, four-ounce gloves typically worn in MMA.\n\n\"That's it in a nutshell, you've got pros and cons on both sides,\" he said. \"Favours us both in certain ways.\n\n\"I believe now that the gloves are eight ounces, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor added.\n\n\"Part of me ... kind of wants to show some skills and dismantle him that way. We are ready for absolutely every scenario.\n\n\"I'm ready to go to war for the full 12 rounds and I am ready to put him away in the first 10 seconds. This is the most distributed event in pay-per-view history,\" White said, also citing the additional digital reach.\n\n\"This thing is in like 200 countries on pay-per-view. {"timeCrawl": "20:21:00", "uri": "711098427", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:15:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"title": "MMAjunkie", "uri": "mmajunkie.com", "id": "8466"}, "url": "http://mmajunkie.com/2017/08/nsac-hand-conor-mcgregor-advantage-floyd-mayweather-attorney-ufc", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "LAS VEGAS - It didn't take much to get eight-ounce gloves approved for \"The Money Fight.\" A little posturing and a little finger-wagging was all it needed to realize Floyd Mayweather's challenge to Conor McGregor.\n\nThe question now is, does it mean anything?\n\nBefore retiring this past year, Mayweather (49-0 boxing) boxed most of his career as a welterweight - he's no stranger to eight-ounce gloves. McGregor(21-3 MMA, 9-1 UFC), meanwhile, competes in the octagon, where four-ounce gloves are standard equipment. Who's got the advantage?\n\nWith less sheathing to cover his heavy hands, some might say McGregor. If you ask the guy who helped him get new gloves, he doesn't necessarily see it that way.\n\n\"Nobody can talk about this fight better than Conor, but I think what Conor would say to that is, Conor would be happy to fight in 16-ounce gloves, or no gloves at all,\" said attorney Mike Mersch, who represented McGregor on Wednesday during the meeting that prompted the commission to break an 11-year-old rule. \"He'd be happy to fight in a boxing ring, or in an octagon. He'd be happy to fight in boxing shoes, or in bare feet. He's ready for this fight. He doesn't care what the size of the gloves are.\n\n\"When this challenge was thrown down by Floyd, Conor immediately accepted. I don't think there's much more to it than that. Conor's ready to fight.\"\n\nThe UFC lightweight champ's attorney is no stranger to the NSAC's rules - he helped write them. A former deputy attorney general, he was on the subcommittee that wrote the rules requiring boxing fights at 147 pounds and under to use eight-ounce gloves, while fights above require 10-ounce gloves.\n\nMersch later took a job with the UFC, eventually becoming the promotion's senior VP of business, legal and government affairs. The commission, meanwhile, never completed a study to test the effectiveness of its new glove regulations.\n\nRaymond \"Skip\" Avansino, the NSAC's most senior member, ordered that study to be completed as a condition of a special one-time exemption from the rule.\n\nMersch agrees with the commission that a change is warranted given the special circumstances surrounding the Aug. 26 blockbuster. He said if anything, the Showtime pay-per-view event at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas provides a catalyst for re-examining the current rules.\n\nOf course, it's a very lucrative catalyst for the commission - which takes a portion of the box office - McGregor, and definitely Mayweather, who said he could make $350 million in one night's work.\n\n\"If there's a fight to try this out as a potential test case, I can't think of a better fight than this one,\" Mersch said.\n\nThe boxing gloves to be used for \"The Money Fight\" have yet to be announced, but the Mayweather and McGregor camps say they will be an American-style glove with more padding on the fist, as opposed to a \"punchers glove\" typical of Mexican-made gloves. Three pairs will by provided to the NSAC for inspection - and inclusion into the glove study.\n\nAs to which fighter has more weight behind his punches, that advantage seems tilted to McGregor. Mersch told the commission the Irish champ will likely be 160 pounds or higher on fight night, while Mayweather will be 150.\n\nFor more on \"The Money Fight: Floyd Mayweather vs. Conor McGregor,\" check out the MMA Rumors section of the site.\n\nJul 13, 2017; Brooklyn, NY, USA; during a world tour press conference to promote the upcoming Mayweather vs McGregor boxing fight at Barclays Center. wants to show some skill and to dismantle him,' the Irishman said\n\nConor McGregor admits a part of him hopes he does not knockout Floyd Mayweather so he can show his doubters why there are wrong to showdown, McGregor predicted that he would stop Mayweather within the first two rounds.\n\nBut the Irishman, who is the heavy underdog for the August 26 clash, claimed he hopes his opponent can withstand his early onslaught so he can 'educate' the boxing world and earn the respect he is due.\n\nConor McGregor is the heavy underdog for his upcoming showdown with Floyd Mayweather\n\nMany boxing pundits predict that the MMA star will struggle to lay a glove on Mayweather\n\n'Now the gloves are 8oz, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,' McGregor said on Wednesday.\n\n'(But) part of me is hoping that maybe he can last... part of me wants to show some skill and to dismantle him.'\n\nMcGregor has been given little more than a puncher's chance in the upcoming bout, particularly among boxing experts and pundits.\n\nMike Tyson claimed the UFC star would be 'killed' in the fight while former Mayweather opponents Manny Pacquiao and Oscar De La Hoya both said he had 'no chance' of beating the former five-weight world champion.\n\nMcGregor predicts that Mayweather will not last two rounds now he is wearing 8oz gloves\n\nBut the Irishman admits he hopes Mayweather does last so he can 'educate' the boxing world\n\nBut McGregor, who has risen to the top of the UFC through intelligent movement and fierce counter-punching, is relishing the chance to show the world that they are wrong to write him off.\n\n'It's certainly motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,' McGregor said.\n\n'I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. It's a set way and there is no other way. Well if that was the case we would have never reached across the waters in search of other lands. We would never have gone into space. You have to have an open mind and you have to realise that there are other ways,' he added.\n\n'I use it as motivation and I look forward to going in and educating. I'm very happy with it,\" McGregor told reporters on a conference call.\n\nMayweather had nearly all of his 49 professional wins using eight-ounce gloves, which may accentuate one of his advantages - his hand speed.\n\nMcGregor preferred the lighter gloves since he is used to the fingerless, four-ounce gloves typically worn in MMA.\n\n\"That's it in a nutshell, you've got pros and cons on both sides,\" he said. \"Favours us both in certain ways.\n\n\"I believe now that the gloves are eight ounces, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor added.\n\n\"Part of me ... kind of wants to show some skills and dismantle him that way. (But) I do not foresee him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nWhile most pundits have McGregor, who has never boxed professionally, as a heavy underdog, the Dubliner said he was determined to prove the doubters wrong.\n\n\"I'm just looking forward to Aug. 26, going in and proving what I'm saying and educating the world on what martial arts is,\" he said. \"And earning my respect in this game also.\"\n\nThe Irishman said his gruelling preparations for the fight would enable him to triumph no matter how the fight develops.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I am not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor added.\n\n\"The training sessions and the practice that we've been putting in has been through hell and back. We are ready for absolutely every scenario.\n\n\"I'm ready to go to war for the full 12 rounds and I am ready to put him away in the first 10 seconds. This is the most distributed event in pay-per-view history,\" White said, also citing the additional digital reach.\n\n\"This thing is in like 200 countries on pay-per-view. Even though much of the focus on the Aug. 26 showdown between Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor has been on the UFC lightweight champion's jump from the Octagon to the ring, somewhat lost in the shuffle has been that Mayweather has declared this bout at T-Mobile Arena will be his final fight.\n\n\"I thought that (the Andre Berto fight) was going to be my last everything,\" Mayweather said on Thursday's media teleconference, referring to the 2015 bout after which he retired. Yet earlier this year, the war of words between Mayweather and McGregor turned into a real fight that pulled the Grand Rapids native out of retirement for next week's meeting.\n\nBut after this one, that's it, said \"Money.\"\n\n\"This is my last one. I gave my word to (adviser) Al Haymon, I gave my word to my children and I don't want to break that. I want to stick to my word. This will be my last fight.\"\n\nNot surprisingly, a lot of the questions asked of Mayweather focused on his past. Yet while the 49-0 future Hall of Famer brought up his fights with Diego Corrales, Phillip Ndou, Arturo Gatti, Ricky Hatton, Miguel Cotto and Canelo Alvarez as ones that his fans point out to him as favorites, the 40-year-old was non-committal when it came to picking the one fight when he thought he was at his best. In fact, he said he doesn't even like to watch his own fights.\n\nRELATED: Get tickets for the biggest fight in combat sports history | Don't wait. Pre-order Mayweather-McGregor now\n\n\"It's hard for me to watch my fights,\" he said. \"It could be a fight against any guy that the fans and people say they love the most, but when I look at it, I'm like, 'I could have done this better, I could have done that better.' I'm a critic of myself and I feel like it's never good enough.\"\n\nMayweather has been more than good enough over the last two decades since he competed in the 1996 Olympics, as he won titles in five weight classes and became the best boxer of this era. His place in Canastota is secure, but there is the looming ghost of the 50-0 mark, which would allow Mayweather to pass Rocky Marciano's 49-0 record as he walked off into the sunset.\n\n\"I'm appreciative for every fighter that paved the way for me to be where I'm at,\" Mayweather said. \"I appreciate the legendary fighters. This is my 50th fight, but that's not really my focus. My focus is to go out there and give the fans an exciting fight, even though I know this is number 50, and we're constantly talking about Rocky Marciano. Rocky Marciano is a legend, he did it his way and I'd just like to try to do it the Mayweather way.\"\n\nHe has done it his way, changing the economics of the sport outside the ring while he beat all comers inside it. Next week, Conor McGregor will try to shock the world and beat Mayweather in his first professional boxing match. It's a risky proposition for the Irishman, but Mayweather believes he's the one with everything on the line in Vegas.\n\n\"I truly believe I'm taking a bigger risk,\" he said. \"I have the 49-0 record, and when a fighter has lost before, if he loses again, they say, 'Oh, it's nothing, he lost before.' But when a fighter has been dominating for 20-something years and never lost, everything is on the line. The open workouts\n\nGetty Images\n\nMost recently America's Terence Crawford, among the world's finest fighters, and David Haye have released videos on social media mocking the warm-up technique with which McGregor demonstrates unusually loose and flexible arms.\n\nRead more Explained: Why Mayweather wanted to fight McGregor in 8oz gloves\n\nMcGregor manoeuvred his way into such a lucrative fight partly through his clever use of social media, but after insisting he found the videos \"light-hearted\", he became defensive and revealed how he is using those doubting him as motivation.\n\n\"It's certainly motivating,\" he said. \"The disrespect of my skill-set: I look at people and their minds are closed. 'It's a set way and there's no other way'. \"If that was the case we'd never have reached across the waters and searched for other land, and never have gone into space.\n\n\"When I hear their disrespect, I use it as motivation and I look forward to going in and educating them. I get it. I'm coming in (to the sport), I understand where it's at, I'm just looking forward to proving what I'm saying and earning my respect in this game also.\n\nMcGregor faces Mayweather in a fortnight (Getty)\n\n\"I've seen some videos, but it's light-hearted, I don't take it personally. If anything I see stiffness in every single one of them. With that skill-set, it's how you can change a jab to a hook in the blink of an eye, or a jab to an uppercut. It's the same thing as the hip-flexors for a kick. If I'm tight in the hips and can't free my legs, I can free my shoulders like I showed...\n\nRead more The breakdown: McGregor's essential stats ahead of Mayweather fight\n\n\"These are just age-old training methods. That shoulder method you saw was made very popular by the great Rickson Gracie, one of the pioneers of mixed-martial arts. It's a shoulder-loosening exercise: you've got to do it correct though.\n\n\"David Haye is a man who's pulled out of contests over a sore baby toe so he must be careful with the way he hits the pads. We will educate as we go forward.\"\n\nMcGregor also again dismissed any notion that there is a racial element to next weekend's fight; the August 26 promotional tour had concluded with Mayweather accusing him of racism on stage at Wembley Arena.\n\nFirst video of Conor McGregor boxing shows him battling former IBF champion\n\n\"This is athlete versus athlete,\" he said. \"I was upset that Floyd tried to bring that in, he and his people truly know that it's not from me. I'm not saying that there aren't people on both sides that have this mindset where it's black versus white, but it's certainly something I do not condone. This is athlete versus athlete, two prime physical condition athletes taking part in an amazing event.\n\n\"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's sometimes been portrayed, but it's just the nature of the game with the way things are going on in the world at the moment. All I can do is stay focused and look to put on a great performance for the fans who are supporting this event as a whole.\"\n\nMore about: Conor McGregor Floyd Mayweather Mayweather vs McGregor Reuse Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way.\n\n\"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a grueling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\"\n\nUlimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\n'Hits like a truck'\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves helps him big time. I think it absolutely does.\"\n\nMcGregor and Mayweather will climb into the ring following an international publicity tour last month marked by expletive-laden tirades and trash-talking.\n\nMcGregor, who was criticised for addressing Mayweather as \"boy\" during one event, dismissed suggestions that there was a racially tinged dimension to the duel.\n\n\"For me, it's athlete versus athlete,\" McGregor said. \"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's being portrayed. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. It's a set way and there is no other way. Well, if that was the case we would have never reached across the oceans in search of other lands. We would never have gone into space.\n\n\"You have to have an open mind and you got to realise that there are other ways. Fighting is a complex game. {"timeCrawl": "23:05:00", "uri": "710586156", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:23:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"title": "Standard Republic", "uri": "standardrepublic.com", "id": "18909"}, "url": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/2017/08/illegal-blow-disqualification-will-cost-mcgregor-90-of-fight-purse-mayweather-rt-sport/25378.htm", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "Conor McGregor will lose a whopping 90 percent of his reported $75 million purse for the fight with Floyd Mayweather Jr on August 26 should he be disqualified for an illegal blow.\n\nMany have speculated that brash Irishman McGregor may resort to a martial arts move in an attempt to end the billion-dollar crossover fight, whether in frustration or in an act of showmanship at the T-Mobile Arena, Las Vegas.\n\nREAD MORE: Russian who defeated McGregor in 2008 puts fight trunks up for charity auction\n\nBut Mayweather claims the UFC hotshot will lose \"90 pecent or more\" of his estimated purse (which could equal $67.5 million) for the fight, should he use any strike that goes against boxing's Queensberry rules.\n\nMayweather made the claims while appearing on American talk show Jimmy Kimmel Live, where he and host Jimmy Kimmel were working their way through available prop bets for the fight when Kimmel put a question to Mayweather.\n\n\"What if Conor kicks you in the head, what are you gonna do? I know it's against the rules,\" Kimmel enquired.\n\nThe fighter, nicknamed 'Money', replied: \"That's a fine, that's a huge fine. I don't think he wants to lose probably 90 percent of his money or even more. I don't know what it's going to be, but it's going to be a heavy fine.\"\n\nMayweather dismissed any claims he himself had designs on using any martial arts moves on McGregor, stating: \"I'm not gonna do that. I follow by the Queensberry rules of boxing.\"\n\nMayweather also told Kimmel that he categorically believes the fight will not go the full 12 round scheduled distance.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Nevada {"timeCrawl": "10:22:00", "uri": "710817474", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:22:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"title": "The Telegraph", "uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "id": "220"}, "url": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/boxing/2017/08/17/conor-mcgregor-8oz-gloves-floyd-mayweather-fight-will-suit/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Conor McGregor believes a Nevada State Athletic Commission decision to allow 8oz gloves for the mega-fight with Floyd Mayweather will play into his hands when the two protagonists clash in Las Vegas on Saturday week.\n\nMcGregor says it will be his greater power with the smaller gloves versus Mayweather's faster hand speed. The Irishman, set to make upwards of $80 million for the fight, also played down any racist undertones to the bout and has used the boxing world's dismissal of his chances of beating Mayweather as \"deep motivation\".\n\n\"I'm very happy with how the Nevada State Athletic Commission handled it. It was handled fairly and they listened to both requests,\" said McGregor.\n\nNevada rules have stipulated since 2006 that boxing matches between fighters over 147lbs must see the use of 10oz gloves. However, both McGregor and Mayweather submitted formal requests to the commission asking for it to issue a waiver for their fight, which is being fought at 154lbs.\n\nThe commissioners voted unanimously in favour of the request on Wednesday, with the appointment in the same sitting session of Robert Byrd as referee and Burt Clements, Dave Moretti and Guido Cavalleri as judges.\n\n\"Overall their approach to the decision, judges and referee was fair throughout, with them taking into consideration both fighters' requests,\" McGregor added.\n\nThe gloves simply intensify the challenge, he believes. \"I think that's it in a nutshell. You have pros and cons on both sides,\" he said. \"Both athletes were asking for it, and me, I'm coming up in ounces from what I am used to. Hey, look what I fight with. I fight in 4oz fingerless gloves. It benefits both of us in certain ways.\"\n\nMcGregor added that he is motivated by being written off by the boxing world. \"It's certainly motivating. The disrespect of my skill-set. I look at people and their minds are closed. 'It's a set way and there's no other way'.\n\n\"If that was the case we'd never have reached across the waters and searched for other lands, and never have gone into space.\n\n\"When I hear their disrespect, I use it as motivation and I look forward to going in and educating them. I get it. I'm coming in, I understand where it's at, I'm just looking forward to proving what I'm saying and earning my respect in this game also.\"\n\nMcGregor also ruled out any racial element in next weekend's contest, after Mayweather had accused him of racism at the Wembley Arena press conference.\n\n\"This is athlete versus athlete,\" he said. \"I was upset that Floyd tried to bring that in, he and his people truly know that it's not from me.\n\n\"I'm not saying that there aren't people on both sides that have this mindset where it's black versus white, but it's certainly something I do not condone. This is athlete versus athlete, two athletes in their prime physical condition taking part in an amazing event.\n\n\"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's sometimes been portrayed, but it's just the nature of the game with the way things are going on in the world at the moment. {"timeCrawl": "09:29:00", "uri": "711358364", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:01:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"title": "Fox Sports", "uri": "foxsports.com.au", "id": "5024"}, "url": "http://www.foxsports.com.au/boxing/mcgregor-vs-mayweather/floyd-mayweather-conor-mcgregor-fight-news-will-ufc-superstar-gas-out-over-12-rounds-nate-diaz-past/news-story/72c8afee8cfaffb4e5d18e3d8c1409a7", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "CONOR McGregor fought 25 minutes against Nate Diaz in their rematch, at times looking terribly exhausted, eyeing off the clock and walking away from his rival to catch his breath.\n\nThat majority decision win was only the second time in his MMA career that McGregor (21-3 MMA, 18KO, 1SUB) has gone the distance. The other instance was four years ago, a unanimous decision win over Max Holloway, in a non-championship match lasting 15 minutes.\n\nThe maximum fight time vs unbeaten boxing icon Floyd Mayweather (49-0), in McGregor's very first professional boxing match, is 36 minutes - 12 three-minute rounds.\n\nSo if he gassed out against Diaz, albeit in five-minute rounds where he also had to grapple, how will his cardio hold up against a fighter who calls himself - with arguable justification - The Best Ever? Especially when Mayweather has gone the distance 19 times in 12-round fights, against world championship-class opposition?\n\nMayweather himself raised the question this week, while Diaz's boxing trainer Richard Perez also panned McGregor's hopes.\n\n\"No, he doesn't have a punchers chance - and he gasses out,\" Perez told BJ Penn Radio, raising old allegations of substance abuse. \"I don't care how hard he trains.\n\n\"There's no way he's going to do this without taking any substances, and be strong in boxing, because boxing is a lot of stamina.\"\n\nLIVE stream Mayweather v McGregor Weigh Ins & Prelims on FOX SPORTS. His struggles can partly be pinned on extra weight - he was fighting at 170 pounds, up from his usual 145/155 pounds at featherweight/lightweight. The Mayweather fight is at 154 pounds.\n\nSpeaking on the Conan O'Brien Show, he was defiant about his stamina.\n\n\"Yeah, we've made slight adjustments in my cardio preparation,\" the 29 year-old said, maintaining his prediction of a knockout victory within four rounds.\n\n\"It's actually been very enjoyable to go from five five-minute rounds, which is what we're used to, which is 25 minutes, to 12 three-minute rounds of boxing, which is 36 minutes. Slight adjustments, but we are more than ready. I've done 12 rounds last night, I've done multiple 12-round fights in the gym in the lead-up to this. We are more than ready.\n\n\"Floyd is praying for me to fatigue in there, but I will not fatigue. I will continue to press forward, and I will break him. At 40 years of age, he will not sustain my pace. So, that is it.\"\n\nMcGregor elaborated speaking to the Telegraph, claiming he had been using a nutrition regime called the 'McGregor Fast Programme' after he lost his first match-up with Diaz.\n\n\"We formulated it for the Diaz rematch and he was a triathlete with a big weight advantage and he could go for days. He had an unrivalled gas tank,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We came up with special formula and we created the McGregor fast programme and I've been on that since a week after that first loss.\n\n\"We've adjusted certain timings in my cardiovascular preparation. The endurance phase has been stretched out to accommodate the twelve three-minute rounds.\n\n\"You've got to factor in that there's not as much grappling. There is still grappling, but not to the extent of a mixed martial arts bout where you can end up on your back and you've got to tactically work your way back to your feet which is very draining. It's a different kind of cardio training. We've adjusted some things and I feel absolutely amazing.\"\n\nMcGregor KO's former champion\n\n0:18\n\nTwo former UFC champions have weighed in on McGregor's chances, one writing him off, the other giving him some hope.\n\nFormer bantamweight champion TJ Dillashaw said the Irishman's cardio would not hold up against Mayweather and also took the little-held view that 'Money' was the harder puncher - and therefore the biggest beneficiary of a reduction in the glove size to eight ounces.\n\n\"Mayweather's going to make him miss, he's going to make him get tired,\" Dillashaw told FightHype. \"McGregor, in my opinion, doesn't have the cardio and [Mayweather] is going to take advantage of that in the later rounds.\n\n\"[8oz gloves are] to his advantage ... to Mayweather's. I think Mayweather is the heavier hitter. Even though it [doesn't look] like it when Conor fights in MMA ... we are wearing 4oz gloves, it's a little bit of a different story. I still think Mayweather is the heavier hitter.\"\n\nEddie Alvarez, who had his lightweight title taken by McGregor via spectacular KO, said his rival could get Mayweather early but risked knockout himself if he went deep into the fight.\n\n\"A lot of boxing fans are looking at Conor like he's never ever boxed. Even the way they're talking, it's like they're writing him of like he's never boxed,\" Alvarez told UFC media.\n\n\"I boxed. He understands boxing. I think that his chance is going to happen within the first four rounds. And Conor can, I think you're a fool if you don't think Conor can put Floyd away. I think he can, I think he can land a punch and put Floyd away.\n\n\"I think if it goes past the fourth round, where it can become a technical boxing match, I think it can look one-sided. Floyd's the king of that. He's the king of kind of swimming and not getting wet, he can punch and not get hit. I think if it goes further past five, six, seven, eight, he could win by TKO. {"timeCrawl": "03:12:00", "uri": "710654169", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:12:00Z", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "source": {"title": "Economic Times", "uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "id": "305"}, "url": "http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/boxing-lighter-gloves-spell-quick-end-of-mayweather-says-mcgregor/articleshow/60095893.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "The Nevada State Athletic Commission on Wednesday, just 10 days before the hotly anticipated Las Vegas fight, approved requests from Mayweather and McGregor to wear eight-ounce gloves rather than 10-ounce ones.\n\n\"That was a good thing for me. I'm very happy with it,\" McGregor told reporters on a conference call.\n\nMayweather had nearly all of his 49 professional wins using eight-ounce gloves, which may accentuate one of his advantages - his hand speed.\n\nMcGregor preferred the lighter gloves since he is used to the fingerless, four-ounce gloves typically worn in MMA.\n\n\"That's it in a nutshell, you've got pros and cons on both sides,\" he said. \"Favours us both in certain ways.\n\n\"I believe now that the gloves are eight ounces, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor added.\n\n\"Part of me ... kind of wants to show some skills and dismantle him that way. (But) I do not foresee him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nWhile most pundits have McGregor, who has never boxed professionally, as a heavy underdog, the Dubliner said he was determined to prove the doubters wrong.\n\n\"I'm just looking forward to Aug. 26, going in and proving what I'm saying and educating the world on what martial arts is,\" he said. \"And earning my respect in this game also.\"\n\nThe Irishman said his gruelling preparations for the fight would enable him to triumph no matter how the fight develops.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I am not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor added.\n\n\"The training sessions and the practice that we've been putting in has been through hell and back. Floyd, however, remained the same laid back guy he has largely been with the media in recent years.\n\n\"I haven't had time to focus on anything but this event,\" he claimed, which anyone who has closely followed Mayweather knows is most likely true. Love him or hate him, he's an fascinating individual. If McGregor rides on overdrive with the media, Mayweather likes to sprinkle his talks with interesting asides. For every boast (\"My real estate portfolio is truly amazing.\") there's something telling about the man that's offered. Like the fact that he refuses to watch his own fights. \"When I look at them,\" Mayweather said, \"I'm like I could have done this better I could have done that better.\" There's also his interesting take on Rocky Marciano, the man whose 49-0 record most assume Mayweather will best in a week from Saturday.\n\n\"Rocky Marciano is a legend,\" he claimed. \"Rocky Marciano did it his way. I just want to do it the Mayweather way.\"\n\nOne interesting side note:\n\nNo one - not a single person - asked Mayweather why he chose a man who has never had a boxing match in his life as his supposed last opponent. {"timeCrawl": "08:42:00", "uri": "711338120", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T08:42:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "uri": "dnaindia.com", "id": "492"}, "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-it-s-worth-it-floyd-mayweather-on-putting-legacy-on-the-line-against-conor-mcgregor-2533912", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "'I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight.' says Mayweather.\n\nWith his superfight against Conor McGregor a little over a week away, Floyd Mayweather struck a reflective tone on Thursday as he discussed the risk of coming out of retirement for a massive payday.\n\nMayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career, while McGregor, who is making his professional boxing debut, is 21-3 in mixed martial arts.\n\n\"When a fighter has lost before, if he loses again they say 'oh, it's nothing, he's lost before,'\" Mayweather told a conference call. \"But when a fighter has been dominating for 20-some years and never lost, everything is on the line. My legacy. My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\"\n\nThe fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite scepticism about how competitive it will be.\n\nMayweather, a master defensive technician and tactician, is heavily favoured to win the August 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said that, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather. \"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 21 years ago. Of course not,\" he said. \"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 10 years ago. I'm, not even the same Floyd Mayweather that I was I was five or two years ago. But I still have a high IQ in that ring. And experience wise, it leans towards me, period, because I have been in the ring at such a high level for so long.\"", "id": "9853640", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "'It's worth it': {"timeCrawl": "19:26:00", "uri": "710504408", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T16:30:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "MMAjunkie", "uri": "mmajunkie.com", "id": "8466"}, "url": "http://mmajunkie.com/2017/08/nevada-commission-8-ounce-gloves-floyd-mayweather-conor-mcgregor", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "The Nevada State Athletic Commission today voted unanimously to grant a request from Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor's camps to allow eight-ounce gloves to be used for \"The Money Fight.\"\n\nCommissioners agreed to the change - a break from its longstanding rule that requires 10-ounce gloves be used for fights contested at 154 pounds - as a one-time exception.\n\nNSAC's current rules stipulate eight-ounce gloves are supposed to be used for fights contested at 147 pounds. But commissioners agreed the unusual circumstances of the bout made it possible to grant the one-time exception, which the Association of Ringside Physicians strongly cautioned against in a letter submitted prior to today's meeting.\n\nTo satisfy safety concerns, three stipulations were also added to the approval: The eight-ounce gloves and their alternate must be inspected and approved by NSAC Chairman Anthony Marnell and executive director Bob Bennett; the gloves must be submitted to the NSAC after the fight; and those gloves be used for a study on glove size conducted by the NSAC (via Twitter):\n\nToday's #MayweatherMcGregor news? Eight-ounce gloves have been approved. Does this guarantee a knockout? pic.twitter.com/hU2520G6YZ\n\n-- MMAjunkie (@MMAjunkie) August 16, 2017\n\n\"The Money Fight\" takes place Aug. 26 at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas. The NSAC regulates the pay-per-view event.\n\nMcGregor expressed pleasure with all of the NSAC's decisions today, including assignments of referee and judges.\n\n\"I am very pleased with the Nevada State Athletic Commission's handling of my next bout today,\" McGregor said in a statement on his website TheMacLife.com. \"Fair play was kept all the way through. Referee - Hall of famer Robert Byrd. Judges - Burt Clements. Dave Morreti and Guido Cavalerri. Eight-ounce gloves approved, with pre- and post-fight analysis of the gloves on the night.\n\n\"This was handled very well and very fairly by the NSAC. I am very pleased and respect the commission's ruling on this. Ten days until fight time.\"\n\nLongtime NSAC commissioner Raymond \"Skip\" Avansino, who raised the initial motion for approval, noted a study had been ordered in 2006 after a safety committee had determined standardized weights and glove sizes. But the study had never been completed.\n\n\"That's the rule for at least 11 years,\" Avansino said. \"However, rules need to be reconsidered from time to time.\"\n\nMarnell offered a token of objection by noting the request had come out of a social media battle between Mayweather (49-0 boxing) and McGregor (21-3 MMA, 9-1 UFC), forcing the commission to address the issue after the two agreed to fight at 154 pounds.\n\n\"Frankly, that part of it, it pisses me off,\" Marnell said.\n\nBut several commissioners ultimately decided that the bout's referee, veteran official Robert Byrd, will be the ultimate gatekeeper of the fighters' health and safety. They expressed confidence that if one fighter is not fighting to his best abilities, the bout will be stopped quickly.\n\n\"We always pride ourselves on stopping the fight one punch too soon, rather than one punch too late,\" Marnell said.\n\nReps for Mayweather and McGregor testified before the ruling that there were no health and safety concerns from the fighters. UFC attorney Hunter Campbell said they have agreed to wear American-style gloves that distribute the gloves' padding to the fists rather than the \"punchers-style\" horsehair gloves made in Mexico.\n\nFor more on \"The Money Fight: Floyd Mayweather vs. Conor McGregor,\" check out the MMA Rumors section of the site.\n\nJul 13, 2017; Brooklyn, NY, USA; during a world tour press conference to promote the upcoming Mayweather vs McGregor boxing fight at Barclays Center. he pocketed $32 million in the process, but for a man of Mayweather's wealth $32 million is a relatively small sum.\n\n'Money' as the 40-year-old is appropriately nicknamed was particularly busy in 2015.\n\nHis historic bout against Manny Pacquiao obliterated multiple records - including PPV buys (4.6 million), total gate ($73 million) and sponsorships ($13 million).\n\nThe Pacquiao fight grossed more than $600 million and was the highest-grossing, single-day sporting event ever.\n\nThe Michigan man topped the Forbes list of highest paid athletes in 2012, 2013 and 2014 and was ranked number 34 in a list of America's richest entrepreneurs under 40 last year (He is now over 40).\n\nAs well as boxing, the American heads The Money Team - a business venture that invests in a range of areas including fashion, music, sport and entertainment.\n\nIn June, he trademarked TMT 50 and TBE 50, which stand for \"The Money Team\" and \"The Best Ever.\"\n\n'Money' Mayweather is worth approximately $340m (\u20ac300m)\n\nThe boxer will significantly add to his riches when he fights McGregor in August, according to ESPN the bout will net over $605 million, adding tax and such, you could expect Mayweather to take home around 55% of the original sum.\n\nWhat is Conor McGregor's net worth?\n\nConor McGregor is a wealthy man. {"timeCrawl": "03:29:00", "uri": "711228144", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:29:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/boxing/its-worth-it-mayweather-on-putting-legacy-on-the-line/articleshow/60112466.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "Mayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career, while McGregor, who is making his professional boxing debut, is 21-3 in mixed martial arts. With his superfight against Conor McGregor a little over a week away, Floyd Mayweather struck a reflective tone on Thursday as he discussed the risk of coming out of retirement for a massive payday.\n\nMayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career, while McGregor, who is making his professional boxing debut, is 21-3 in mixed martial arts.\n\n\"When a fighter has lost before, if he loses again they say 'oh, it's nothing, he's lost before,'\" Mayweather told a conference call. \"But when a fighter has been dominating for 20-some years and never lost, everything is on the line. My legacy. My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\"\n\nThe fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite scepticism about how competitive it will be. Mayweather, a master defensive technician and tactician, is heavily favoured to win the Aug. 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said that, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather. \"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 21 years ago. Of course not,\" he said. \"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 10 years ago. I'm, not even the same Floyd Mayweather that I was I was five or two years ago.\n\n\"But I still have a high IQ in that ring.
