{"timeCrawl": "16:49:00", "uri": "710438656", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:03:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "Cageside Press", "uri": "cagesidepress.com", "id": "19157"}, "url": "https://cagesidepress.com/2017/08/15/mayweather-vs-mcgregor-break-records/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "The super fight between Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor is supposed to be the biggest event in combat sports this year, and arguably of all time. The bout pits the biggest draw in boxing against the absolute hottest ticket in mixed martial arts. Both men are experts in their craft, and brilliant showmen and promoters in their own right. They have become household names by galvanizing fanbases in ways very few fighters have ever been able to do and the collision between the two is expected to do historical numbers. Why then, does it feel as if there are now tentative expectations as the super fight draws closer?\n\nFirst, the reports of ticket sales doing poorly are a sign that promoters overestimated the market. Prices are astronomical, even by blockbuster fight standards. By comparison, the hotly anticipated boxing match-up between Canelo Alvarez and \"Triple G\" Gennady Golovkin has been sold out almost since the tickets went on sale. Before conclusions are jumped to, it should be noted that prices for Canelo/GGG are far lower than those for Mayweather/McGregor.\n\nMayweather promoter Leonard Ellerbe has stated that sales are doing well, and adjusting for inflation they most likely are. Ticket prices are significantly higher. As such, the super fight does not need to sell nearly as many tickets in order to surpass the gate of Canelo/GGG.\n\nThis does not change the fact that increasing reports do not bode well for a sold out T-Mobile Arena. There are still hundreds of seats available with the fight now two weeks away. More recently, the re-sale market has spiked indicating that demand to go to the fight in person is lower than anticipated. On another note, reports that tickets are now available at Costco feel more like a prank than a way to boost sales. Simply put: if the fight was sold out, would there even be a chance that tickets found their way to Costco regardless of whether that was the plan or not?\n\nThe $100 dollar tag for the pay-per-view has many fans balking at the price. The previous $100 super fight between Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao left many fans feeling cheated as the bout failed to please fans. That fight was between two of the best boxers of a generation. McGregor may yet become an all-time great mixed martial artist, but it does not change the fact that he is 0-0 as a boxer taking on the man many believe is the best of his era. Getting fans to cough up that price again with less of a guarantee of fireworks is going to be a tough sell, even if the salesman is \"The Notorious.\"\n\nEven Mayweather has seen the need to address the issue, speaking to ESPN in an exclusive interview in which he states he will push the action against McGregor to make it an exciting fight. He even states that he feels the obligation to do so for those who criticized the Pacquiao fight.\n\nIn the last week, promotion has hit more of a frenzy. The dissolution of the partnership between McGregor and former two-weight champion Paul Malignaggi has led to the now exaggeratedly discussed video of the apparent knockdown. While the story has played out like a reality show, it has all been in favor of McGregor. Fans and professionals alike are declaring the exchange in question a knockdown, which boils down to more faith in McGregor's boxing skills at the end of the day.\n\nFinally, the undercard has been released for the super card. Unlike the bout with Pacquiao which featured only two other televised fights beside the main event, this card features several matches involving several of the top up-and-coming stars in boxing. While fans will certainly appreciate more boxing for their hard earned money, it is yet to be seen what impact it will have when it comes time to buy the fight.\n\nThe final factor may well be timing. The UFC is coming off an incredible July in which they put on their annual Independence Day weekend event and the stacked UFC 214 super card. Just three weeks after Mayweather vs McGregor will be Canelo vs Golovkin. With mixed expectations for McGregor's boxing debut, will fans have decided to invest their money on a safer event by the time the summer is over?\n\nThe fight has been projected to do historic numbers, breaking the Mayweather vs Pacquiao record and setting a new precedent for what a constitutes a super fight in the modern era. The question will be, can McGregor inspire enough confidence to get fans to shell out that much money for PPV? It is far easier to have faith that \"The Notorious\" will find a way to catch the boxing legend with a powerful shot than to think that Mayweather will miss a step for the first time in 50 fights. If there is any fighter who can inspire that kind of belief in a fan base to spend that much money, it is McGregor. Will he be able to get a historic number of fans to tune in, however, is the real question.", "id": "9525705", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Will Mayweather vs. McGregor Be Able to My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\"\n\nThe fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite scepticism about how competitive it will be.\n\nMayweather, a master defensive technician and tactician, is heavily favoured to win the Aug. 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said that, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather.\n\n\"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 21 years ago. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. Mayweather is regarded as one of the greatest defensive boxers of all-time and has never been beaten in his storied 21-year career, while McGregor has never boxed professionally.\n\nPundits and fans seem united in the belief that McGregor's only chance of winning is by way of knockout early into the fight, but the confident Irishman has said he is more interested in winning on points in a result that would send shockwaves around the world.\n\nRead more Explained: Why Mayweather wanted to fight McGregor in 8oz gloves\n\n\"Now the gloves are 8oz, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" McGregor said in a conference call on Wednesday.\n\n\"(But) part of me is hoping that maybe he can last... part of me wants to show some skill and to dismantle him. We are ready for absolutely every scenario. I am ready to go to war for the full 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away in the first 10 seconds.\"\n\nMcGregor also again dismissed any notion that there is a racial element to next weekend's fight; the August 26 promotional tour had concluded with Mayweather accusing him of racism on stage at Wembley Arena.\n\nConor McGregor's most memorable quotes 15 show all Conor McGregor's most memorable quotes 1/15 McGregor on...\n\n... staying humble.\n\nGetty\n\n2/15 McGregor on...\n\n... how he chose to make an honest living.\n\nGetty Images\n\n3/15 McGregor on...\n\n... why he doesn't watch Britain's Got Talent.\n\nGetty Images\n\n4/15 McGregor on...\n\n... bums, and selflessly transforming their respective bum lives.\n\nGetty Images\n\n5/15 McGregor on...\n\n... the exceptionally dangerous solid gold pocket watch industry. {"timeCrawl": "18:37:00", "uri": "710485466", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:37:00Z", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4796846/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "And the Welshman claims his bout with Jack 'could be the real fight of the night'\n\nNathan Cleverly believes his world title clash with Badou Jack could prove the 'real fight' of a 'freak event' topped by Floyd Mayweather's showdown with Conor McGregor.\n\nThe Welshman will defend his WBA light-heavyweight title against Jack, 33, on the undercard of the money-spinning Las Vegas fight on August 26.\n\nUnlike the headline fight, in which McGregor will make his professional boxing debut against the most dominant fighter of his generation, Cleverly-Jack is a meeting of two established world level fighters.\n\nNathan Cleverly claims Floyd Mayweather's fight with Conor McGregor is a 'fantasy' fight\n\nThe Welshman will take on Badou Jack (right) on the undercard of the August 26 showdown\n\nMayweather is the heavy favourite to beat McGregor, who will be making his debut in the ring\n\nJack is stepping up to 175lbs for the clash, having vacated his world super-middleweight title following his draw with Britain's James DeGale in January. Cleverly, meanwhile, will be defending his title for the first time since wrestling it off Juergen Braehmer in October 2016.\n\nAnd with many predicting a one-sided contest between Mayweather and McGregor, the Welshman is confident he and Jack can steal the show.\n\n'It's one of these once in a blue moon fantasy fights, Mayweather-McGregor. It's captured the public's imagination,' he said.\n\n'As chief support you have a real, real fight between me and Jack, two genuine world class operators putting it on the line. This could be the real fight of the night, I'm looking to capitalise on that,' he added\n\n'It's a bonus that this fight is part of this show, the way it has all worked out it is a tremendous opportunity.'\n\nJack, who fights under the banner of Mayweather promotions, rose to the top of the 168lb division by beating the likes of Britain's George Groves before his pulsating draw with DeGale.\n\nCleverly will be making his first defence of the world title he won by beating Juergen Braehmer\n\nJack, 33, rose to the top of the 168lb division with wins over the likes of George Groves\n\nCleverly revealed, however, that he has not turned to his compatriots for advice, claiming: 'Regardless of any advice or what anyone tells me, it's down to me.'\n\nAnd though his clash with with Jack will play second-fiddle to Mayweather-McGregor on the night, the 30-year-old admits that no other fight has provided him such a platform to break into the elite level of the sport.\n\n'Every fight is big because each fight is important in its own right,' Cleverly said.\n\n'(But) on an exposure level...this fight is exceptionally important and (in) helping me break through to elite level, it is the most important fight.'\n\nCleverly is confident that he will emerge victorious at the T-Mobile Arena and the Welshman is in little doubt, too, that fellow boxer Mayweather will beat McGregor in the night's headline fight.\n\nAnd though he admits that the Irishman does not 'deserve' a shot at the biggest name in boxing, he paid tribute to the two fighters for putting themselves in a position to cash in on this 'one-off' event.\n\nCleverly fully expects Mayweather to beat McGregor. 'He's too good,' the 30-year-old said\n\nThe Welshman also claimed that the Irish UFC star does not 'deserve' to fight Mayweather\n\n'I don't believe there is any way of an upset, I believe Mayweather is too good, he has perfected his art and craft meticulously, he's too good to allow someone like McGregor to capitalise,' Cleverly said.\n\n'But in regards to McGregor making the fight happen, well done to the guy and best of luck to them because to make it happen they have to put themselves in that position and to put themselves in that position takes a lot of hard work, years of work.\n\n'Mayweather is rightfully so in that pinnacle position of boxing - he deserves it - and McGregor is in that pinnacle position of UFC fighting. Does he deserve the opportunity in boxing? No. But can you blame him for making it happen and combining with Mayweather to make it happen? No you can't blame him.\n\n'Fair play to the guys for the work they put in the gym and outside the gym for capturing the public's imagination and making this a one-off freak event.'\n\nSky Sports Box Office will show Mayweather v McGregor exclusively live on 26 August. He has some links to MMA. His wife is an MMA judge.\"\n\nMoving onto Mayweather, the man who will be standing on the opposite side of the ring trying to knock him off his perch, McGregor isn't intimidated by stepping into his opponent's world to determine the better fighter.\n\n\"I do not care about his record,\" he said, per Rafael. \"I do not care about his achievements.\"\n\nIn addition to not caring about Mayweather's record or achievements, McGregor laid into anyone who doesn't believe his ability will translate to boxing.\n\n\"The disregard and disrespect of my skillset, their minds are closed,\" said McGregor, via MMA Fighting. \"I look forward to going in and educating.\"\n\nAddressing his normal day job as a UFC fighter, McGregor said he still believes himself to be both the promotion's featherweight and lightweight champion. He was the first person in UFC history to hold two titles simultaneously after beating Eddie Alvarez for the lightweight belt last November.\n\nHowever, as a result of his inactivity in the division, McGregor was stripped of the featherweight title. He still holds the lightweight title, despite not defending it since his victory over Alvarez.\n\nMcGregor issued a challenge to Mayweather while throwing the undefeated boxing star's own words back sport.\n\nMcGregor lacks the experience and professional training going into the Aug. 26 showdown, but he's doing everything in his power to make sure the world knows he's going into it with his {"timeCrawl": "08:01:00", "uri": "710754331", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T02:42:00Z", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "source": {"title": "Bleacher Report", "uri": "bleacherreport.com", "id": "3199"}, "url": "http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2727203-floyd-mayweather-vs-conor-mcgregor-inside-the-numbers-around-megafight", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "The best boxer of his generation. The most recognizable mixed martial artist in the world.\n\nAn international publicity tour with enough vitriol, insensitivity and contrived, microphone-friendly menace to leave media outlets of all stripes tittering like six-year-olds on a birthday cake high.\n\nLadies and gentlemen, we give you Mayweather-McGregor.\n\nTheir Aug. 26 get-together seems destined to stretch the outer limits of internet capacity, and there is no shortage of numbers to pore over while preparing for the circus.\n\nWe've assembled a batch of the best ones here. So sit back, relax and get yourself ready for the fun.\n\n0: In case you're unaware, it's the number of times McGregor, on the verge of facing a consensus all-time great, has stepped into a ring for an officially sanctioned amateur or professional boxing match. He has, however, had 24 mixed martial arts matches, winning 21 and scoring 18 stoppages.\n\n5: Number of professional weight classes in which Mayweather, who began punching for pay at age 19, has won sanctioned world championships. He earned his first belt, at 130 pounds, in 1998, and has since added jewelry at 135 (2002), 140 (2005), 147 (2006) and 154 (2007).\n\n50-0: The pro record Mayweather would reach with a win, eclipsing the 49-0 mark established by heavyweight champion Rocky Marciano between 1947 and 1955. No other widely recognized world champion has retired with a better record with zero losses and zero draws.\n\nTMT50 and TBE50: The trademarks applied for by Mayweather Productions with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, per ESPN.com. TMT is short for \"The Money Team,\" while TBE stands for \"The Best Ever.\"\n\n19.5 million: The number of buys Mayweather has helped generate as a pay-per-view fighter, including the three most-purchased bouts in history -- 2.4 million against Oscar De La Hoya in 2007, 2.2 million against Canelo Alvarez in 2013 and 4.6 million against Manny Pacquiao in 2015.\n\n$600 million: The total projected gross revenue for the bout, according to ESPN's Darren Rovell, which would place it second only to the aforementioned Mayweather-Pacquiao show two years ago.\n\n$235: The proceeds of the public assistance check cashed by McGregor, according to Yahoo Sports, shortly before his UFC debut in 2013.\n\n$4.8 million: The price tag for the rare luxury car, a Koenigsegg CCXR Trevita, that Mayweather added to his collection in 2015, per Rolling Stone. The magazine said the ride maxes out at 254 mph and goes from 0 to 60 in 2.9 seconds.\n\n154 pounds: The agreed-upon weight for the Aug. 26 fight. Mayweather, most recently a full-time welterweight, has previously ventured into the junior middleweight for defeats of De La Hoya, Alvarez and Miguel Cotto. His heaviest weigh-in number was 151 pounds against Cotto. McGregor, meanwhile, fought at a 170-pound limit for a stoppage loss against substitute opponent Nate Diaz in 2016.\n\n11, 1 and 2: The chronological and statutory advantages -- in age (29 to Mayweather's 40), height (5'9\" to Mayweather's 5'8\") and reach (74 inches to Mayweather's 72) -- that McGregor will have when he enters the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n2,170 days: The length of time, come fight night, that will have elapsed since Mayweather last scored an inside-the-distance victory, via fourth-round KO against Victor Ortiz.\n\n13 seconds: The amount of time it took McGregor to stop Jose Aldo for his signature UFC win, capturing the organization's featherweight (145 pounds) championship in December 2015. He's since picked up the UFC lightweight (155 pounds) belt as well.\n\n22 seconds: Duration of the sparring video released by the UFC showing McGregor working with former two-division world champion Paulie Malignaggi. Malignaggi has since left the McGregor camp and claimed on social media that the clip, including what McGregor labeled a knockdown, wasn't at all representative of the 36 total minutes of sparring.\n\n$150: The wager, according to OddsShark, required to make a $100 profit on a Mayweather victory against McGregor inside the 12-round distance. A Mayweather win by decision, incidentally, would yield $230 for a $100 bet.\n\n$325: The profit available for a $100 bet on McGregor, again according to OddsShark, in the event the Irishman pulls off the upset. For comparison's sake, that profit number was at $950 when the fight was first rumored last fall.", "id": "9637446", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Floyd Mayweather vs. Conor McGregor: There's no guarantee that he will step up his training at this point, because it's clear that he will prepare in the manner that he sees fit and doesn't care what others think.\n\n\"I am going to do exactly what I want to do,\" Mayweather said in a previous episode. \"Nobody is going to tell me what to do.\"\n\nThe ongoing saga between McGregor and Showtime boxing analyst Paulie Malignaggi is likely to play out further. In each of the last two episodes, McGregor and Malignaggi have sparred to help the UFC lightweight champ prepare for Mayweather. The Showtime cameras were turned off for the sparring sessions, but McGregor has said he has gotten the best of the former fighter.\n\nMcGregor claimed in an interview with MMA Fighting's Ariel Helwani that his most recent sparring session was a 12-round fight and that he won each round. Malignaggi has dismissed the claim on The MMA Hour podcast and has asked for the tape for all 12 rounds to be released.\n\nWhile that has not happened, a small snippet of Malignaggi going down to the canvas has found its way to the public. Even that is controversial, because Malignaggi says that his tumble is the result of a shove and not a punch.\n\nIn any event, it is clear that McGregor has used his time to train in a much more serious manner than Mayweather. He knows he has a huge opportunity coming up in a little over a week, and he is trying to prepare as best he can for the first official boxing match of his career.\n\nMayweather is taking his 49-0 record into the ring, and while he has not competed in two years, his defensive skills are not likely to have waned. While he may not be as quick as he was in his prime, it's difficult to conceive of McGregor gaining enough skill to challenge him successfully.\n\nThe countdown to the megafight is starting to reach The lighter gloves have less padding over the knuckles and are believed to favour the heavier puncher.\n\nEarlier in August, the NAC, who sanctioned the contest, told BBC Sport they could not recall a fight at 154lbs ever being given dispensation to make such a move.\n\nMcGregor typically uses 4oz fingerless gloves in MMA, while undefeated boxer Mayweather has used 8oz gloves in 46 of his 49 bouts.\n\n'Not welcome in boxing'\n\nIn a lengthy conference call, McGregor took questions from journalists around the world just 10 days before he makes his boxing debut in Las Vegas against former five-weight world champion Mayweather, 40.\n\nHe revealed he has been conducting \"scary\" training sessions at 13,000ft in an altitude chamber and stated he feels in \"absolutely amazing\" condition for the T-Mobile Arena bout.\n\nBut the UFC lightweight champion believes he has been \"discarded\" by boxing analysts and made to feel \"not welcome\" in the build-up to what could be the richest fight in history.\n\n\"It's certainly motivating - the disrespect and disregard for my skillset,\" added McGregor. \"I look at people sometimes and their mind is closed.\n\n\"Fighting is a complex game. I look forward to going back and continuing where I left off.\"\n\nMcGregor said Mayweather would get his \"respect\" if he followed through on comments made on a US talk show this week in which he said the pair could rematch under MMA rules.\n\nPaulie Malignaggi - who quit as McGregor's sparring partner after reacting angrily to images appearing to show him knocked down in a session - has also raised the prospect of coming out of retirement to box the Irishman.\n\n\"Tell him to shut his mouth and join the queue,\" McGregor said when asked about facing the former two-weight world champion.\n\n\"He got whooped and went sprinting. {"timeCrawl": "08:56:00", "uri": "711343574", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T08:56:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"title": "Cyprus Mail", "uri": "cyprus-mail.com", "id": "2441"}, "url": "http://cyprus-mail.com/2017/08/18/mayweather-putting-legacy-line-worth/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "Floyd Mayweather Jr. of the US makes his way through a gym crowded with members of the media during a workout at the Mayweather Boxing Club in Las Vegas\n\nWith his superfight against Conor McGregor a little over a week away, Floyd Mayweather struck a reflective tone on Thursday as he discussed the risk of coming out of retirement for a massive payday.\n\nMayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career, while McGregor, who is making his professional boxing debut, is 21-3 in mixed martial arts.\n\n\"When a fighter has lost before, if he loses again they say 'oh, it's nothing, he's lost before,'\"Mayweather told a conference call. \"But when a fighter has been dominating for 20-some years and never lost, everything is on the line.\n\n\"My legacy. My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\"\n\nThe fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite scepticism about how competitive it will be.\n\nMayweather, a master defensive technician and tactician, is heavily favoured to win the Aug 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said that, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather.\n\n\"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\n\"But I still have a high IQ in that ring. {"timeCrawl": "02:15:00", "uri": "710638301", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T22:34:00Z", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "source": {"title": "Yahoo Sports", "uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "id": "2139"}, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mcgregor-vows-fast-finish-against-mayweather-003450123--box.html", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "Los Angeles (AFP) - Conor McGregor believes he will knock out Floyd Mayweather inside two rounds but is ready for all scenarios when the two fighters clash in their eagerly anticipated superfight next week.\n\nIrish mixed martial arts star McGregor told reporters on a conference call on Wednesday that a controversial switch to lighter gloves could lead to an explosive outcome in the August 26 showdown in Las Vegas.\n\nMcGregor, who is widely seen as a massive underdog against undefeated former welterweight king Mayweather, predicted an early finish to the fight.\n\n\"Particularly with the eight-ounce gloves, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" said McGregor, nevertheless expressing the hope that the fight would last longer.\n\n\"I don't want people saying 'Oh, it was a lucky punch' and all that. Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way.\n\n\"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a grueling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\"\n\nUlimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\n- 'Hits like a truck' -\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves helps him big time. I think it absolutely does.\"\n\nMcGregor and Mayweather will climb into the ring following an international publicity tour last month marked by expletive-laden tirades and trash-talking.\n\nMcGregor, who was criticized for addressing Mayweather as \"boy\" during one event, dismissed suggestions that there was a racially tinged dimension to the duel.\n\n\"For me, it's athlete versus athlete,\" McGregor said. \"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's being portrayed. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. It's a set way and there is no other way. Well, if that was the case we would have never reached across the oceans in search of other lands. We would never have gone into space.\n\n\"You have to have an open mind and you got to realize that there are other ways. Fighting is a complex game. On the call, White said that the fight is tracking to be the biggest ever on pay-per-view.\n\nMayweather's 2016 fight with Manny Pacquiao set a record with 4.6 million pay-per-view buys. That fight included two of the biggest names in boxing and finally brought together two fighters the fans had been dying to see face each other in the ring for years. McGregor comes from a different sport and has a massive fan base, so when you combine his drawing power in MMA with Floyd's in boxing, it's no surprise that this thing could do five million buys.\n\nThe fight also received an interesting twist on Wednesday when the Nevada Athletic Commission voted unanimously to allow the two men to box in 8-ounce gloves.\n\nThe state's typical rules necessitate 10-ounce gloves for fights taking place at 147 pounds or above. Mayweather and McGregor are fighting at a weight limit of 154 pounds, but they petitioned the commission for a waiver to allow them to fight with the 8-ounce gloves. The commission approved the one-time waiver via a 5-0 vote on Wednesday.\n\nFinancial terms of the fight have not been disclosed. My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\"\n\nThe fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite scepticism about how competitive it will be.\n\nMayweather, a master defensive technician and tactician, is heavily favoured to win the Aug. 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said that, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather.\n\n\"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 21 years ago. Of course not,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 10 years ago. I'm, not even the same Floyd Mayweather that I was I was five or two years ago.\n\n\"But I still have a high IQ in that ring. Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way.\n\n\"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a grueling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\" Ulimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves helps him big time. I think it absolutely does.\" McGregor and Mayweather will climb into the ring following an international publicity tour last month marked by expletive-laden tirades and trash-talking.\n\nMcGregor, who was criticized for addressing Mayweather as \"boy\" during one event, dismissed suggestions that there was a racially tinged dimension to the duel.\n\n\"For me, it's athlete versus athlete,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's being portrayed. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. It's a set way and there is no other way. Well, if that was the case we would have never reached across the oceans in search of other lands. We would never have gone into space.\n\n\"You have to have an open mind and you got to realize that there are other ways. Fighting is a complex game. But I'm just looking forward to August 26 and proving what I'm saying and educating the world of what martial arts is.\"\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is {"timeCrawl": "02:04:00", "uri": "710635569", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T02:04:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "TODAY", "uri": "todayonline.com", "id": "1197"}, "url": "http://www.todayonline.com/sports/boxing-mcgregor-vows-fast-finish-against-mayweather", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "LOS ANGELES -- Conor McGregor believes he will knock out Floyd Mayweather inside two rounds but is ready for all scenarios when the two fighters clash in their eagerly anticipated superfight next week.\n\nIrish mixed martial arts star McGregor told reporters on a conference call on Wednesday (Aug 16) that a controversial switch to lighter gloves could lead to an explosive outcome in the August 26 showdown in Las Vegas.\n\nMcGregor, who is widely seen as a massive underdog against undefeated former welterweight king Mayweather, predicted an early finish to the fight.\n\n\"Particularly with the eight-ounce gloves, I don't believe he makes it out of the second round,\" said McGregor, nevertheless expressing the hope that the fight would last longer.\n\n\"I don't want people saying 'Oh, it was a lucky punch' and all that. Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way.\n\n\"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a gruelling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\"\n\nUlimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\n'HITS LIKE A TRUCK'\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves helps him big time. I think it absolutely does.\"\n\nMcGregor and Mayweather will climb into the ring following an international publicity tour last month marked by expletive-laden tirades and trash-talking.\n\nMcGregor, who was criticised for addressing Mayweather as \"boy\" during one event, dismissed suggestions that there was a racially tinged dimension to the duel.\n\n\"For me, it's athlete versus athlete,\" McGregor said. \"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's being portrayed. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. It's a set way and there is no other way. Well, if that was the case we would have never reached across the oceans in search of other lands. We would never have gone into space.\n\n\"You have to have an open mind and you got to realize that there are other ways. Fighting is a complex game. But I'm just looking forward to August 26 and proving what I'm saying and educating the world of what martial arts is.\" AFP", "id": "9596610", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Boxing: {"timeCrawl": "01:25:00", "uri": "711196159", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:25:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "SBS", "uri": "sbs.com.au", "id": "793"}, "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/18/mayweather-puts-legacy-line", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "With his superfight against Conor McGregor a little over a week away, Floyd Mayweather struck a reflective tone on Thursday as he discussed the risk of coming out of retirement for a massive payday.\n\nMayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career, while McGregor, who is making his professional boxing debut, is 21-3 in mixed martial arts.\n\n\"When a fighter has lost before, if he loses again they say 'oh, it's nothing, he's lost before,'\" Mayweather told a conference call. \"But when a fighter has been dominating for 20-some years and never lost, everything is on the line.\n\n\"My legacy. My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\"\n\nThe fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite scepticism about how competitive it will be.\n\nMayweather, a master defensive technician and tactician, is heavily favoured to win the August 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather.\n\n\"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 21 years ago. Of course not,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 10 years ago. I'm, not even the same Floyd Mayweather that I was five or two years ago.\n\n\"But I still have a high IQ in that ring. And experience wise, it leans towards me, period, because I have been in the ring at such a high level for so long.\"", "id": "9804691", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Mayweather puts {"timeCrawl": "10:12:00", "uri": "711376210", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:12:00Z", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "source": {"title": "The Indian Express", "uri": "indianexpress.com", "id": "1155"}, "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/sport-others/its-worth-it-floyd-mayweather-on-putting-legacy-on-the-line-4802556/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "By: Reuters | Published:August 18, 2017 3:02 pm Floyd Mayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime. (Source: AP) Game of Thrones season 7's latest episode has got Twitterati excited for more reasons than oneAishwarya Rai Bachchan steals a million hearts in this white Manish Malhotra suit at IFFMWATCH: Groom enters wedding in a TRACTOR! That's desi swag in Canada\n\nWith his superfight against Conor McGregor a little over a week away, Floyd Mayweather struck a reflective tone on Thursday as he discussed the risk of coming out of retirement for a massive payday.\n\nMayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career, while McGregor, who is making his professional boxing debut, is 21-3 in mixed martial arts.\n\n\"When a fighter has lost before, if he loses again they say 'oh, it's nothing, he's lost before,'\" Mayweather told a conference call. \"But when a fighter has been dominating for 20-some years and never lost, everything is on the line.\n\n\"My legacy. My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\" The fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite skepticism about how competitive it will be.\n\nMayweather, a master defensive technician, and tactician is heavily favoured to win the Aug. 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said that, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather.\n\n\"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 21 years ago. Of course not,\" he said. \"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 10 years ago. I'm, not even the same Floyd Mayweather that I was I was five or two years ago.\n\n\"But I still have a high IQ in that ring. {"timeCrawl": "09:29:00", "uri": "711358335", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:01:00Z", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "source": {"title": "FanSided", "uri": "fansided.com", "id": "8632"}, "url": "https://fansided.com/2017/08/17/floyd-mayweather-will-capitalize-on-moment-enter-fitness-industry/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "Floyd Mayweather has a big fight ahead of him against Conor McGregor, but what he has lined up for after the fight might prove to be an even greater challenge.\n\nAfter Floyd Mayweather faces Conor McGregor, he is going to face the rigors of building a business in the competitive fitness industry centered around his success as a boxer.\n\nAccording to Scott Gleeson of USA Today Sports, Mayweather plans to open his first self-branded fitness club in Southern California during November. That is just the beginning for Mayweather's plans, however.\n\nMayweather wants to open similar clubs around the world, focusing on areas where such facilities are least likely to exist due to economic or other logistical difficulties. The global strategy for Mayweather's fitness business includes more than just providing places to work out. Mayweather also plans to invade the training space as well.\n\nJust as Mayweather wants his fitness clubs to have a global presence, he intends to use technology to train individuals around the world. Forming exercise regimens which mimic his own, Mayweather will disseminate content in which he takes customers through the workouts using a mobile application and virtual reality tech.\n\nEntering the fitness industry is in and of itself an ambitious task. Not only is the business crowded, but there is very little which any single entity can claim as proprietary. In order to grab any market share, much less one the size that Mayweather is eyeing, it will take enormous resources and a strong brand identity.\n\nFortunately, Mayweather has a strong brand identity and enormous resources. On top of his status as a world-class athlete that is instantly recognizable, his estimated net worth sits at $340 million.\n\nThe brand and financial power of Mayweather will be even stronger after the fight with McGregor, especially if he claims victory. Mayweather stands to make at least $100 million but up to $400 million from the fight. That money can go a long way toward establishing Mayweather's mobile app, virtual reality content and fitness clubs.\n\nIf there ever was a time that would be appropriate for Mayweather to launch this {"timeCrawl": "17:05:00", "uri": "711011857", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:24:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "FanSided", "uri": "fansided.com", "id": "8632"}, "url": "https://fansided.com/2017/08/17/floyd-mayweather-vs-conor-mcgregor-beginners-guide-hot-takes/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "On Saturday night, Aug. 26, Floyd Mayweather will take on the UFC lightweight champion Conor McGregor in a highly anticipated boxing match at the T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas, Nevada.\n\nThere have been many articles and conversations in regards to this fight. However, it can be quite difficult discussing it with casual combat sports fans. As will be noted, these fans may not be properly informed about what is happening in the current state of combat sports. While technically nobody is currently incorrect in stating an opinion about this upcoming bout since it hasn't happened yet, you seem to get the same answers from fans who aren't dialed into, not only the current state, but also, the history of boxing, and Floyd Mayweather's career in general.\n\nFrom listening and engaging in conversations with these fans, we have chosen the top-9 most frequently used takes as it relates to the bout between Mayweather and McGregor.\n\nAnother choice that was taken into consideration is the trash-talking aspect between the two. Since we were able to see it play out during the four city, three country world tour, that aspect of this list has been omitted.\n\nThis is more of an educational guideline for the casual sports fan. We have assembled a panel of experts from multiple aspects of the fight world, which includes coaches, journalists, broadcasters, boxing and Mayweather enthusiasts, professional boxers, who have also made the transition to MMA, as well as active fighters in the UFC. The panel has been asked about each individual hot take and have responded to it as they see fit.\n\nHere is the panel:\n\nAna Julaton: Professional boxer (14-4, 1 draw), former WBO Super Bantamweight World Champion, IBA Super Bantamweight World Champion\n\nONE Championship women's flyweight (2-2)\n\nAngelo Reyes: Boxing Coach of former UFC heavyweight champion Frank Mir, and others since coming from the boxing world where he has developed world champions under the guidance of Freddie Roach.\n\nBlake Stephenson: Floyd Mayweather expert, Host of The Loaded Joe's MMA and LoudMouth Boxing podcasts\n\nHeather Hardy: Professional boxer (20-0), WBC International Female Flyweight Champion\n\nRay Flores: Ring announcer for Premier Boxing Champions, hosted the London, England stop of the Mayweather-McGregor world tour\n\nOn June 15, 2017, Max Kellerman and Stephen A. Smith debated the fight between Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor on ESPN's First Take. While Kellerman also stated that Mayweather would not fare well in the MMA world, he told the world that Conor McGregor \"had zero chance in this fight.\"\n\nWhat really made headlines was Kellerman stating that \"Conor McGregor will not land a single punch against Floyd Mayweather.\" Since Kellerman made that bold prediction, casual fans, when discussing this fight, have gone to what Kellerman said on ESPN back in June as a reason why Mayweather will defeat McGregor on Aug. 26.\n\nHere is how the panel responded to the No.9 casual fan hot take:\n\nAna Julaton: It doesn't happen in boxing. In boxing, you have to know that you're going to get hit. I mean it's just part of the game. Floyd's going to get hit and that's what makes him such a warrior. He knows he's going to get hit. He just knows exactly who he is. He knows what his strengths are, what his weaknesses are, and with that, he knows how to disarm his opponents.\n\nI don't necessarily agree with Max Kellerman 100 percent. I don't know if he has practiced boxing, but getting into a live fight where you don't have the face mask, you're going up against time and you get someone who's trained to just take your head off, it's different. It's a different arena altogether. So yeah, it's going to be a fight. Floyd himself said that he's expecting Conor to just come right at him.\n\nAngelo Reyes: I disagree. I do believe that Floyd will dominate him. I know where Max Kellerman was coming from, and Max is great. I have nothing bad to say about Max. I think what Max was trying to explain was, he doesn't believe Conor will land a significant punch. George Foreman has said this in the past, the better the boxing match is, the less people will actually appreciate it. It's like an art piece. When you look at a piece of art, and let's say it's worth a million dollars, if you're not in the art world and understand the artistry of it, you won't understand why it's worth a million dollars. I think this is Max Kellerman saying to himself, as an artist in this world of boxing, I can't possibly see Conor McGregor understanding this boxing painting. That's what he meant when he said he won't land a single punch against Floyd. Of course, he's trying to get the headline, but I understand what he's actually saying.\n\nManny Pacquiao is amazing, he's a legend. If he had a hard time catching up to Floyd, then how can Conor, who's never boxed in a professional setting, have an easier time doing it to Floyd?\n\nBlake Stephenson: Exaggeration without thought. That's why he went back on it and was like, \"yeah he will land, but not much.\"\n\nHeather Hardy: OK, I don't think that's true. I think that he won't punch a lot, but I do believe that he's going to be a little bit awkward and it might take Mayweather a round or so to adjust. Not that I don't fully believe that Mayweather will adjust, but I do think it might take him a punch or two.\n\nJose Youngs: Foolish. That's the only way to describe Kellerman's comments. Now don't get me wrong, I firmly believe Kellerman is one of, if the not the best boxing commentators in the business. But saying McGregor will land ZERO punches after 12-rounds of action is a little absurd. Honestly, I doubt Kellerman even believes this.\n\nNot taking into account McGregor could trip and accidentally punch Mayweather, the Irishman's longer reach and accuracy will undoubtedly lead to a bruise or two plastered across his opponent's face.\n\nIs Mayweather the greatest defensive boxers of our lifetime? Yes. Will he avoid over 100 punches in 12 rounds? Probably not. Does landing a handful of punches mean McGregor will win? Absolutely not.\n\nSorry Max.\n\nRay Flores: I don't think that's the case. I think that he is going to be able to connect at least once and Conor better make that punch count because that's the only time he is going to touch Floyd. At some point over the first three or four rounds, Conor, just based on the size, his explosiveness and his athletic abilities, will find a way to connect against Floyd. He better make that shot count.\n\nShane Burgos: He will definitely land a single punch. Most definitely land at least one punch, it's almost impossible for him not to land a punch. At least a body shot, I mean the head is a little harder to hit because Floyd is really good at moving the head. C'mon, let's be real now. He's going to land a shot, more than one. He said it like he is dead serious too. If that actually happens, props to that guy.\n\nZak Ottow: I can see rounds where he may not land anything clean, but I see this fight going for several rounds. Over the course of several rounds, I wouldn't be surprised if McGregor lands some clean shots, just because of the mirrored stance that they like to be in, and the fact that Mayweather does like to burst out with those quick cross darts, and I think McGregor can fade out on those and try to bang that left hand, like he likes to do. To say he won't land anything the whole fight, I don't agree with that.", "id": "9740039", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Floyd Mayweather vs. Conor McGregor: A beginner's guide to hot {"timeCrawl": "19:48:00", "uri": "711082770", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:11:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"title": "LowKick MMA", "uri": "lowkickmma.com", "id": "15129"}, "url": "http://www.lowkickmma.com/UFC/conor-mcgregor-predicts-first-round-finish-over-floyd-mayweather/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "Conor McGregor once said that he's 'cocky' in prediction, and that trend has seemed to continue ahead of his Aug. 26 boxing match with the legendary Floyd Mayweather.\n\nDespite the fact that he has never competed in a professional boxing match, McGregor has previously predicted that he'll stop the undefeated Mayweather within four rounds. With the Nevada State Athletic Commission (NSAC) changing the glove size from 10 oz. to 8 oz, however, McGregor doesn't believe \"Money\" will 'exit the first round':\n\n\"I said four, but that's me being humble,\" the UFC lightweight champion told Conan O'Brien. \"I don't believe he will even exit the first round, but I'm trying to be humble on national TV. So I say four -- inside four.\"\n\nIn addition to his patented power, McGregor feels as if his movement will serve as something Mayweather has never seen before:\n\n\"I think the styles of opponents that Floyd has faced have moved in a certain way,\" McGregor said. \"The boxing game is almost set in its way, I feel. Their feet are flat. They have no spring in and out. Compare that with a mixed martial artist, they can bounce in and out at a fast tempo. So I believe I will paint pictures in there that he has never seen or the boxing community has never seen before and that will cause him big trouble.\n\n\"Factor that in with the precision and the punching power -- it only takes me one shot. I've KO'd men inside three seconds. I won the UFC title in 13 seconds. The request was approved by including Italy's Guido Cavalleri.\n\n\"Otherwise I would have used an out-of-state judge,\" Bennett said. \"Mr. Cavalleri has travelled the world, from Japan to Madison Square Garden, and performed exceptionally.\"\n\nThe NSAC also changed their own rules to allow Mayweather and McGregor to wear 8oz gloves, rather than the 10oz gloves that were previously mandatory in the 154lbs division.\n\nBennett explained: \"Conor is used to fighting in 4oz gloves. Floyd typically fights in 8oz gloves with three exceptions - 'Canelo', Miguel Cotto and Oscar De La Hoya - because he usually fights at welterweight [147lbs].\n\n\"We evaluated our regulations and decided it was in the best interest of the fighters and the fans to deviate for one-time only.\n\n\"This is a one-time waiver with the caveat that the gloves must be inspected, which is standard procedure. The original pair must then be returned to the commission after the fight for our inspection.\"\n\nAsked about safety concerns with the smaller gloves, Bennett said: \"We initiated a study to see if there is a significant difference between 8oz and 10oz gloves. This study was not completed. We will proceed with the review.\n\n\"A one-time exception, while we continue this study, is applicable because you could argue that it's beneficial to each fighter.\"\n\nWatch Mayweather vs McGregor, from the T-Mobile Arena, Las Vegas, from midnight August 26, live on Sky Sports Box Office. But I don't see him absorbing the blows in the first two rounds.\"\n\nMcGregor was reminded that 46 of Mayweather's 49 fights have been contested in 8oz gloves, but the UFC champion said: \"That doesn't bother me. He has some links to mixed martial arts - his wife Adelaide Byrd is [a UFC judge].\n\n\"We were hoping for someone with links to MMA.\n\n\"They gave us options. We didn't necessarily ask for any referee in particular. There was a referee that gave an opinion which made it very hard for them to be considered.\n\n\"Tony Weeks was a consideration. We'd have never gone into space. You've got to have an open mind and realise that there are other ways.\n\n\"Fighting is a complex game - there is a time and a place for every attack, and every move. {"timeCrawl": "01:59:00", "uri": "710633940", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T00:54:00Z", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "source": {"title": "Fox Sports", "uri": "foxsports.com.au", "id": "5024"}, "url": "http://www.foxsports.com.au/boxing/mcgregor-vs-mayweather/conor-mcgregors-former-sparring-partner-unleashes-on-the-ufc-stars-cultlike-fanbase/news-story/9a8e0b1a220b25d714be86d71c184d1f", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "IT'S the sideshow to the main show but aggrieved Conor McGregor sparring partner Paulie Malignaggi has managed to steal a week's worth of headlines.\n\nAnd he's not done yet.\n\nThe 36-year-old New Yorker has unloaded on the UFC star, his camp, his millions of fans and Dana White ahead of the hugely anticipated fight.\n\nMeanwhile, the ongoing debate over which gloves should be allowed for the August 27th showdown is over -- and the big bucks have begun rolling in for the money man, Floyd Mayweather Jr.\n\nTHE CULT OF CONOR\n\nFormer super lightweight and welterweight world champion Malignaggi is furious at the McGregor camp, over his treatment after being invited into camp to spar.\n\nMaglignaggi took shots at McGregor's \"cult-like\" fans and the McGregor camp for allegedly misrepresenting their 12 rounds of sparring.\n\nMaglignaggi told Yahoo Sports that any suggestion he copped \"a beating\", as claimed by McGregor's camp, was far from the truth.\n\nUFC chief Dana White -- firmly in McGregor's corner -- released footage on his Twitter account of the Irish hero knocking Maglignaggi down with a left hook.\n\nTo Maglignaggi, the footage shows a push which he says came in the 12th round when he was completely spent. To White, McGregor and his legion of fans, it shows the fighter's awesome power and knockdown ability.\n\nMcGregor KO's former champion\n\n0:18\n\n\"What they're doing is so adorable and so cute,\" Malignaggi told Yahoo Sports.\n\n\"They're trying all these sales tactics. His fan base is adorable and cute, because they're jumping all over it. Everything they say, they're jumping all over it. They're so happy to hear this news that he's supposedly doing great and the video shows this and that's how it is.\n\n\"I've never seen such a cult-like following to the point where people are in denial and where the fighter himself doesn't even believe in himself to that point he's putting out this fake stuff. He's afraid the real stuff won't convince anybody.\n\n\"This entire thing, he's like the little engine that could. He's like this adorable guy trying so hard to look like Hercules. He knows nobody believes in him and he's trying so hard to get people to believe and his minions are trying so hard that they believe anything he says. Dana is the little ringleader.\"\n\nMalignaggi reserved a sensational character assassination for White.\n\n\"Dana being the fake guy that he is, he tried to come up to me and say, 'Hey man, good work,'\" Malignaggi said. \"I just brushed him off because he's not somebody I like.\n\n\"I don't like the way he runs his business. I don't like the way he screws the fighters. I don't like the fact he's trying to prevent the Muhammad Ali Act from being included in mixed martial arts. I don't like him as a person. I don't like what he stands for and I don't like anything about him.\n\n\"So when he tried to talk to me after the sparring, I kind of brushed him off anyway. The fact he put out the video, I think he got a lot of pleasure out of that, the whole editing and putting it out, because he didn't like how I brushed him off to begin with.\"\n\nI'LL PAY YOUR BETS\n\nFloyd Mayweather Jr. is well known for outlaying ridiculous money on bets on everything: notably basketball and American football, both college and professional in both cases.\n\nBut next weekend, he's going to be betting on himself.\n\nDon't worry -- unlike in most of the world, where betting on your own fight or team would be a punishable offence -- it's perfectly legal in Las Vegas, Nevada, where the superfight is taking place.\n\nMayweather confirmed his betting plans in an interview on Jimmy Kimmel Live on Wednesday.\n\nKimmel: Are you allowed to bet on yourself in this fight?\n\nMayweather: Yes\n\nKimmel: You are... and will you bet on yourself?\n\nMayweather: Yes.\n\nKimmel: You're not allowed to bet against yourself?\n\nMayweather: I'm never going to bet against myself, never.\n\nMayweather then doubled down, saying Kimmel could bet on him freely and without fear, such is his confidence in victory that the 40-year-old boldly claimed he'd cover any bets placed on him by the talk show host.\n\n\"It is worth it, whatever you bet -- if you don't win I will give it back to you. You've got my word,'' Mayweather said before shaking hands on the deal.\n\nI WOULD DO ANYTHING FOR GLOVES\n\nFrom their very first press conference, the debate over which gloves -- and, more specifically, what weight the gloves would be -- has been at the forefront of the baiting between the two fighters.\n\nAnd the fight, on that front at least, is over.\n\nMcGregor is used to fighting in the UFC with 4oz gloves, while typically in boxing heavier gloves are the norm.\n\nMcGregor got on the offensive early and set the tone for the debate, saying that Mayweather was afraid to fight with the lighter gloves.\n\nNot so, said Mr. 49-0 and they've reached an extraordinary agreement to ratify a late switch.\n\nWhite couldn't be happier at the news and believes it will give McGregor an instant advantage against the famously rock-solid Mayweather defence.\n\n\"It definitely benefits Conor,\" he told Sky Sports UK.\n\n\"First of all, Floyd isn't a big puncher, he's not a knockout puncher.\n\n\"His whole game is defence, using the gloves to defend himself, and smaller gloves means Conor will have more places to hit.\n\n\"Conor isn't concerned about Floyd's punching power at all.\"\n\nHowever, not everyone is happy.\n\nThe move certainly didn't have the support of the Association of Ringside Physicians who on Wednesday released a statement categorically stating it doesn't support the push for smaller gloves.\n\n\"Unless there is scientific evidence to support the view that such a change might improve the safety of this bout, we would strongly caution against allowing current regulation to be overruled,\" said the Association's Chairman, Dr Raymond M. Monsell, in a letter to the Nevada State Athletic Commission.\n\n\"To do so would also set a precedent for future bouts.\"\n\nWhoa! Biggest bet in Vegas yet? @VSiNLive pic.twitter.com/Kw4VGDOQPe -- Mitch Moss (@MitchMossRadio)\n\nAugust 11, 2017\n\nFOLLOW THE MONEY\n\nFloyd 'Money' Mayweather is the firm favourite to take down his talkative rival -- but the Las Vegas bookies might need to reel their prices in a touch after this bet.\n\nNotorious billionaires the Maloof brothers -- Joe, Gavin and Phil -- have outlaid an outrageous amount of money on Mayweather to get the job done.\n\nThe brothers -- who previously owned NBA franchise the Sacramento Kings -- dropped a cool $US880,000 ($A1,121,450) in a bid to pocket a further $USD120,000 ($A153,000) and walk away with an even $US1,000,000.\n\n\"McGregor's much younger and he hits hard, but he's going against the best boxer ever,\" said Gavin Maloof, who added that he lives down the street from Mayweather.\n\n\"I just don't see it. The line in Vegas is that the over/under is 4.9m. Everything is tracking right now to say that we're going to kill this thing. It's looking really good.\"\n\nAlthough Mayweather has been used to generating hundreds of millions of dollars from a single fight, this is new territory for White and McGregor - the previous pay-per-view sales record was 1.65m for the Irishman's rematch with Nate Diaz last year.\n\nThat fight marked McGregor's biggest payday to date, pocketing him $3m. In contrast, Mayweather made an estimated $180m from his Pacquio victory.\n\nNevertheless, White said the addition of UFC and its digital sophistication would help drive larger revenues than that 2015 event.\n\n\"This is the biggest event that has ever happened in combat sports,\" said White.\n\n\"It is the most distributed event in pay-per-view history. In the United Kingdom, it is expected that the fight will start between 4-5am on Sunday, August 27 morning.\n\n2) The fight will be a boxing event - not a UFC fight. All rules and regulations will be as they would be for any other professional boxing fight, meaning McGregor will not be allowed to use any of his usual mixed martial arts moves during the Mayweather fight.\n\n3) There is no title belt on the line. Winning this fight will mean much to both fighters and their fans than any title belt in either boxing or the UFC.\n\n4) At the present time, there is no contracted plans for a rematch in a UFC style fight. McGregor and Mayweather have both teased a follow-up battle in the octagon, but it is unlikely Mayweather will agree to a mixed martial arts fight.\n\nWith just a week left until the fight starts, here are some of the best locations in Chelmsford to watch 'The Notorious' Conor McGregor vs Floyd 'Money' Mayweather:\n\nOpening Times: Walkabout will open on Saturday at 11am and remain open all through the night until 6am on the Sunday morning. They will then close until 11am, which is when they'll open for their usual Sunday service.\n\nEntry Prices: Standard tickets for this event will be priced at \u00a310 per person. VIP packages are also available and start at \u00a350 per person. They are available by emailing sales.chelmsford@walkaboutbars.com or calling 01245 806533.\n\nOpening Times: Wheatsheaf will also be staying open until 6am - or 30 minutes after the fight finishes.\n\nEntry Prices: Entry at Wheatsheaf is completely FREE before midnight or \u00a35 if tickets are purchased in advance for after 12am. Ticket prices on the door will be \u00a310 and subject to availability.\n\nOpening Times: The Golden Fleece will stay open all night and will have a live band from 10pm, before a DJ takes over till 2.30am. Seats will then be reserved from 3am.\n\nEntry Prices: There are two options for entry at Golden Fleece. "storyUri": "eng-3366641", "body": "Not only are Floyd Mayweather's hands more brittle and therefore more likely to break with less padding, but McGregor is accustomed to wearing 4oz. gloves in the Octagon and his superior power is at its most devastating when less cushion exists between knuckle and jaw.\n\nAdd to that the fact that a smaller glove translates to more difficulty for Mayweather when it comes to implementing his infamously defensive style and you understand just how beneficial the recent update is to McGregor.\n\nEverything came up 'Notorious' at Wednesday's Nevada State Athletic Commission hearing, where several aspects of the McGregor vs. Mayweather fight were finalised.\n\nThe commission gave the green light to a one-time waiver for fighters at 154lbs to wear 8oz. gloves, rather than the 10oz. gloves that were originally agreed upon and are typically worn by super welterweights.\n\nThe NSAC also assigned judges and the referee for the contest and it could be argued that McGregor got his way once more as Kenny Bayless, the official who has been accused of a Mayweather bias in the past, was taken out of the running.\n\nRobert Byrd was ultimately selected to be the man in the middle on August 26 while McGregor's request for an international judge was also granted as Italy's Guido Cavalerri was appointed alongside US scorers Burt Clements and Dave Morreti.\n\nAll in all, Wednesday couldn't have gone better for McGregor and his statement in the wake of the hearing tells you all you need to know about his take on the rulings.\n\n\"I am very pleased with the Nevada State Athletic Commission's handling of my next bout today,\" McGregor wrote on Instagram. \"Fair play was kept all the way through. Referee - Hall of famer Robert Byrd.\n\n\"Judges - Burt Clements. Dave Morreti and Guido Cavalerri. 8oz gloves approved. With pre and post fight analysis of the gloves on the night.\n\n\"This was handled very well and very fairly by the NSAC. Part of me is hoping maybe he can last so I can show some skill and dismantle him that way.\n\n\"But I do not see him absorbing the blows in the first few rounds.\"\n\nThe charismatic 29-year-old said a grueling training camp has taken him to \"hell and back\" and left him ready to face any kind of scenario inside the ring at the T-Mobile Arena.\n\n\"There is no way in hell that I'm not ready to fight in the deepest of trenches in this contest,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"We are ready for both scenarios. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\"\n\nUlimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\n- 'Hits like a truck' -\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters -- Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. Conor hits like a truck, so smaller gloves helps him big time. I think it absolutely does.\"\n\nMcGregor and Mayweather will climb into the ring following an international publicity tour last month marked by expletive-laden tirades and trash-talking.\n\nMcGregor, who was criticized for addressing Mayweather as \"boy\" during one event, dismissed suggestions that there was a racially tinged dimension to the duel.\n\n\"For me, it's athlete versus athlete,\" McGregor said. \"I'm disappointed to hear the way it's being portrayed. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done. It's a set way and there is no other way. Well, if that was the case we would have never reached across the oceans in search of other lands. We would never have gone into space.\n\n\"You have to have an open mind and you got to realize that there are other ways. Fighting is a complex game. {"timeCrawl": "16:17:00", "uri": "710988905", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:03:00Z", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "source": {"title": "InvestorPlace", "uri": "investorplace.com", "id": "771"}, "url": "http://investorplace.com/2017/08/how-to-watch-the-mayweather-mcgregor-fight/", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "UFC fans that want to watch the Mayweather-McGregor fight have plenty of options.\n\nOne of the options that may best appeal to millennials that want to watch the Mayweather-McGregor fight is DISH Network Corp's (NASDAQ:DISH) Sling TV. The streaming service will be offering the event as pay-per view to its customers.\n\nThose that want to watch the Mayweather-McGregor fight on Sling TV will have to have an account for the service. On top of this, they also need to shell out $99.99 plus tax for it. This will include the fight, coverage leading up to it and more.\n\nThere are also several other options for streaming the Mayweather-McGregor fight. The easiest way is to buy the fight directly from the UFC website. This gives users the ability to stream it from the following devices.\n\nThose looking to watch the Mayweather-McGregor fight the old fashioned way can order it from several local cable providers. Fathom Events will also be showing the fight at select theaters. {"timeCrawl": "05:51:00", "uri": "711271005", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:15:00Z", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "source": {"title": "Daily News", "uri": "nydailynews.com", "id": "422"}, "url": "http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/sports/mayweather-putting-legacy-line-worth-article-1.3421670", "eventUri": "eng-3366262", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3366262", "body": "By Frank Pingue\n\n(Reuters) - With his superfight against Conor McGregor a little over a week away, Floyd Mayweather struck a reflective tone on Thursday as he discussed the risk of coming out of retirement for a massive payday.\n\nMayweather, who has not fought in nearly two years, needs a win next week to surpass Rocky Marciano's record and reach 50-0 for his career, while McGregor, who is making his professional boxing debut, is 21-3 in mixed martial arts.\n\n\"When a fighter has lost before, if he loses again they say 'oh, it's nothing, he's lost before,'\" Mayweather told a conference call. \"But when a fighter has been dominating for 20-some years and never lost, everything is on the line.\n\n\"My legacy. My boxing record. Everything is on the line.\"\n\nThe fight, which the two combatants promoted with a four-city international media tour stretching across three countries, has garnered plenty of interest despite scepticism about how competitive it will be.\n\nMayweather, a master defensive technician and tactician, is heavily favored to win the Aug. 26 fight in Las Vegas but the 40-year-old has said that, on paper, everything leans toward the 29-year-old Irishman, who is taller and has a longer reach.\n\nMayweather acknowledged the physical demands of training for a fight had become much harder on his body than when in his prime, but said he did not let negative thoughts enter his mind.\n\n\"I try not to think about losing or taking the 'L.' That's not really my focus. Every day I tell myself I am a winner. I was born to be a winner at life. Not just in the ring but I was born to be a winner,\" said Mayweather.\n\n\"It's all about taking risk. I wouldn't be where I'm at if I didn't take risks so I don't mind putting a 49-0 record on the line, putting everything on the line for this fight. I feel like it's worth it.\"\n\nMayweather may be far from his prime but feels his sheer experience in the ring will carry him through what he says will be his last fight, one that is expected to be the most lucrative event in the history of combat sport.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 21 years ago. Of course not,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't think that I'm the same Floyd Mayweather that I was 10 years ago. I'm, not even the same Floyd Mayweather that I was I was five or two years ago.\n\n\"But I still have a high IQ in that ring. And experience wise, it leans toward me, period, because I have been in the ring at such a high level for so long.\"\n\n(Reporting by Frank Pingue in Toronto; Editing by Ian Ransom)\n\n(c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2017. I'm ready to go to war for 12 rounds and I'm ready to put him away early on.\"\n\nUlimtate Fighting Championship President Dana White also believes the gloves switch could shape the outcome of the fight.\n\nThe move is widely seen as benefiting both fighters - Mayweather's fast hands could be quicker with lighter gloves, while McGregor will be able to make his punching power more keenly felt, provided he can land a blow on his American opponent.\n\n\"I think it affects the contest a lot,\" White said when asked if McGregor would be helped by the change.\n\n\"Yes, Floyd will be faster with eight-ounce gloves but he's more defensive. All I can do is stay focused on my craft and go out and put a performance for my fans.\"\n\nMcGregor, meanwhile, said he has used disparagement by the boxing community as motivation.\n\n\"It has certainly been motivating, the disrespect and the disregard for my skill set,\" McGregor said.\n\n\"I look at people so many times and their mind is closed to how things can be done.
